business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws the attention of the Senate to the need to encourage participation in private health insurance both to allow individuals freedom of choice and to maintain a viable health system.

Your petitioners note with satisfaction the Government's proposal to provide a 30 per cent rebate on all private health insurance premiums, without means test, from 1 January 1999. This is necessary to allow those persons who are prepared to take responsibility for their own health care to be able to afford to do so.
We believe that health insurance is an essential part of our health care system.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to ensure that the legislation providing this rebate is passed without delay.

talk.start.para: Senator Watson(from 162 citizens)

petition.para: The petition of the undersigned shows that citizens are aggrieved by the unfair nature of the amendments to the Sales Tax Legislation 1992 which introduced and continues to have a discriminatory and disadvantageous impact on the Greyhound Racing Industry in both rural and metropolitan Australia.

The amended legislation removed the exemption from sales tax on food for greyhounds, a working animal purpose bred for racing, but maintained an exemption for sales tax on food for other racing animals.

Your petitioners request that the Senate amend sales tax legislation to reinstate sales tax exemption on animal food given to greyhound breeders and trainers prior to 1992. This action would re-establish the parity with other sections of the racing industry who have exemptions, or in the alternative, we request an amendment to allow the same exemptions given in other similar circumstances by redefining `Livestock' under the Act to include greyhounds (or racing animals) or else include greyhounds in the special classification for working dogs.

talk.start.para: Senator Faulkner(from 2,687 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in the Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned draws attention to the potentially damaging affects of National Competition Policy on small business such as newsagents.

Your petitioners ask the Senate in Parliament to call on the federal government to review the decisions of the Australian Consumer and Competition Tribunal which threaten the viability of newsagents and introduce legislation to override these decisions and preserve the current system of distribution for magazines and newspapers through Australian newsagents.

subdebateinfo.title: Days and Hours of Meeting and Routine of Business

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell)—as amended, by leave—proposed:
That—
(1) On Thursday, 10 December 1998—
(a) the hours of meeting shall be 9.30 am to 6.30 pm, 7.30 pm to midnight;
(b) consideration of general business, and consideration of committee reports and government responses under standing order 62(1) not be proceeded with;
(c) the routine of business from 7.30 pm till the adjournment shall be government business only;
(d) divisions may take place after 6.00 pm.; and

(e) the question for the adjournment of the Senate shall not be proposed till after the Senate has finally considered the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1998 and two associated bills, the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 and two associated bills, and the Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill 1998, or a motion for the adjournment is moved by a minister.
(f) if the Senate is sitting at midnight, the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 9.30 am on Friday, 11 December 1998.
(2) On Friday, 11 December 1998:
(a) the hours of meeting shall be 9.30 am to 12 noon, 1.00 pm to 6.30 pm, 7.30 pm to midnight; and
(b) if the Senate is sitting at midnight, the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 9.30 am on Saturday, 12 December 1998.
(3) On Saturday, 12 December 1998:
(a) the hours of meeting shall be 9.30 am to 12 noon, 1.00 pm to 6.30 pm, 7.30 pm to midnight; and
(b) if the Senate is sitting at midnight, the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 9.30 am on Monday, 14 December 1998.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I have no objections and I think the terms of this motion that have been redrawn by the Manager of Government Business are reasonable. I think the point that the opposition has made in negotiation with the government in relation to the hours of meeting and the routine of business in the Senate for tonight is this: if the Senate is close to completing its work around midnight, then, as far as the opposition is concerned, we would certainly look favourably at the Senate continuing its deliberations until that work is completed.

speech.para: This particular motion, of course, does not allow for that to occur. I think it is reasonable for me to say that, if that is the case and we can conclude our work in a reasonable hour after midnight—it may be the view of minor parties and other Independents; I do not know—as far as the opposition is concerned, I say this to the Manager of Government Business: we would look favourably at trying to facilitate the Senate's business in that way. It is difficult to make that assessment at 9.43 a.m., but obviously managers and whips can discuss this at a later stage. It might mean that, if that finds favour with the government and the minor parties and Senator Harradine, we can deal with the government's business program in that way.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to repeal and amend acts and make other provisions consequential on the enactment of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1998, to make technical amendments, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

This bill continues the process of reform of Commonwealth environmental legislation. It is an adjunct to the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998 which proposes the most fundamental reform of Commonwealth environmental legislation since the first environmental statutes were enacted in the early 1970's.

The Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 has three primary objectives. Firstly the bill provides for the repeal of the five acts to be replaced by the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998. These are the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, the Whale Protection Act 1980, the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, and the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992.

Secondly the bill puts in place savings and transitional arrangements for a smooth transition from the processes in place under the existing acts, including environment assessment and permitting arrangements, to the new schemes established under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998.

The bill also amends Commonwealth Government legislation that is affected either by the repeal of the five acts, or by the content of the proposed Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998.

The bill, together with the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998, provides a new environmental law regime which enables the Commonwealth to join with the States in providing a truly national scheme of environmental protection and biodiversity conservation, recognising our responsibility to not only this, but also future generations. It does so by respecting and building upon the strengths of our Federation and the primary responsibility of the States for delivering on-ground natural resource management. It does so also in a way that is "user friendly", with predictable, transparent, and timely assessment processes. By accepting Commonwealth leadership, respecting the role of the States, and providing best process for users, the new regime provides a framework within which to build public confidence and support for its vitally important objectives.
I commend the bill.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned till the first day of sitting day in 1999, in accordance with standing order 111.

speech.para: That the provisions of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 be referred to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report by 22 March 1999, with particular reference to:

(a) whether the bill, by treating companies differently depending on whether they are in a region covered by a regional forest agreement (RFA), provides for a discriminatory regime between one state and another which is inconsistent with section 99 of the Constitution;

(b) whether the bill is invalid to the extent that it refers to instruments not yet in force (RFAs that have yet to be concluded) or to instruments that can be varied without reference to Parliament or without a specific power in the bill enabling the variation;
(c) whether the compensation provisions in the RFAs are valid to the extent that they attempt to bind Parliament or fetter the exercise of executive power;

(d) whether the bill will limit Australia's capacity to meet its obligations under international treaties, in particular the World Heritage Convention, the Climate Change Convention, and the Ramsar Convention;

(e) whether the requirements of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 , the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992 have in fact been met, notwithstanding declarations to that effect in the RFAs; and
(f) any other matters that the committee considers relevant.

That the provisions of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 be referred to the Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee for inquiry and report by 22 March 1999, with particular reference to:

(a) the relationship between the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 and the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998, in particular, the activities regulated by each and the extent of the geographical areas covered by each;

(b) whether the bill will fetter the capacity of the Commonwealth to meet its obligations under the World Heritage Convention and the Climate Change Convention, or any other international convention, and in particular whether native forests that are either listed, nominated or identified as being of World Heritage value could be logged;

(c) the amount of compensation for which the Commonwealth would be liable if its ac tions directly or indirectly curtailed forestry or mining operations in areas covered by the regional forest agreement (RFA) as a result of Australia's obligation under the Climate Change Convention to reduce greenhouse gas emissions;

(d) the amount of compensation for which the Commonwealth would be liable if an action by it resulted in curtailment of forestry or mining operations in areas covered by the RFA for any of the following purposes:
(i) nomination or listing of an area for world heritage, for either cultural or natural values,
(ii) protection of species or communities that are found to be threatened during the next 20 years,
(iii) protection of the quantity or quality of water in a water catchment, and
(iv) flood mitigation;

(e) whether any remedy is available to the Commonwealth where a state is found to have breached the RFA, such as by logging illegally (as in East Gippsland) or by downgrading the status of reserves to permit mining (as in Tasmania);

(f) whether the requirements of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 , the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992 have in fact been met (notwithstanding declarations to that effect in the RFAs) and the environmental impact of RFAs overriding those Acts; and
(g) any other matters that the committee considers relevant.

talk.start.para: —These motions are an effort to have the provisions of the regional forest agreements around the country referred to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee and the Environment, Communications, Information Technology and Arts Legislation Committee. As a result of votes in the Senate yesterday, there is going to be no real scrutiny of the content of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 and the ramifications there are for this nation. I will not go over that ground except to say that this is the opportunity for the Labor Party to at least see that there is some scrutiny of the impact of a bill which is aimed to essentially take away the power of the federal or, for that matter, state governments to intervene on what the woodchip corporations have been doing in our forests for 20 years.

speech.para: We heard yesterday from Senator Murphy that there is gross mismanagement in the forests of Tasmania. To summarise, the woodchip corporations are using Forestry Tasmania as an instrument to rapidly as possible cut down the grand forests of Tasmania and export them for profit, which does not stay in Tasmania but is exported to shareholders of corporations like North Pty Ltd outside the state.

The small operators in Tasmania lose out. Senator Murphy sited the Cue River sawmill, which has been operating for 100 years, which is now closing at a time when the forests of Tasmania are being cut at the greatest rate in history. When the Green-ALP accord came to an end, because Labor broke its accord commitment, particularly section 9, by lifting the ceiling on woodchip exports in 1991, the rate was 2.7 million tonnes per annum. That is the limit to which woodchip exports had been capped for 10 years. The current rate is 4.6 million tonnes per annum. It is devastating the forests of Tasmania.

There is an added component, which is very important for the Senate to know, if it does not know already—that is, there is job shedding as the carnage of the forest increases. So in the period between 1991 and now, where the forests have been cut at something like double the rate, there has been job shedding because of automation and glomeration. Big corporations are sending 90 per cent of Tasmania's forests to the woodchip mills and, ultimately, the rubbish dumps of the northern hemisphere, while the small mills continue to close. This is gross mismanagement.

There is a case to be put for there being corruption in the forest industries of Tasmania. There is a prima facie need for an independent inquiry in Tasmania, if not in the other states. We have seen the uproar in Western Australia in recent days. There is a need, I believe, for a royal commission into the way in which this great resource in Tasmania is being exploited at a loss for Tasmanians. As you will know, Mr Acting Deputy President Watson, the people of Tasmania are getting something like $12 a tonne for the forests; freight on board for the woodchip company, $120 a tonne; when it comes out of the paper mills of Japan, $1,200 a tonne. This is an extraordinary set of figures showing just what an extraordinary loss of value occurs, as far as these forests are concerned, under the mismanagement of serial Labor and Liberal governments in Tasmania and Forestry Tasmania, which is nothing other than an instrument, a handmaiden, of the big woodchip corporations.

If we look at the job side of it—and the woodchip corporations always weep crocodile tears and say that they are there to defend jobs—we will see that, while some 2,500 jobs were shed in the logging of native forests in Tasmania, 3,500 jobs were created in the service, hospitality and tourism industries thanks to the native forests left standing. Whereas logging is shedding jobs as they cut faster, tourism is putting on extra jobs, even though the forests are dwindling. It is absurd.

It is irresponsible that this process should be cemented in place—a process which allows the forest to be destroyed by job-shedding, out-of-state industries for 20 years under this legislation and which we, in the Senate, will not send to be scrutinised by the proper committees before we vote on it. I want the Labor Party, if it is going to oppose this, particularly the Tasmanian Labor senators, to get to their feet and explain why they don't want this scrutiny, because they have become part of the problem if that is the way they are going to vote.
Senator Faulkner has just said to one of his colleagues that they are part of the problem if they do not support this bill going to these committees.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. It is incumbent on a senator not to eavesdrop on other senators' conversations. Senator Brown is quite wrong to have insinuated that I indicated to one of my colleagues that they were part of any problem. He misheard what I was saying and, as a result, has grievously misled the Senate. I would not like that to stand in Hansard in that form. It is unusual for me to do this, but on this occasion I ask that Senator Brown withdraw that slur and insinuation that I would have suggested such a thing of one of my colleagues. It is absolutely untrue. Although I do not take personal affront, one of my personal colleagues might take personal affront. On that basis, I think it might be better to withdraw.
—There is nothing to withdraw. There was no misuse of parliamentary language. I can hear right across the chamber very accurately.
—You should not be eavesdropping.
—Well, one should not be speaking in such an audible tone that it is interrupting the delivery of a very cogent argument to this chamber.
—Unfortunately, I was not able to pick up the full import of what you said. Therefore, I am not in a position to rule, Senator Brown.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. That is a good ruling. I was saying that the Labor Party owes it to the people of Tasmania, if not to every other state, if they are going to vote against these motions to say why. Why on earth, of all things, should there not be Senate committee scrutiny of this matter? I think one of the most important pieces of legislation this government will deal with next year is the regional forest agreements. They have created an uproar in New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania, and they will create an uproar in Queensland when they are announced there.
—You have created an uproar in Tasmania; they have not created an uproar in Tasmania.

—I am getting further interventions from, in this case, Senator Sherry from Tasmania, who is out of his seat, if I am not wrong, who says that there is no uproar in Tasmania. That blinkered, ostrich like attitude to the majority of Tasmanians that the tearing down of our grand and magnificent wild forests is wrong should have been brought to an end.

speech.para: But even if it is not, I ask this question: why should this legislation not go before these committees? Why should there not be scrutiny? Why should the public not have an opportunity to have input before the Senate deliberates on this legislation? I will tell you what I think. I think it is because of the sway of the woodchip corporations. I am very aware of the fact that, for example, North Broken Hill in the last couple of years has put $80,000 into the election baskets of both of the major parties. That is having an untoward effect on the way in which this whole debate is proceeding. You cannot look at matters like this important move to refer the RFA legislation to committees being blocked by the major parties without standing back and asking why. I believe there is enormous pressure from the logging corporations around this country to prevent such an outcome.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think that is a clear reflection on the motives of senators. Senator Brown has made that a very clear reflection. The fact is this Senate voted yesterday to refer these very bills to a committee for a period of at least two months. To say that there is some conspiracy and that senators are being manipulated or bribed to stop reference of these matters not only is patently absurd and contrary to the facts but also reflects on the motives of senators and how they vote in this chamber. And I think that any inference in relation to that should be withdrawn immediately and unreservedly.

—On the point of order, I agree wholeheartedly with Senator Ian Campbell. To suggest that people cast their vote on a particular matter on the basis of the allegations that Senator Brown made is certainly alleging an improper motive. It is exactly the same as the sort of scurrilous remark made yesterday when Senator Kemp accused senators of having improper motives when they voted on the superannuation surcharge.

—I have made no inference about any particular senator in this matter. If the parties feel fragile about the assertion I have made, then it is for them to get up and debate the matter. I might add that we need to be mindful in debating this matter, as I am sure all senators were yesterday, of the standing orders requiring anybody who has an interest in the matter to have declared it yesterday and to declare it today. That is a rule of this place.
—Senator Brown, the imputation does not have to be against individual senators, and I ask you to withdraw your allegation of improper motives.
—Sir, I ask you to look at what I said. I said that the corporations—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not think the honourable senator can debate your ruling; he can either accept your ruling, and do the proper thing, or he should move a motion of dissent on your ruling. He does not have any other alternatives, as far as I am concerned.
—Senator Brown, you have either got to withdraw or make it quite clear to everybody in the Senate that you are not imputing improper motives, either individually or collectively.
—If you look at the record, you will find that I was imputing the motives to the corporate sector, which wants to levy influence on this place, and not to the senators in this place.
—We have senators from either side of the chamber who both feel that you have imputed improper motives.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order, you gave Senator Brown a choice to either withdraw or explain the statement that he made. From the opposition's perspective, from the explanation that he has given, I can only come to the conclusion that that does not impugn individual senators and—
—That is not the issue.

—With respect, I think, given your ruling, it has become the issue, because you in fact asked Senator Brown to either withdraw or explain himself. From the explanation that I did hear Senator Brown make, I do not think that we can draw any further the inference that individual senators are being impugned.
—Collectively or individually.

—Yes. So, with respect, it seems to me that Senator Brown has complied in his own way with the request you properly made from the chair. I suspect, given that circumstance, the matter is dealt with. But, of course, it remains open for any individual senator to take the issue on in debate if they wish, because there may well be very little support from senators for the case that Senator Brown makes. But in relation to the ruling you have made, I think that has adequately been dealt with, and we ought to just get on with it.
—Senator Brown, continue your remarks.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I must say that the short debate that has just occurred is a very important one, and it is one that I will be coming back to in the future in this place. I was saying that I believe it is very important for the Labor Party—and the same applies to the government—to explain why, if they are going to vote against these motions, we ought not be seeing reference of this extraordinarily important regional forest agreement legislation to these committees so that the public can have the input that I know it wants to have. I think that the Senate is failing that public if it does not allow those committees to go to the places where there is turmoil over the destruction of forests in this country—and that does not just apply to conservationists; that applies to many businesses around this country of ours and many people employed in businesses which depend on forests being kept standing—so that they can have a say.

speech.para: It is right out of kilter that this legislation will not be subject to far greater scrutiny than what yesterday's motion would on the face of it allow it to have. If these motions go down, I will be one of those who will be trying to bring up constitutional and environmental issues before the committee under yesterday's reference. But it will depend on that committee. As things stand, there could be a total block on such matters being discussed. I do not think it is good enough to leave it to a committee to be good-hearted enough to decide it will accept evidence about the environmental downsides or the potential constitutional problems associated with the regional forest agreement legislation.

There is something untoward if the Senate does not send this legislation to these committees. I cannot say much more than that. Let those who vote against these references explain why they are going to do that, not only in this place but to the Australian public at large, remembering that opinion polls over the last decade have consistently shown that the great majority of Australians do not want the wild forests of this country further destroyed and they do want the plantation base which we have in this country, which is totally adequate for the country's wood needs, to be the total basis upon which woodchipping as well as other logging pursuits take place in the years ahead.

There can be a win-win situation. We can keep our wild forests and at the same time have a healthy industry based on plantations. Many people in here will not know that already 80 per cent of the wood products used in Australia come from plantations. There is the wherewithal to make that 100 per cent. The Tumut mill, announced with federal government support in the last week, is an example of that. I do not know why on earth Premier Carr in New South Wales was not, as part of the announcement there, saying, `We are putting an end to the cutting of wild forests in New South Wales.' It was a historic opportunity to say to the public, `Here we have got the end of wild forest cutting, the end of controversy and a mill based totally on plantations,' which is the way of the future. It was a political failure on a grand scale by the Carr government, which is the sort of political failure happening at the state level right around the country as far as forests are concerned.

That is another good reason why the whole thing should have been opened to much greater public scrutiny. The Senate, ultimately, is not doing itself a good turn if it does not allow that public scrutiny, because I can assure you that this legislation for the regional forest agreements—which is a prescription for wild forest destruction around the country—is going to be a major item for debate when it comes before this chamber some time in the new year.

talk.start.para: —I will briefly put the government's point of view on the reference of the provisions of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 to two committees. As I said in a point of order, the coalition rejects the claim that this bill will not get proper scrutiny. We supported a motion yesterday to have this very bill referred to the appropriate legislation committee—the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee—which I understand is chaired very well by Senator Crane, who I think is respected by all sides of the chamber.

speech.para: I am quite confident that any of the constitutional and environmental matters that Senator Brown has referred to and any submissions made on those matters will be given due consideration; that people making submissions on these matters will be heard by that committee; and that members of the public who want to make submissions or be heard by the committee from now until 15 February, a period in excess of two months, will be heard by this committee—the appropriate committee, an effective committee, a well-chaired committee and a committee on which a number of honourable senators who have given good service to this place sit.

I think it reflects on the committee, the committee secretariat and the members of that committee to suggest that that committee will not be able do its job. It has certainly done its job on a number of contentious, complex pieces of legislation during the term of the last parliament. I have absolute confidence that the members from various parties on that committee will fulfil their duties to the parliament and the people of Australia in giving proper consideration to, as Senator Brown calls it and the government concurs, this very important piece of legislation, which does seek to create a win-win situation for Australia's forests from a conservation point of view, a biodiversity point of view and a resource security point of view.

The committee will receive submissions. It will have public hearings. It will have, in effect, over two months to receive those submissions and deliberate on these matters and make a report to this parliament. It will, hopefully, then be a matter for this Senate to deal with when we return in the second half of February. So the coalition will be rejecting these motions. We believe they were debated at great length yesterday. The government believes that the debate has been had and the votes have been had. We would like to see the matter resolved this morning as quickly as possible.

talk.start.para: —The opposition does not support the motions of Senator Brown to refer the provisions of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 to two committees. In fact, we also reject quite strongly the assertions that he has made regarding our position on this issue. We, first of all, support the bill being considered by the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. That is the appropriate committee that should consider the legislation, and that is indeed what will happen.

speech.para: We do, however, want to make the point, as we did yesterday when the matter was debated, that the ultimate reporting date that was determined by the Senate, by the brutal use of numbers by the government, of 15 February does cause us some concern. There may well be two months between now and then, but everyone knows that it is not that easy to organise public hearings and conduct inspections, if necessary, over the December-January period.

We also know that work is being done by many other senators in other committees early next year, particularly those related to the GST. We raised that point yesterday. As I understand it, that was why we put forward the suggestion in the Selection of Bills Committee deliberations that the reporting date would more appropriately be a date in late March—22 March was the date we proposed. I understand that, at the time, the government was prepared to accept 8 March as a suitable reporting date but, as there was no agreement within the committee, it was understood that the issue would be ultimately resolved in this chamber.

We were rather surprised and believe it was pretty dirty pool on the part of the government yesterday to have pushed through, by the use of numbers, the date of 15 February as the reporting date. But that is an issue with regard to the ultimate reporting date of a reference which is already before the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. The committee will do everything it can to meet that timetable but, as we know does happen from time to time, if timetables become impossible to meet then it is open for the Senate to revisit that issue on a subsequent occasion. We will be pushing that view strongly in the committee in the hope that we can get more time for consideration of this legislation.

Putting that aside, on the central issue of Senator Brown's propositions, we reject them. We reject the allegation that we will not be serious about giving this legislation the scrutiny that it deserves and taking into account all the submissions that the committee receives. The bill is already before the appropriate Senate committee and, on that basis, we will be opposing the motions.

talk.start.para: —I rise in support of Senator Brown's notices of motion Nos 2 and 3 and I will speak briefly, aware that there is business of the Senate people wish to go on with. Yesterday, one of the reasons I was called out of the chamber during the ARPANSA bill, which I was deeply involved with, was that I was asked to do a brief interview on radio in Western Australia, which ended up being less than brief. It ended up, unbeknownst to me, that I was debating head to head with the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, Wilson Tuckey.

speech.para: The minister said that we were concentrating too much on the environmental aspects of regional forest agreements and that we should be more interested in the economic aspects. I thought that was very interesting from a minister who comes from Western Australia, because the whole process of the regional forest agreements has been given largely to the states. Of course, the mechanisms available within the states are the ones that are part of this intrinsic agreement which is coming together to be dealt with in this bill.

The irony in Western Australia is that Mr Tuckey said that economic consequences should be dealt with as well as environmental consequences. I actually happen to agree. I have always believed that the definition of `environment' should include the impact on the local economy. Having sat in on one unit of environmental law, it seems it was the intention—even if it was not written into the law—that the impacts on the environment, especially the local environment, and the impacts on the local economy should be assessed in the environmental impact assessment.

But what does that mean? It means that you look at the economy as a whole and not just on one narrow sector. Once you start looking at the economy as a whole—how it works, what fits in and what does not—often you find there are quite different circumstances from what you assumed in the first place. Honourable senators will remember that the Resource Assessment Commission was set up to do just that. It was set up, I suppose, to beat environmentalists around the head on the basis of doing assessments to see what the outcomes would be for communities and for the wider public interest.

Ironically they did their job too well. They did their job so well that they produced reports which looked at the balance between the environment and the economy and came out with different results from what was assumed. They asked people what they valued in certain areas like Kakadu. If you were to have a Resource Assessment Commission assessment of the Jabiluka proposal, most of us are quite sure of what people would say when asked what their values would be—what they would be prepared to pay not to have Jabiluka mined for uranium. There would probably be a few people throwing in cash from other parts of the world as well, if you were to do that. But that is not what the Resource Assessment Commission did.

Minister Tuckey says that we have it wrong, but he has not looked at the history of his own state. Unfortunately, we have a situation where there is an agreement between both of the major parties in this chamber that we will deal with this as a rural and regional issue—not deal with it as an environmental issue and not look at the legal issues in context. I will be very pleased if the rural and regional committee is able to look at the legal issues, if they can do it properly. But there is very limited time available, and we cannot be sure that the resources will be made available to that one committee even to be able to hold the hearings that may be necessary for the level of interest there is in this issue right around the country.

I am disappointed to hear what I have heard today. The numbers are quite clear in what is going to happen. But we have evidence that the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill, is sitting on his hands in relation to action on regional forest agreements already, even before some of them are signed. We can see that even the mechanisms that are available to the Commonwealth now are not being used. We also know that, after this bill is passed, there is no specific action that can or will take place that will guarantee that any agreements must be abided by. So it looks as though we will have a much worse situation than we have experienced up to now, and that is a great disappointment. These issues deserve to be given greater scrutiny. They are being passed over and shoved under the carpet. I am very concerned that this is the process we have come to. I support Senator Brown's motions.
Question resolved in the negative.

cognateinfo.title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1998
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 8 December, on motion by Senator Minchin:
That the bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Lees had moved by way of an amendment:
Omit all words after "That", substitute:
"the Senate:

(a) notes the evidence provided to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee that the rebate scheme will not take the pressure off public hospitals and is an inefficient and inequitable use of public funds;
(b) resolves that the bill not be read a second time; and
(c) calls on the Government to:
(i) introduce a means test to restrict eligibility for the rebate to hospital insurance for people on low incomes;
(ii) implement a review process to evaluate the rebate scheme against defined outcome measures;
(iii) require health insurance funds to achieve improved performance outcomes; and

(iv) address the key areas of need in the public health sector, including coordinated care for older Australians; waiting lists in public hospitals; public dental health services; rural health services; and the health care needs of indigenous Australians."

talk.start.para: —These private health insurance bills are of central importance to the way that we run Australian society. Much has been said already about these bills and about the wisdom or otherwise of devoting over $1 million to private health insurance. In talking about these bills and about health services overall, there are certain questions that should be asked, certain prospects that should be discussed and certain perspectives that should be looked at. Those things have been done in debates so far.

speech.para: This debate is essentially about who should bear the cost of illness and injury in Australia. Once somebody becomes ill or injured, there is a cost. The issue is who will bear the cost. It might be the person who is injured or the person who becomes sick. That person might bear the cost simply by having to suffer for a longer time than otherwise. He or she may have an illness which, if not treated, might be terminal or, at the very least, put people through considerable distress. Society could choose to say that the person who is going to bear the cost of this illness and trauma is the person who suffers it. He or she either bears it by simply going through the pain, distress and torture that illness and trauma can bring or by paying for treatment out of his or her own pocket. That is one alternative that we might take.

The doctors might bear the cost. In other words, you might have a health system where the doctors get less than they really ought. Indeed, that happens now, particularly with junior doctors in hospitals, who are paid at times less than they should be paid and who have to work overtime that is sometimes not paid. That is the other alternative; the doctors might bear the cost that comes about through illness or injury. Nurses might do it by working for longer hours than they should. Physiotherapists or dietitians or what have you also might. That is another choice that we could make. We could let the health providers bear the cost.

The hospitals might do it. The private hospitals in particular and the public hospitals are saying that they cannot afford to give the treatment that is needed to people who are injured or who suffer illnesses. The community might bear the cost through insurance schemes. In other words, you spread the cost across the community by having insurance schemes. The function of the insurance schemes is to gather money from the community generally and spread the loss that comes about through illness and injury. Everybody puts in, irrespective of whether they are ill or injured themselves, so that the community, as it were, bears the cost. The community could also bear the cost through taxation, either generally across the board or through specific imposts such as, for example, the Medicare levy.

They are the choices we face. This legislation must be looked at in that context. It should be looked at not only in the context of who should bear the cost of illness and trauma but also in terms of where the money might come from. That means not only in terms of insurance and taxation but also from other bodies. One thing that seems not to have been looked at in this context is how specialist insurance, if I can call it that, operates in all this. How much, for example, does the Transport Accident Commission in my home state of Victoria contribute to the cost? How much does the Victorian Workcover Authority contribute?

In looking at this legislation and in listening to the debate about it, that sort of question seems not to have been answered. I wonder why not. What contribution do bodies such as the Victorian Workcover Authority and the Transport Accident Commission make to the costs imposed upon people through injury and illness? There are bodies like them in all the states around Australia. What sort of contribution do they make? That question could be asked in the committee stage of this debate.

What does occur to people as they go through this debate is that the whole system seems not to be in control. There are institutions that cover people injured at work. There are institutions that cover people injured on the roads. There is private health insurance and private insurance, in any event. There are public and private hospitals. There are people who are underpaid. There are people who suffer and who cannot get proper treatment.

Those concepts do not seem to be addressed in the bill. What seems to be happening is that we are going to say, `Righto! We will contribute over $1 billion towards helping the private insurance industry.' And no doubt it is argued that, through helping the private insurance industry, a flow-down effect will occur and people will be better looked after. But it seems to me that in this debate that particular approach has been taken without having a wider vision of what it is all about. The explanatory memorandum seems to have ignored the concept of how we can best help health services across the board. It says on page 1, in the `General Outline and Financial Impact' statement:
The Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1998 will provide for a financial incentive for people who take out or maintain private health insurance.

It then tells how the incentive works. On page 56 of the explanatory memorandum, the section headed `Assessment of impact (cost and benefits) of the measures' talks about the particular people who will be affected and the particular funds which will be protected.

But there is no concept put forward in the explanatory memorandum of what we should be doing in the whole area of health, which is really about trying to get people better after they have become ill or have suffered trauma. It is a bad approach in a policy sense to confine the issue of how we get people better to one particular area. Say that somebody is injured on the road or at work, or gets sick in any particular circumstance. Where does he or she go to get money? To some sort of accident compensation scheme, if they are injured at work? To a fund that is supposed to look after people who are injured on the road? To a private insurance scheme, if they are injured in the home? Do they go straight to a public hospital? Or do they go to the local doctor? Unless we get a concept of what this is all about, we are in trouble.

There is one other matter I want to raise while we are talking about this, and I hope I have made the point clear. Legislation dealing with issues of health services should have the care of the sick and the maimed as its prime objective. It is not quite clear what weight the legislation before us gives to the sick and the maimed, as distinct from trying to prop up a system of private health insurance. I have read from the explanatory memorandum as an illustration of what I mean by that.

It does seem that the propping up of private health insurance is the prime objective here, rather than the care of the sick and the maimed. The legislation is an answer to a wrong question; namely, how private insurance can be subsidised. The right question should be who should bear the burden of sickness and injury. You can look at society as either a collection of individuals or a community where every member can benefit to the utmost. The legislation here sees society as a collection of individuals who have each got to get what they can out of the system. Unless we start thinking in a communal way, we will not get a solution to the issues that are raised by those who are sick and injured in our community.

talk.start.para: —The issue before us today is a choice between playing politics or good health policy. Good health policy demands that the government devote adequate resources to the public health system. It also requires that we endeavour to strike the appropriate balance between the public hospital system, Medicare and the private health insurance industry. The government seems hell-bent on diverting substantial sums of taxpayer funds from the public health system, from public hospitals, from the states—who have the responsibility for managing those hospitals—ultimately into subsidising private health insurance funds.

speech.para: It has been a disturbing trend of coalition conservative governments over many years that, in their ideological objection to Medicare, they have followed this path. It must be remembered that it was a Labor government back in the 1970s that introduced Medicare—then known as Medibank. It was Malcolm Fraser, when he was Prime Minister and John Howard was his Treasurer, who abolished Medibank. Whilst the government stands up and talks about the levels of private health insurance membership today and how they may have fallen, what they do not say is that, when they were in office between 1975 and 1983, they left 30 per cent of the Australian population totally uninsured. There was no universal health coverage system. There was no Medibank, because they abolished it. So many hundreds of thousands and, indeed, millions of Australians had no health cover at all.

It was only when the Hawke government came into power in 1983 and Medicare was introduced that once again we had a universal health coverage system, a system whereby all Australians could have access to decent, quality health care, particularly when they most desperately needed it, when illness or accident suddenly struck. It is in those circumstances that you need a decent, high quality, affordable, accessible public health system. Australia today stands, and has done for many years since the introduction of Medicare, as a world leader in providing the best of public health coverage.

This government, however, in its short 2½ years stripped some $2.6 billion out of funds available for the health system in this country. It took around $800 million out of public hospital funding in its first budget by slashing funds to the states—and the states were forced to find the money to make up that shortfall. It abolished the dental scheme, a scheme worth around $400 million which provided urgent dental care for persons who were unable to afford it. It took an incredible $1.4 billion out of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, making many necessary drugs and treatments far more expensive.

On top of that, they introduced the health incentive scheme, a scheme, they said, designed to encourage people back into private health insurance. They claimed that it would increase the rate that was declining. In reality, private health insurance membership did not increase at all—despite the $1.6 billion or approximately $650 million a year that was earmarked to be provided for that incentive scheme—but fell even further to its now lowest level ever of just over 30 per cent. That scheme was a failure, which was acknowledged by everybody, whether a Labor supporter or a conservative Premier. Indeed, many experts in the health industry recognise that it was a failure.

When the last round of Medicare agreements were being negotiated, what were the states unanimously calling for? Whether they were conservative or Labor governments, they were calling for greater funds to be directed into the public health system because needs were not being met through increasing waiting lists as a result of this federal government's failure to provide adequate funds.

This current proposal would provide a 30 per cent rebate with no means test to persons with private health insurance. So those people who have had to drop out of private health insurance because they were unable to afford the ever increasing premiums or were unable to afford the huge gaps that exist between the level charged by doctors and the amount refunded through private health insurance will suffer even further. This is a scheme which will reward all of those people who can afford to have private health insurance. The high income earners, and many of us in this parliament who are in private health insurance and who have stayed in it, will be rewarded whilst those who cannot afford it will not be in any greater position in terms of being able to access private health insurance. There is no means test and, furthermore, there is no discrimination at all between the types of coverage for which the rebate will be paid.

Coalition ministers such as Senator Herron have talked about how they believe the previous scheme reached a position where health insurance membership had plateaued and was on the increase. That is what we were constantly being told by Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care in this chamber. Yet, at the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee's hearing on 4 December, the evidence of Mr Schneider, representing the Australian Health Insurance Association, was that it was declining and was continuing to decline irrespective of the government's measures.

So one has to ask the logical question: why should throwing more money at this system work? Of course the answer is that it will not. Until we are able to address the fundamental problem of private health insurance in this country—that is, the issue of the gap—these sorts of schemes will simply not work. Whilst it might be very attractive and it might be seen as good politics to pay substantial amounts of money by way of a rebate to the 30-odd per cent of people who have private health insurance, it is certainly not good health policy.

Everyone knows that the major problem with private health insurance is that you pay your $2,000-odd a year for your family cover and you get your doctor of choice but, after you have had elective surgery in a private hospital, you often find that, whilst your hospital costs may have been met, your medical costs have not been met because the surgeon has charged well in excess of the schedule fee. The private health companies pay a refund of only 25 per cent of the schedule fee. Further, they do not cover the gap between the doctors' fees and the schedule fee. It should be remembered that private hospitals have the benefit of the fact that, for all the medical procedures that are undertaken in private hospitals, 75 per cent of the schedule fee—that is, the costs of the surgeon, the anaesthetist or whomever—are met out of Medicare, they are met out of public funds. So we are already providing substantial support to private hospitals.

I just want to finish on two other points. Everyone knows that, whilst we do need, and we on this side support, a strong private hospital system that complements the public hospital system, first and foremost the objective of government is to support the public health system. I hear time and time again of situations where after people have gone into a private hospital for an operation, something serious has developed following that procedure and they have been very quickly transferred, in some cases just across the road, to the public hospital.

It is a fact that many private hospitals do not provide all of the facilities that can be obtained in a public hospital, whether they be crash carts or the sorts of intensive care units that patients in a critical condition may need. Essentially, we are providing huge amounts of money to support private hospitals, profit making enterprises, dealing largely in providing elective surgery at the expense of much needed funds that should be in the public hospital system.

The final point I wish to make is this: I obtained some information about where in New South Wales private hospitals are located. It is very interesting to note that, of the 85 private hospital licensed establishments in New South Wales, 23 are in the northern Sydney area, eight are in the central Sydney area and 15 are in the south-eastern Sydney area. That is, over 50 per cent of private hospitals in New South Wales are located in areas which are in northern, eastern or central Sydney.

It is no wonder that people in rural and regional areas, in western Sydney where they only have five private hospitals, in south-western Sydney, or in the far west where there are none, according to this table, are screaming out, saying that they want decent hospital systems in their regions rather than huge amounts of funds being diverted into private hospitals which ultimately will be accessed more by the higher income earners of this country than by the general public.

talk.start.para: —I thought I might begin my contribution on the second reading debate on this legislation by quoting from the 1998 platform of the Australian Labor Party, which says this:

speech.para: Labor remains resolutely committed to universal access to publicly funded health services through Medicare. Labor will work to ensure that health resources are allocated on the basis of need and people are not excluded from necessary services because of their economic circumstances.

Labor is committed to maintaining the effective integrity of Medicare as a system of universal health insurance that will finance the delivery of high quality, medical and public hospital services to all Australians.

These are the principles that the Labor Party will honour and will uphold, as we deal with this legislation; they will guide the approach of the Labor Party on this matter that is currently being dealt with by the Senate. Our Labor Party platform, in regard to the private sector, also says this:
Labor recognises the role of the private health sector and remains committed to a balanced health system making best use of both public and private sectors.

The private sector must operate under appropriate government regulation. In particular, Labor remains committed to a private health insurance system which does not discriminate on the basis of age, sex or health.

The critical point of this is balance: we want a balanced health system that makes the best use of both the private and the public health sectors. This legislation before the parliament now is unfair: it does not provide balance, and it certainly, I have to say, is not good policy.

We think that the best way to boost hospital funding and reduce hospital waiting times for surgery is to directly fund public hospitals. The public hospital system is our priority because that is where the greatest need exists. We believe that spending money directly on treating patients is the most effective way of reducing waiting lists. We encourage people, of course, who wish to take out private health insurance. But we know that for many people in Australia, people on low incomes particularly, the public health system is the only option they have.

The hundreds of millions of dollars that are being thrown at this rebate in this legislation would go a very long way to improving the public hospital system—and that would be of benefit to all Australians. The rebate being proposed by the government is inherently unfair. It does not provide balance, nor will it achieve its desired objective of increasing the take-up of private health insurance, and therefore reduce pressure on the public health system—and that is very strongly backed up by the National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health, which I thought put forward some strong and persuasive arguments against the legislation at the Senate committee hearing last Friday. Just look at what it actually said to the Senate committee. It summarised its position as follows:

First, that it will not fix the problem it seeks to fix, it will probably make the problem worse and it is highly unlikely to do anything to improve the quality of health care available to the Australian people;
second, that the huge proposed transfer payment would be more efficiently and equitably used in other ways;

third, that the problem that has led the government to this point should now be the stimulus for real reform of private health insurance, making it supplementary to, not a competitor with, the publicly funded health care system.

There is no evidence that the private health insurance rebate will take the pressure off public hospitals. If you take the example of the government's existing means tested rebate—which, of course, the proposal before us is supposed to replace—you find that it has not increased the number of people taking up private health insurance. The new rebate will benefit primarily people who have existing private health insurance.

The government's estimate for increasing the number of people with private health insurance is a mere 2.7 per cent. That is the government's figure—a mere 2.7 per cent increase; up from 30.3 per cent to 33 per cent. That is a 2.7 per cent increase at the cost of $1½ billion. That is what the government is proposing, and we say that it is simply not good enough. Minister Wooldridge, I noticed, boasted an increase to 40 per cent in his second reading speech in the House of Representatives. A private hospital survey has claimed that the rebate would result in a boost to coverage to 45 per cent. Again, you have to ask this question: where is the evidence to back up those sorts of claims?

I mentioned the evidence of the National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health given to the Senate committee. I think they presented a very worthwhile and impressive submission to the Senate inquiry. On the question before us, they said:

. . . this is a clumsy and predictably ineffective way to achieve what the government wants to achieve. This approach would lock the government into an inflexible $7 billion spending program which would not produce the desired offsets in the public sector . . . this subsidy is likely to exacerbate the problem for the private funds of adverse selection and differential risk dropouts, without addressing the underlying problem.

We say that the government is throwing good money after bad. It is sticking a whopping $1.5 billion into the private health system—money, of course, that is desperately needed in the public health system in public hospitals; money that could really make a difference in the public health system. It is directing this enormous amount of money exclusively to private health insurance owners, and we say that is patently and transparently unfair. It will benefit most those who need it least. It will benefit most high income households, most of whom already have private health insurance. How obviously unfair.

In May of this year the Australian Bureau of Statistics produced a private health insurance survey which demonstrated a direct correlation between income and private health insurance. It showed that of those earning less than $20,000, 22 per cent have private health insurance; of those earning between $50,000 and $60,000, 60 per cent have private health insurance; and, of those earning over $70,000, 72 per cent have private health insurance. Most low income families in Australia cannot afford private health insurance. They simply cannot afford it, and that is the case with—
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Exactly, Senator West and Senator Denman. They cannot afford it with or without a rebate. That is the truth of this issue. That is why we say the priority here must rest with the public health system—and that is Labor's priority—because it is the system that most Australians rely on. That is the fundamental principle that guides the Labor Party in its approach on this legislation.

speech.para: But I do not want to suggest for one minute that the unfairness stops there. Pressure on public hospitals will not be relieved by extending the rebate to all ancillary services. There is no justification at all for doing that. Take the example of what I think is the great injustice on dental health. While abolishing the Commonwealth dental health scheme, which was, as I recall, worth $100 million—a scheme that provided dental health care and treatment to pensioners and low income people—those with private insurance are going to get a 30 per cent rebate on their dental premiums. That is the government's approach. Nearly $200 million of the rebate will go to subsidising private dental treatment. On the other hand, the low income people in our community wait at least a couple of years for treatment.

We now have, as I say, this open-and-shut case of the unfairness of the legislation that is now before the parliament, but we also have the spectacle of the government trying to turn debate on this legislation into just another typically tawdry Liberal Party political stunt. As far as the government is concerned: forget about the health system and the health issues—the debate really is not about that. There is an election on the horizon in the state of New South Wales. That is an election, of course, that the coalition obviously desperately wants to win. So the debate no longer is about the policy issues, and I am sure that in particular my colleague from New South Wales, Senator West, has noted this. The debate is not about the policy but it is about the politics—the politics of the New South Wales election in March of next year.

I just want to mention this as I conclude my remarks on this bill. John Howard is now less focused on the January 1999 start-up date for this rebate than he is focused upon realising political advantage in forcing the Senate to reject an unaltered or unamended and unnegotiated piece of legislation which the vast majority of commentators and experts agree is bad policy. Mr Howard, the Prime Minister, is perfectly happy to risk his January 1999 start-up—risk it all—for a bit of politics to play in the New South Wales election in March of next year. Of course, he has his pollsters like the discredited Mark Textor. They have, apparently, predicted significant political advantage to the New South Wales Liberal Party in forcing the Senate into some game of brinkmanship on this legislation. We are told that it would suit the New South Wales Liberal Party if the Senate does not pass the legislation in time for a January 1999 start-up so they can reintroduce this legislation in three months time.

talk.start.para: —Anything to take the focus away from their leadership problems.

—That's true, Senator West. But also, of course, three months time is right on the eve of the New South Wales election. I am glad you raised the issue, Senator West, of the Liberal Party leadership in New South Wales because you have a situation, which has been demonstrated so clearly during the debate on this legislation, where the Prime Minister is far more interested in matters relating to the internal dynamics of the New South Wales Liberal Party than he is in what ought to be his responsibility—the health of Australian families. What he is on about is the health of his stumbling protege in New South Wales, Ms Kerry Chikarovski, and Mr Howard's and Ms Chikarovski's cronies in the New South Wales Liberal Party.

speech.para: I draw the Senate's attention to last week's article in the Bulletin by Mr Laurie Oakes, who reported that before John Howard committed his government to the 30 per cent rebate on private health insurance premiums he had the concept market tested. The results, as reported in the Bulletin, were unequivocal in regard to its popularity. According to—and I use this term advisedly—the `researcher', the only proposal he had ever found to be more popular was the reintroduction of the death penalty.

This policy, this legislation, that we are debating has been poll driven from its conception. I put all my money on who did the research. You can bet your life it was Mark Textor, that grubby, unprincipled push pollster for the Liberal Party. No doubt as has been reported, his most recent polling is inextricably linked to both Ms Chikarovski's leadership coup and the politics of the 30 per cent tax bribe for upper income earners. I assume polling was uppermost in Dr Wooldridge's mind when he threatened on the weekend to bring the legislation back to the Senate for a vote a week before the New South Wales election if it did not pass unamended this week.

I will be very interested in the Liberals' approach during the committee stage of this debate. I will be very interested to see whether Dr Wooldridge will be delivering on that threat that he made on the weekend or whether it was just a bit of breastbeating and empty rhetoric, as we have come to expect from people like Dr Wooldridge, or whether the Liberals will contemplate no amendment at all to this legislation—whether they happen to consider that that's in their political interest. Don't think for one minute that threats and brinkmanship are going to work with us. They are not. They are not going to work with the Labor Party; they never have. We are going to stand by our principles.

talk.start.para: —Our policy.

—What we are going to do is stand by our policy and stand by the public health system in this country. We are not ashamed of that. We are opposing this legislation in the name of fairness and balance. That is what drives the Labor Party's approach on this. We are opposing it because we want to ensure the health of our public hospital system, we want to ensure the health of all Australians and we want to ensure that low income people in our community are not disadvantaged. I commend the approach of the opposition. (Time expired)
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to move an amendment to my second reading amendment.
—I point out that I wasn't consulted.

interjection.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Senator Tambling, this is no major change to the amendment.
—Could I just be clear, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Senator Lees is seeking leave to amend her second reading amendment? I assume that is what is occurring.
—Senator Less has leave to move her amendment.
—I shall amend my second reading amendment by adding just two words, `and middle', to paragraph (c)(i), so that it will now read `for people on low and middle incomes'. I move:

speech.para: Paragraph (c), subparagraph (i), omit "low incomes", substitute "low and middle incomes".

talk.start.para: —I would like to state very clearly at the outset that I do have a small amount of private health insurance—about the lowest you can buy. I have some insurance that enables me to receive doctor of choice treatment in a public hospital, but I am beginning to wonder about the value and benefit of private health insurance, like so many other people in this country. Let me give an example of why I feel this way. I had my gall bladder removed during the break recently. The doctor's bill was pretty much on par with what I got back from Medicare and Medibank Private, but the anaesthetist's bill took the cake. For two hours of being trundled into the theatre on a trolley and being trundled out of the complex to the ward on a trolley, I scored a bill from the anaesthetist for $500. I had to write a cheque for $223.75, which was the gap.

speech.para: The gap is not a problem for people on my income, which is around $100,000 a year. The Prime Minister, in answering questions on why this proposal is so wonderful, talked about how people are scrimping and saving to be able to purchase health insurance. They need to do a hell of a lot more scrimping and saving if they are going to cover this gap. This proposal is bad policy. It does nothing to address many of the fundamental problems and issues that need to be addressed in the provision of health care. There is nothing in this proposal that will rein in the activity of some doctors. I say `some doctors' because I can give you an example of my surgeon's bill which was quite close to the mark. Probably the only reason it is not closer to the mark is that I am having a disagreement with the HIC over a small amount of money, in the region of $9 to $10.

A former neighbour of mine several years ago who had maximum private health insurance and maximum ancillaries—the whole box and dice—had cataracts removed. She wrote cheques for $3,000. She had to have both eyes done, so all in all she ended up writing cheques for $6,000. We are not talking figures that are within the ballpark of being able to be afforded by the average, ordinary person. We are talking figures that can be afforded only by the 70-odd per cent of people earning more than $70,000-odd a year who have private health insurance.

This is legislation aimed at greed and not need. This is not good policy. Senator Faulkner has pointed out a number of things that have driven this. I want to look at how this will impact upon rural areas. We know from the submissions to the inquiry last week that the Western Australian government raised a concern that there are only two private hospitals outside the metropolitan area in Western Australia. What incentives are there? Why do people in Western Australia outside of Perth require private health insurance? Their only opportunity for health treatment is in the public system.

If you have an accident or you have a major illness, where are you going to end up? You are going to end up going through casualty or emergency into the public health system. For anybody who disagrees with that, let me remind them, as I have done on many occasions, that my background is nursing. I am a member of the two colleges of nursing in this country. I do not speak in this case on their behalf, but I do speak as somebody who has a background in nursing. I am older than most of the advisers in the box. I can tell them that this has been the case for the last 30-odd years that I know of.

I can remember working in a public hospital, in a teaching hospital in Sydney, 25 years ago and having somebody who was earning a six-figure sum a year admitted to our ward because he had thrown off a pulmonary embolus from a deep venus thrombosis. He was admitted to a teaching hospital in the middle of the public ward. It was the Royal Prince Alfred that he was admitted to. He eventually moved to the private section in Gloucester House. But for time immemorial that sort of level of acuity has always ended up, and should continue to end up, in our public hospital system because for the most part that is where the best treatment is available.

I find this piece of legislation obscene. It find it obscene that somebody like me on an income of $100,000 a year is offered a 30 per cent rebate to encourage me to take out private health insurance which I already have. I find it obscene that included in that 30 per cent rebate are ancillaries such as dental. If this legislation is passed, I think it is an obscenity that $200 to $300 million will be spent to give people who have some form of income, and who are on the whole wealthier, access to dental care through ancillaries and to not give that money to lower income people through the state system. It is an injustice.

We will very shortly, if this legislation is passed, not need to ask a person anything about their income, their occupation or their status. We will be able to line them up behind those boards you see at fairgrounds with a hole for the face and ask them to smile. Because it will be quite apparent who has and who has not got money. If you do not have money, you will have holes in your teeth. If you do have money and you have private health insurance, you will have a perfect smile. That to me is an obscenity.

I also want to talk about some of the other issues that this legislation does not address. The issues of waiting lists are not addressed. Occupancy in the private health system is very high, as well as in the public health system. This does not address the shortages of doctors in various places and the shortages of specialists. This does not address the fact that a number of colleges that allow access for specialist training have, I would allege, almost monopolistic and cartel-type activities in keeping their numbers restricted. This government is all for competition, but it is not looking at the behaviour of some of those colleges and their restriction of competition. Maybe Professor Fels should look at them and not some of the other areas. It does nothing to address those issues.

This legislation does nothing to address the shortages of occupational therapists, speech therapists, dietitians, physiotherapists and social workers in rural areas of Australia. It does nothing to address the problems and the shortages of mental health services in rural Australia. This will not help bring one more of these professional people to the bush and maybe even to the outer areas of some of the capital cities, particularly Sydney. This legislation does nothing to address these fundamental problems that we have to address in health.

This is legislation which, as I said, is an obscene and unjust piece of legislation which gives those of us on my income a bit more money and does not give a service that I consider to be an absolute basic service essential to life and human dignity. It does not give that. This is the most unchristian piece of legislation I think I have seen come into this place in some considerable time. This is about giving to the haves and not sharing with the have-nots, and I find it an obscenity. I find it an obscenity that people can get a rebate to buy a pair of Reeboks or running shoes. That sort of business will not help the public health levels in this country and will not do anything to reduce people's usage of the public health system.

The money could far better spent in many, many other ways. This, as I said before, is bad policy. It is bad legislation. It has been put forward by a government which is being poll driven and thinking only of political advantage and not the advantage, the benefit and the wellbeing of this country. For that, the government should be roundly condemned.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in this debate briefly today, firstly, to indicate that my family has private health insurance. I suspect that, as a result of that, I am not paying the additional one per cent Medicare levy as one who falls in the higher income levels that attract the levy. I will be opposing this inequitable legislation which proposes to grant me a significant tax concession whilst I am exempt from paying this additional Medicare levy. This legislation will give a person on the income level of a senator, member of parliament or the many higher income earners in the community a significant advantage over the bulk of the constituents of my state of Tasmania, more than 80 per cent of whom have a family income of less than $50,000. I believe that the recent census information distributed by the Parliamentary Library this year points that out very clearly from my examination of the figures.

speech.para: This legislation will give someone like me a significant financial advantage. I do not propose to canvass figures because I think they have been most eloquently dealt with by my colleagues earlier in the debate. It will give a very small benefit, if any benefit at all, to the bulk of the constituents of my state, and certainly I am talking about those who hold private health insurance. The many thousands of families who do not hold family health insurance, who cannot afford family health insurance or who believe that family health insurance is not attractive because, even if you have the insurance, you still get significant bills—and we have just heard about that from Senator West—are all going to be significantly disadvantaged by this legislation.

I also oppose this bill because ultimately it threatens the future of the public hospital system in my state. It means that those hospitals will not be receiving the funding in the future that they need to provide the services that everyone—all Tasmanians, whether insured or not—may ultimately rely upon, particularly in relation to critical care issues or complex medical procedure issues which are not provided by the private health system.

After talking to constituents during the last election campaign who are holders of private health insurance, particularly independent retirees who saw some benefit in this government policy, I was heartened that, when they were confronted by the approach of the Labor Party—that is, we support seeing the public health system funded so that the kind of care that particularly elderly Tasmanians may need in terms of deterioration of health issues and medical procedure issues is provided in preference to rewarding only those who have private health insurance—I received an indication that the representatives of the independent retirees found that to be quite a valid concern and one which they thought very worthy of consideration.

I am curious about a comment I received from a coalition senator about this legislation. It is an aspect that I had not considered until the point was made to me.
