The point was that, because members, senators and other higher income earners are paying a higher Medicare levy by virtue of the levy being a percentage of income, the private health insurance rebate was in fact a way of getting back part of that higher Medicare levy that the higher income earners are paying when compared, for example, with the combined effect of paying the Medicare levy and private health insurance between people on lower and higher incomes.

I found that comment curious at first. Ultimately, I guess it fits in with the Labor Party's view of where the coalition is coming from in relation to this legislation: this is yet another way of undermining the Medicare system. The Medicare system, whatever the government has been saying about it, exists to provide universal medical services for the community, whether insured or not. Labor has always supported a parallel system. If the ultimate effect of this legislation is to undermine the funding of the public health system to bolster the funding of the private health system, then I do not think constituents of my state will see that as anything other than an anathema to their interests.

At the end of the day, people in Tasmania, if they have major problems, rely on the public hospital system. I am sure that is not just the case in Tasmania but all over Australia. People rely upon the public health system, particularly for critical care, as I said earlier. If the funding of the public health system is sacrificed in the interest of funding private health insurance, which will ultimately, I suspect, bolster the private health system to the detriment of the public health system, then that is against the interests of all of my constituents.

To the extent that there have been newspaper advertisements and lobbying in my state, I say to the people who placed those advertisements that they should look not at the issue of self-interest but at the interests of the health system for the whole of the population of Tasmania when this matter is considered. I remind my constituents and the Senate that the Labor Party is doing just that in saying that we oppose this legislation as inequitable and a threat to the public health system Australia wide.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is discussing the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1998 and associated bills. It is a sad moment for the Senate to be discussing such poorly targeted legislation—legislation which was conceived during an election campaign when the government was in some difficulty in making election promises, legislation which the government now seeks to gain some political advantage from in the forthcoming election in New South Wales. This bill is not about health care. This bill is blatant politicking on behalf of a government that does not care.

speech.para: This bill will do nothing to resolve the problem that was headlined in the Perth Sunday Times on 29 November this year, just a couple of weeks ago: `97 die awaiting surgery'. Ninety-seven people died awaiting surgery. The $1.7 billion that the government will hand out to people who do not need it, like me on the salary that I have, would be better served going to alleviate the difficulties of Western Australians and their relatives who cannot get hospital treatment. But, no. Mr Howard and Mr Wooldridge are seeking to put money in my pocket. I am on $100,000 a year. I have private health insurance. I do not need an incentive in the form of a tax rebate to remain in health insurance. I have the money to afford it.

Why are you doing this? Mr Howard, why are you spending $900 million in giving tax rebates to people earning more than $70,000 a year? This is absolutely stupid legislation, particularly so when you get headlines such as: `97 die awaiting surgery'. It is even worse when you get a headline such as the one that appeared on the front page of the Australian newspaper on Friday, 27 November 1998: `Health funds reap $300m fee bonanza'. We are going to put more publicly funded money in their direction. What has gone wrong?

There is obviously a major difficulty in the Prime Minister's office, the cabinet office and in the government party room if they continue to proceed with this bill and not either send it back for a rethink or accept some amendments on the floor at the committee stage. I understand that your party, Mr Acting Deputy President Watson, is not going to negotiate on that. This is absolutely criminal activity on behalf of the government—propping up health funds which actually need a great deal of scrutiny as to how they operate.

Who said they need scrutiny? The Private Health Insurance Ombudsman's annual report, tabled very recently in this place, said they need scrutiny. Complaints against the private health insurers are up by 60 per cent on the previous year. One can understand that when you see the full-page advertisements that appear in the media. I quote from the West Australian newspaper of Saturday, 28 November:
An open letter to Members of Federal Parliament
This is from one Michael Gurry, Managing Director of HBF, Hospital Benefits Fund of Western Australia. Mr Gurry addresses me and my colleagues saying:
Members of Federal Parliament
I write on behalf of the 1,056,310 electors and their families in Western Australia who have private health insurance to ask why some of you refuse to allow them a 30% refund . . .

Who gave Mr Gurry the authority to put that letter in on behalf of me and my family as members of a private health fund? Neither he, his organisation nor the individual fund which I am a member of consulted me about putting a letter like that in. Mr Gurry went further, though, he wrote direct letters to members of parliament. He sent a letter by way of fax to me—and, I guess, to my other parliamentary colleagues—on 26 November 1998. He said:
Dear Senator McKiernan
I am writing on behalf of the 830,000 members of the Hospital Benefit Fund of Western Australia to express their concern at the attacks the Labor Party is making on private health insurance.

I read the Hansard from the other place, and I did not see any attacks on private health insurance. Perhaps the reason my comments are toned the way they are is because I am replying directly to Mr Gurry about what he did in putting forward that letter to me. I wrote back to him on the same day asking him to confirm the membership. I quote from my letter:
Your fax says 830,000 members, but the annual report of the Private Health Insurance Administration Council suggests you have a total membership (hospital and ancillary) of 392,489 at June 1998.
I asked him which was the true figure. A week later, Mr Gurry responded by saying:
I confirm HBF does have 830,000 individual members. HBF classifies all individuals covered by HBF as members.
The babies, the infirm—everybody is supposed to be a member according to him. The letter goes on:
The figures referred to in the PHIAC report for June 1998 are for Health Insurance policies not coverage.
For your information HBF has 788,000 Health members and 42,000 General Insurance members.

Mr Gurry is putting forward absolute lies, without the authority of his members, to me as a member of parliament. He asked for a copy of this speech, and I will ensure that he gets it. I hope that in the fullness of time the Department of Health and Aged Care or the Private Health Ombudsman will do something to bring some respectability into the way in which some of the health insurance funds operate. There are many that would appear to be lining their own pockets at the expense of those insured.

Earlier this year, I, like many others in the community, following the last round of increases, gave very real consideration to whether or not I would remain as a member of my fund. As I said in my earlier comments, I can afford to be in it. On the salary that I earn, I can afford to retain coverage. The reason I considered dropping out was the ever increasing cost of the insurance. This particular bill that is before us now—giving away something like $1.7 billion of taxpayers' money—does nothing to address those ever increasing premiums that I and other members of health funds have to pay.

The bill does nothing—as previous speakers have said—to address the biggest problem associated with private health insurance, and that is the gap. It does absolutely nothing to address the gap difficulties. Senator West, giving the most recent of the excellent contributions from this side of the chamber, outlined some of the finer details on that and, rather than use the time of the chamber now, I refer people to Senator West's and Senator Faulkner's excellent recent contributions on this. There were other contributions as well.
Senator Forshaw interjecting—

talk.start.para: —And Senator Forshaw also made some comments, as I recall. The gap is the major problem associated with the health insurance industry in Australia today, yet we have the government coming into this place presenting legislation which does nothing to address it.

speech.para: The final thing I want to talk about in the limited time that I have imposed on myself—and that we, on this side of the chamber, have imposed in order to progress the legislation—is the letters that I have received from my constituents in Western Australia. I am quite pleased to receive letters such as those. I am very disappointed to receive letters from doctors, specialists and professors which are rote letters, probably drafted in a public relations office in the Hospital Benefit Fund. I expect a little bit better from professional people than that. The Hospital Benefit Fund have been the main leaders of the campaign in Western Australia, and that is a bit disappointing. All of the individuals who have written to me have got a response. Some of them have asked for copies of my speech and, indeed, those who have asked will get a copy of it. I am very disappointed, as I said, that learned and highly educated people should just take form letters and send them on. The campaign just has not had an effect. They have wasted their time and their energy in sending these letters through.

It is a crying disgrace that the funds have used the elderly in our society. I have got great sympathy for those who are on pensions who do continue to hold health insurance, who do—as they said in their letters—go without meals in order to keep up their payments because it is something they have always done. The funds have got to be condemned for using people in the way they have used those in Western Australia.

I would hope, whether this bill passes or does not pass, or whether it passes in an amended form, that the funds themselves sit back and have a look at their own conduct in this whole thing. The way they have managed themselves in order to line their own pockets, in order to get an increase in membership for private hospital cover of a mere 2.7 per cent—from 30.3 per cent to 33 per cent coverage—is not to their credit. It is appalling what they have done. One would hope that they will learn something from this whole escapade. Perhaps next year, when the parliament has more time to look at them in detail, there might not be the damning reports from the Private Health Insurance Ombudsman that we have seen this year.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998
Consideration resumed from 9 December.

talk.start.para: —The committee is considering the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 and an amendment moved on behalf of the opposition by Senator Forshaw. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

interjection.para: Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I would normally ask leave to move the Greens (WA) amendments Nos 1 and 2 together, but we have seen opposition amendment No. 1 incorporate part of the Greens (WA) amendments. So I will be basically asking for the chamber to consider agreeing to Greens (WA) amendment No. 1. This is different in that it actually asks that nothing in the act is to be taken to authorise the construction or operation of a nuclear fuel fabrication plant, a nuclear power plant, an enrichment plant, a reprocessing facility or a nuclear waste storage or disposal facility.

speech.para: Considering the government has made statements on a number of these issues, especially in recent times on waste storage, disposal and so on, then I am sure it would have no problem at all in agreeing to this and indicating quite clearly without any doubt that this is not what this legislation is meant to, or can, be used for in the future. Therefore, I commend this amendment to the chamber. It makes it clear and unequivocal that this legislation cannot be used simply to allow a CEO to rubber-stamp an authority or a licence for any of those mentioned facilities.

talk.start.para: —I indicate on behalf of the opposition that we are prepared to support Greens (WA) amendment No. 1. These fac ilities, such as nuclear power plants, do not exist in Australia at the moment. We understand that there is no either medium-term or long-term intention on the part of the government to proceed to construct such facilities. On many occasions the government has made it clear that, whilst it is determined to build a replacement research reactor located at Lucas Heights, it has stressed that it was not prepared or had no intention of building a waste reprocessing plant at the same site. On that basis alone, one would think that the government should be prepared to support this amendment. As I said earlier, we are happy to support it.

—The Greens propose the addition of clause 9A which explicitly states that nothing in the act authorises the construction or operation of any nuclear power plants, reprocessing plants and so on. The ALP amendment addresses the substantive concerns of the Greens by removing nuclear plants and reprocessing facilities from the definition of `nuclear installation'. Therefore, the further statements proposed by the Greens are unnecessary.

speech.para: However, I indicate to Senator Margetts that, if she were prepared to remove proposed paragraph (e)—which reads, `a nuclear waste storage or disposal facility with an activity that is greater than the activity level prescribed by regulations for the purposes of section 12'—we could accept the balance of the amendment.

talk.start.para: —I do not know whether the rest of the chamber supports the whole thing. I could offer to move (1)(a), (b), (c) and (d) separately and then move (1)(e). It is an extraordinarily interesting statement. I was abused on the radio yesterday by Mr Wilson Tuckey about whether there ever would be a major nuclear waste international storage facility via this legislation. He made quite outrageous comments against me, actually. This could be cleared away altogether by saying that this legislation was not used for that. I am prepared to move an amendment regarding 9A(1)(a), (b), (c), (d) and (2) and then move one regarding 9A(1)(e) and see what the chamber says. I therefore move:

speech.para: (1) Page 4 (after line 21), after clause 9, insert:

para.inline: 9A Prohibition on certain nuclear installations

speech.para: (1) Nothing in this Act is to be taken to authorise the construction or operation of any of the following nuclear installations:
(a) a nuclear fuel fabrication plant;
(b) a nuclear power plant;
(c) an enrichment plant;
(d) a reprocessing facility;
(e) a nuclear waste storage or disposal facility with an activity that is greater than the activity level prescribed by regulations for the purposes of section 12.
(2) The CEO must not issue a licence under section 31 in respect of any of the facilities mentioned in subsection (1).

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the ALP amendment that has already been agreed to includes the issues raised in proposed sub-subsection (e) in a definitional sense. To have it in this part of the legislation in the manner proposed by Senator Margetts would, in effect, be introducing a contradictory clause into the legislation.

—On the matter of the opposition amendment, I was wondering whether I could ask the same question that I asked yesterday towards the end of the debate before it was adjourned. I asked the government whether it understood the definition proposed by the opposition to include nuclear reprocessing and power generation. I thank the parliamentary secretary for answering that question. I was wondering whether Senator Forshaw would give us his understanding of the definitions that are covered in the amendment.

—The intention of what we put forward was to ensure that any such facility is one that is contemplated at the moment, such as the intermediate or low level waste storage facility called for in the Senate select committee report. Indeed, we are certainly prepared to support Senator Margetts's amendment. We believe it ensures that the act will not authorise the construction of any larger facility, having in mind, for instance, one which could deal with imported waste and reprocessing to the enrichment stage. That is really what there has been some public discussion about in recent days.

speech.para: The ultimate situation is that, whilst the definition of `nuclear installation' includes a nuclear waste storage or disposal facility, the regulations will limit the operation of any such facility. Clearly, if clause 9A(1)(e) is carried, the act would not authorise the construction of such a facility beyond what is set in the regulations. I hope that is clear. That is why we do not see any contradiction between carrying proposed clause 9A and the amendment that we have just carried.

talk.start.para: —The question before the chair is that the Greens amendment which concerns clause 9A subclauses (1)(a), (b), (c), (d) and (2) be agreed to.

interjection.para: Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —The question now is that the Greens amendment which concerns clause 9A subclause (1)(e) be agreed to.

interjection.para: Question put:

para.inline: * denotes teller

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —The Greens (WA) oppose clause 7—`Act not to prejudice Australia's defence'—and clause 8—`Act not to prejudice national security'. As always with clauses such as these which appear in legislation from time to time, the problem from our perspective is the lack of definition and the consequent broad powers which are then given to the Chief of the Defence Force and the Director-General of Security.

speech.para: The additional problem is one of perception, particularly international perception. As everyone knows, in foreign affairs, perception counts for a great deal. When those perceptions are intertwined with the often shadowy world of nuclear weapons, then there is cause for concern. As I stated in my speech in the second reading debate, many defence and security analysts acknowledge that the best method for developing nuclear weapons capability is through civilian nuclear technology. This is a great flaw. The great lie that underlies the international nuclear non-prolif eration framework is the belief that you can prevent nuclear weapons proliferation if non-weapon states are provided with assistance to develop so-called peaceful nuclear technology.

This is especially so in the current world situation with proliferation, re-proliferation and disarmament, and Australia's standing in that debate. I believe we have got to be seen to be not just with the rest of the world but a good example to the rest of the world—and a leading example. I guess Australia could do that by taking a very positive role in the middle powers initiative. But, unfortunately, we are not.

In this particular instance we are using the powers that are available under the ASIO Act. I believe—perhaps the government can tell me if I am wrong—that it potentially enables ASIO operatives to be exposed to levels of radiation to which they normally would not be, perhaps for spying or whatever. Can the government clarify whether that is the case or whether we potentially have a situation where there is a great deal more power under this act to the Chief of the Defence Force and the Director-General of Security? Can the government tell us what assurances there are that that will not or cannot be misused beyond anything which the public would believe is normally given under this legislation?

talk.start.para: —I indicate on behalf of the opposition that we are not prepared to support the position put by Senator Margetts on this matter. Perhaps clauses 7 and 8 could have been drafted more tightly but we are prepared to support the inclusion in the bill of the principles contained in clauses 7 and 8. We note particularly that any declaration made under subsection (2) by the Chief of the Defence Force, after consultation with a minister, is a disallowable instrument. Similarly, any declaration under clause 8 is a disallowable instrument. The opposition will support the clauses of the bill.

—Clauses 7 and 8 of the bill relate to exemptions on the grounds of national security and defence. The Greens seek to remove these provisions. However, the provisions must remain in the legislation. Removing them would jeopardise the national security and defence of the country. The provisions are standard clauses included in all such Commonwealth legislation—for example, the occupational health and safety legislation. With respect to the issue raised by Senator Margetts, I refer her to clause 8(2) of the bill, which reads:

speech.para: Without limiting subsection (1), the Director-General of Security may, after consulting with the Minister, declare by notice in writing that specified provisions of this Act or the regulations do not apply, or apply subject to such modifications as are set out in the declaration, in relation to:
(a) premises or a workplace under the control of the Director-General; or
(b) a person who is employed under section 84 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979 ; or
(c) the performance of work by such a person for the purpose of carrying out a function set out in section 17 of that Act.
Whilst there is a role for the Director-General, it must be related to the purposes of the act.

talk.start.para: —I draw the committee's attention, again, to the Director of Safeguards report through Foreign Affairs and Trade. I asked the government yesterday if it could explain the activities of the company Silex Systems, which is developing laser enrichment technology at Lucas Heights. The committee may like to know that on page 23 of the report, under the heading `Laser enrichment research and development', it states:

speech.para: An Australian company, Silex Systems Pty Ltd, is researching a novel method of separating uranium isotopes, using laser techniques. The company has entered into an agreement with the United States Enrichment Corporation (USEC) to explore the commercial potential of this technology. In the first phase USEC specialists are undertaking a technical assessment in Australia. If this is successful, the technology would be developed further in the US—this aspect is discussed further under Task C.1.
We look at that and then at page 31 of the report where, under the heading `Laser enrichment technology', it makes the comment:
Reference was made under Task A.1 above—
which I have just quoted—

to the laser enrichment R&D being undertaken by Silex Systems Pty Ltd. If this technology is classified as "associated technology", then any transfer to the US for further development will require an amendment to the existing Australia/US nuclear cooperation agreement, or a new agreement. ASO officers have been participating in discussions with US officials to develop appropriate arrangements.

This relates to what Senator Margetts refers to as the potential of civilian technology to be applied to the manufacture of weapons. I ask the government to explain what is going on at Lucas Heights. Is there going to be a change to the US-Australian nuclear cooperation agreement and, if so, why?

talk.start.para: —I would just point out the time and the fact that there are other important functions in and around Parliament House at this time. I would like to return to that issue at a later point, Senator Brown, perhaps when we return to the legislation a bit later.

speech.para: Progress reported.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 December, on motion by Senator Minchin:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak briefly on the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 . As my colleague Senator Cook outlined in his speech in the second reading debate, this bill has unanimous support from all sides of the chamber. It is a real problem in the world which many people probably do not focus on enough. The problem was outlined in a speech by my colleague Mr Brereton last year, and Senator Cook referred to some of the statistics from the International Red Cross outlined by Mr Brereton in that speech, and it is worth traversing those again.

speech.para: There are an estimated 119 million active landmines in 70 countries. It therefore becomes an issue of mammoth proportions indeed. The report also said that some 15 countries are, in effect, crippled as a result of the placing of landmines. It is interesting to note some of the places that are listed as being crippled: Afghanistan, Angola, Bosnia, Cambodia, Mozambique and Somalia. This is not because of external forces fighting each other but because of internal war, civil war, in many instances. One finds that, once the civil war has been resolved, the mines that were laid are invariably left lying around the place. The effect of that is that they injure, maim and kill innocent people long after the hostility, the internal insurrection, has ceased.

The International Red Cross report, as my colleague Senator Cook indicated, states that landmines kill or maim some 2,000 people every month. The figures broken down are 800 killed and 1,200 maimed every month. That, again, is something of mammoth proportions and is completely and totally unnecessary. The International Red Cross report went on to say—and this was as of last year—that, if mine clearing were to proceed and no more mines were to be laid, it would take 1,100 years to clear the entire world of mines laid during civil or other wars that have occurred. That really puts into perspective the problem that is confronting many people in many nations. It is not a small problem; it is a problem of great magnitude.

Antipersonnel landmines are an indiscriminate killer, as I said earlier. Long after peace has been brokered within many of the countries where civil war has occurred, the people who laid the mines have invariably gone onto other pursuits. Of course the minefields were laid without any markings and in peacetime they become an indiscriminate killer, particularly of the young and the old and of women and children. That, in itself, should be completely avoided at all costs. People who had no direct input into the violence, people who invariably had no part to play in the warring that took place, are being injured long after the settlement of the melee. In many instances, as the statistics have shown, death occurs quite wantonly for these people.

The fact that there are so many landmines out there causes real poverty in some of these nations—nations which really cannot afford to be subjected to additional poverty, because poverty is one of the factors those nations inherit as a result of the protracted and prolonged wars having taken place in them. The existence of vast minefields stops appropriate resettlement within these nations, stops many of their people from being able to return to agriculture to till the land because mines are in the arable land. And all that does is impose further poverty. It also acts as an obstacle to the transportation of people and goods within some of these countries, and it has an effect on the provision of basic services. All in all, one sees in many cases not a very pretty picture being painted as a result of the laying and indiscriminate use of landmines in conflicts that have long been resolved—and, of course, they have wreaked havoc on very innocent populations in postwar periods.
I found it of interest to read a publication dated May 1997 called Living in a minefield—a report on the mine problem in Afghanistan, which was put out by—pardon my French—Medecins Sans Frontieres.

talk.start.para: —Good; eight out of 10.

—It was quite good? I got an eight out of 10 for French there, and I thank the honourable senator for that mark. But that was not the point. The point was not to prove my French but to look at just a couple of excerpts from this publication. I believe that we really have no experience nor real understanding of the problems caused by landmines and, therefore, it becomes a bit of an academic exercise for us. But I find it interesting that outlined on page 12 of the publication are the problems caused by landmines. It states:

speech.para: There are three common patterns of anti-personnel mine injury: one is amputation of the foot or leg from standing on the blast mine; the second is multiple fragment injuries from triggering a fragmentation mine where the legs are injured and often so too are the head, neck, chest and abdomen; and, three, hand, arm, face and eye injuries from handling a mine.

What we see are injuries that are not at all pretty, injuries that take a lot of treatment and injuries that, in many cases, absolutely ruin the dignity of the individual living in these communities. This brings with it problems in terms of treatment, problems in terms of rehabilitation and problems in terms of ongoing support. It places a strain on the economy, on the family and on the community. Without being emotional about the issue, one sees landmines really as being a blight on our society and an issue being appropriately addressed by this legislation and measures that are being taken by the government through our expenditure going towards the elimination of mines in different parts of the world.

Part of the real problem in this is the finding of the mines; that costs time and money as well. Of course, in many instances, the minefields have not been marked and have not been mapped. So it is not simply a matter of once the war is over the nation returning to normalcy; what one finds is that there is still much work to be done in finding the mines, marking the areas, mapping them and then, of course, clearing the areas. This further disrupts the lives, the lifestyles and the chance of a livelihood of those people within those nations.

Part of the problem is educating the locals and making them aware of the problem. This in itself can have its own problems in that many of these people are unable to read or write and, therefore, are not necessarily able to understand signage. Even if signage is placed there, with many of these people being so poor, there is evidence that it is removed to assist them to make basic shelter and homes. As I have said, the Australian government is to spend $100 million by the year 2005, and this is very commendable.
As I realise this is non-controversial legislation, the last thing I will do is read from a World Vision document, which highlights the problem in Cambodia. I quote:
Between six and 10 million landmines that were laid in Cambodia during or after the 25-year war are yet to be removed. One of every 236 Cambodians has lost an arm or a leg to a mine.

I repeat: one in every 236 people. It is something of enormous proportions and it shows the lack of dignity that these people must experience in the injury being inflicted and in the harm that has been caused to them by the landmines that were placed in Cambodia over a long period of time.

We are a nation free from this. In this nation we do not have this problem, we do not experience it and, therefore, probably do not understand the disaster it causes at the family and social levels within these communities. The article goes on:
Landmines are currently the single greatest causes of poverty in these districts—
this is in Cambodia—

not only because of the deaths and the injuries but also because of the large areas of precious farming land that cannot be used due to the mines that lie hidden there. Mines are preventing needy families and communities from re-establishing decent livelihoods and futures.

The fact remains that, whatever one's view of war might be, landmines should be banned. They should be kept out of the realms of war. We as a nation should seek to assist others in clearing lands that are peppered with these indiscriminate killers. The fundamental thing that we can achieve by helping these people out is to return to them the most precious commodity that we can give them, and that is their dignity as human beings—their dignity as persons. I commend the legislation and I hope it gets the speedy passage it deserves.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Bourne, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a speech on the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The Anti Personnel Mines Convention Bill is one of the most important we have dealt with in this Senate.

The Democrats have a proud record in calling for a total ban on the use, production, transfer and stockpiling of landmines. We join with NGOs here and around the world in believing that the only solution to this terrible problem is a complete and total ban.
First, and most importantly, this Bill represents Australia's commitment to the eventual destruction of landmines throughout the world, and their elimination as a legitimate weapon.
Former UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros Gali said

para.inline: The landmine, that scourge of the battlefield of World War I, has re-emerged on a scale unimagined, and with hideous unanticipated effects. There is today a global landmine crisis. . . it began as a military problem; it is now an ongoing humanitarian disaster.

speech.para: The United Nations estimates it would take more than a thousand years to clear the 110 million active landmines already in the ground in 64 countries around the world. Two million more mines are laid every year.
Poor farming communities bear the greatest load from the deployment of landmines. The burden of injury and loss of income affects poorer women to the greatest extent.

The mindless carnage caused by landmines is an affront to the conscience of humankind. Growing public awareness of landmines and the devastation they cause are the best weapons against their continued use.

In recent years, landmines have attracted international coverage—they are now recognised as a global catastrophe. In 1994 the UN General Assembly adopted a resolution calling for the eventual elimination of landmines. This led to the Ottawa process and the Bill we have before us today.

This Bill is also important for a second reason. It sends a loud message about Australia's commitment to a total ban on landmines. For that, the Minister for Foreign Affairs should be congratulated. I know it cannot have been easy for the Minister to convince the rest of the Cabinet that this was the right thing to do, and it is very much to his credit that he was able to do so.
In ratifying the convention and introducing this legislation the Australian Government will encourage other governments in our region to take similar action.

The past 20 years have seen new types of warfare, often involving non-conventional combatants such as insurgents, partisans, terrorists and guerrillas. Regular armies fight against these groups and each other. All use landmines. Those mines will kill civilians. In far too many circumstances, mines are beyond military control. They have ongoing political, social and economic effects.

Those countries most affected by landmines tell the story—Afghanistan, Angola, Burma, Cambodia, Ethiopia, Iraq, Kenya, Pakistan, Rwanda, Somalia, Sudan, Vietnam and former Yugoslavia. The list goes on.
The effects are devastating and the practice is a blatant violation of international humanitarian law.

Anti-personnel mines are cheap and very easy to manufacture. According to the International Committee of the Red Cross, prices range from $3 to $15 per mine. They might be cheap, but the cost of dealing with their effects is appallingly expensive.

Hospital stays, physical and psychological rehabilitation services, are all expensive. Many of the most affected nations don't have the money or resources to provide these services. Artificial limbs are just too expensive for many. Children typically require a new artificial limb every year. Then there are the costs of re-integrating victims into society, making them feel useful and able to feed their families.
De-mining is very expensive. Clearing mines, which in most cases must be done by hand, can cost as much as $1,000 per mine.

The Australian Defence Force has an excellent record in mine clearance and training. The Government recognised this with a pledge at the Ottawa signing to provide an extra $100 million to aid clearance work. We welcome this. However, we fear the money for mine clearance will be drawn from the aid budget rather than the defence budgets where it belongs.
The Democrats and the NGO community have always maintained that funds for mine clearance operations should come from the defence budget. The humanitarian aid budget is already dreadfully depleted.

We also believe the Minister could better use forums such as the ASEAN Regional Forum to achieve a total ban on anti-personnel mines in our own region, as recommended by the Treaties Committee in our landmine report.
The Minister should be actively encouraging our South-East Asian neighbours to sign the Ottawa convention. Australia has demonstrated leadership in this matter and we should not lose that momentum.
The Democrats are keen to know when and how Australia will destroy our own stockpile of these weapons.

We welcome the Minister's clarification of clause 7(iii), which we now understand will be applied in instances where an Australian Defence officer carries out one of the prohibited acts under clause 7(i) in the course of combined operations.

We are also pleased that Defence doctrinal and operational manuals will be amended to comply with the prohibitions contained in the Bill. We are sure these amendments will be made as soon as possible after this Bill becomes law.
In conclusion, I would like to say how pleased the Democrats are to see this Bill before the Senate. It is remarkable to think that we are moving towards an effective total ban on landmines.

Lastly, I would like to thank Sister Patricia Pak Poy, Australia's co-ordinator for the International Campaign to Ban Landmines, whose tireless campaigning and encyclopaedic knowledge on the subject of landmines have been absolutely central to Australia becoming a party to the Convention on the Prohibition of the Use, Stockpiling, Production and Transfer of Anti-Personnel Mines and their Destruction.

talk.start.para: —Also while I am on my feet, I seek leave, on behalf of Senator Margetts, to incorporate in Hansard a speech on the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
Today is a particularly satisfying day in my Parliamentary career, seeing the Bill come before the Senate and being met with the support of all Senators.

It is an issue which has been close to my heart and one I have tried to pursue from the very early days of time in this place. My first question in the Senate on the issue was about the Australian Defence Force use of mines and Australian compliance with the inhumane weapons convention back in February 1994. The part of the question to do with modification of weapons for use as booby traps wasn't answered at that time and the issue of grenades and other weapons being modified to work as defacto land mines is still a problem.

What was different then was the political climate on the issue. In June 1994, when I raised the landmines issue in the context of its effect on the world refugee problem it seemed to me I was very much on my own in this place. There was sympathy but no commitment to getting anything done about it.
Australia was being accused of providing Papua New Guinea with grenades which could be easily converted to mines for use in Bougainville—but the government continued to turn a blind eye.

Australia's role in this arms trade was a recurring theme of my speeches on the issue and several times I sought to draw the attention of the Senate to the hypocrisy and inconsistency of the Government over its failure to support a total ban campaign. They held to a position that mines were OK if they were mapped and if they went off by themselves or defused themselves after a certain time. I pointed out then that they couldn't be mapped if they were dropped from planes or fired from guns and didn't necessarily do what was expected of them anyway.

Then in 1995 there was the infamous Gareth Evens speech which I hope will continue to haunt him till his dying day in which he referred to my call for a total ban on landmines as "hopelessly utopian". He went on in that speech to use the chilling phrase "landmines perform a unique military function".
That is an expression that deserves to be rated alongside collateral damage and smart bombs!

Well Gareth, maybe now that you have time for reflection from your position in semi-retirement on the backbench, you'll realise that a utopian position is not necessarily hopeless. If a few more people in high office were to take a utopian position we might actually get a few more achievements such as this Bill to ratify the Ottawa Treaty.

Over the years that I engaged in a war of attrition with then-Senator Evens, Senator Hill and others, the real battle to put an end to landmines was being fought by the non-government sector which was building up a world-wide constituency pressing governments to go further, to take on the total ban as an achievable aim.

In 1995 Australian Catholic Relief, Community Aid abroad, The Christian Centre for Social Action and many others affiliated with the Australian Council For Overseas Aid raised almost a quarter of a million signatures requesting the Government to push for a total ban on Landmines.

The turning point was the 1996 Ottawa Conference at which Australia pledged to work towards a having a ban treaty in place as soon as possible. It wasn't long before the Government were backtracking on that position, moving in to line behind the US which preferred the slower approach through the UN Conference on Disarmament. The CD approach was always going to be flawed as landmines got caught up in the complex trade-offs over nuclear weapons—and the commitment of the US was always in doubt anyway.

Fortunately the momentum for change was overwhelming. The groundswell of popular feeling could not be ignored. Disgust grew as people became aware of the indiscriminate nature of weapons which lay around for years, sometimes killing children, farmers, anyone in the wrong place at the wrong time. And the wrong place at the wrong time could be any place at any time—in fields, on paths, in forests.

Then gradually there was the realisation that—all the more horrible—that this killing of civilians was not always so indiscriminate. That sometimes it was the intentional outcome of the planting of mines. This was the case in many conflicts around the world.

This realisation, and the appearance of television coverage of the plight of victims, intensified the movement for a total, global, unconditional ban on landmines. It would never have come about if it hadn't been for the untiring efforts of people such as Sister Patricia Pak Poy and the International Campaign to Ban Landmines. I am please to see Sister Patricia was recognised for her efforts with an ANZAC peace prize earlier this year.
It is she and the others in the Non-Government sector who are to be thanked for making so much progress on an issue that seemed so intractable only a short while ago.
That brings us to the current situation—where what was once "hopelessly utopian" is now Government policy and soon will be Australian law.
The Bill to ratify The Convention On The Prohibition Of The Use, Stockpiling, Production, And Transfer Of Anti-Personnel Mines And Their Destruction is very welcome indeed.

While there have been some concerns raised about particular aspects of the Bill, particularly in respect of Section 7 (3), on the issue of Australian troops involved in operations with non-signatory states, I understand those concerns have been pretty much addressed in the Second Reading speech by the Minister. I certainly hope that loop-hole is well and truly closed.

The issue I wish to focus on is: Where to from here? What happens from now on in terms of action to get the mines out of the ground, to provide assistance to victims and to universalise the Treaty. It is important to know how all of this will be managed and monitored. In this regard I commend the current efforts in Ottawa to establish a Landmines Monitor, but we will also have to be vigilant in our monitoring of Australia's role.

The amount allocated by the Government for work on landmines—$100 million—is on the face of it a generous amount. But do we have guarantees that this is `new money'? i.e. not coming out of existing aid budgets. Even with this allocation, there is room for Australia to make further allocations for clearance of mines from priority land, and for assistance to victims and survivors.
Universalisation

Ratification by Australia now puts us in a better position to seek to convince others in the region, and elsewhere (including the US), to come on board. Vietnam, Laos, Burma, Singapore and PNG are still not signatories. Neither are China, Korea, India, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Let's make this a high priority in our regional relations.

The focus needs to be on total ban. Let's not see our efforts fall back into reliance on the CD process. While the CD is obviously one forum, Government efforts here should not detract from the ban principle. We must continue efforts in UN forums especially the next Review of Protocol II in 2000-2001.
Mine Action

Key issues around mine action are the priorities—deciding where and how the remainder of the $100m gets spent. The choices here need to be made in a strategic and transparent way, targeting getting the mines out of the ground, maximising local capacity in the countries affected and maximising Australian expertise in the area. In this context, countries in our region should receive priority attention.

Mine Action programs should develop local capacity in mines awareness, management and clearance—not rely on expensive expatriate expertise. In this regard we should capitalise on the potential for the ADF to play a positive role—as part of its training and awareness role—and its moral responsibility.

But there are other advantages to the Defence Forces in participation in de-mining and their efforts should be funded out of their budget, not from humanitarian/relief allocations whether on a cost recovery basis or any other.

The choice of where to de-mine should be based on proper data, and on practical and humanitarian principles which will maximise the capacity of local affected communities to return to productive and safe livelihoods.
Victim Assistance

Obviously there needs to be an ongoing commitment to assisting people who have been injured by mines. In an immediate sense, we need to continue with medical assistance etc. But also we need to focus on providing assistance to victims, and their families in developing safe and alternative livelihoods (where people can't farm their land because it is mined, or because they have lost limbs etc). Landmines are currently the single greatest cause of poverty in some parts of the world: not only because of the deaths and injuries, but also because large areas of precious farming land cannot be used due to the mines that lie hidden there.

It is most appropriate that this assistance be provided through the non-government sector as much as possible. It is the NGO's who have the experience on the ground and the confidence of local people and organisations and it is they who are best able to provide assistance.
Organisations such as Austcare, World Vision, Red Cross and others have well established programs which are deserving of greater government support.
Monitoring

We would not want to see the legislation as being the end of this process. Although it has been a good achievement, we should not let the feast of self-congratulation cloud the fact that what matters will be what Australia actually does to further the cause of the elimination of landmines. There are many aspects here: how Defence implements its side (including the destruction of the stockpile—and the importance of openness about progress towards destruction of the stockpile within 4 years), how DFAT approaches the task of universalising both the principle and the fact of the Treaty, how AusAID disburses funds (and against what criteria) and what other efforts the Government and civil society will need to make in scrutinising adherence in the manufacturing/transfers area. There is a role for multipartisan scrutiny here—involving parliamentarians, bureaucrats and NGO's.
Research
There is also need for research and development of mine detection and clearance technology, but it needs to be stressed that this must not come from the aid budget or humanitarian funds.
Finally let us turn to the longer term priorities.

In July this year in Rome the international community created a statute for an International Criminal Court (ICC). The ICC will come into being once 60 States have ratified the treaty. Unfortunately anti-personnel landmines were not included in the list of prohibited weapons found in Article 8 dealing with war crimes. However there is an opportunity to amend the Statute pursuant to Article 121 and 123 in the future. If the use of landmines was deemed a war crime it would be an extremely powerful tool in the fight to stop these heinous weapons destroying more lives.

The first priority there is for Australia to ratify and then start the long term process of getting the use of landmines considered a war crime for which prosecution can be mounted in the International Court.
But maybe that is just me being `hopelessly utopian' again.

talk.start.para: —I want to associate myself with the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 . This is a very important issue to a lot of people, particularly those who live in developing countries or countries that have seen strife, unrest, fighting and war in the last few years. I think particularly of Cambodia. However, more recently we have had brought home to us the troubles experienced around Honduras and some other Latin American countries as a result of Hurricane Mitch—the worst hurricane ever—dislodging and moving a significant number of landmines to areas that had previously been clear.

speech.para: That is the thing about landmines: they are silent killers and silent maimers. Everyone in some of the rural villages and communities of developing countries—people on low incomes—needs to participate in the labouring work that has to be done in the fields. These instruments of war silently sit buried for any number of years—with some of the later devices and batteries that are operating in them, it could be a century—and, when least expected, they explode, usually maiming rather than killing. This places a large burden on small rural villages because an active worker is removed from that community. If the victim happens to be a child, the effect would be to remove that child from whatever future he or she had. If the child was maimed, their only future would be to beg or be at home, dependent upon other members of the family and other members of the village. When the village is living not much above subsistence, these impacts are very great.

The impact of this was brought home to me when, on Anzac Day and the day after, I visited the French and Belgian battlefields of World War I. Tonnes and tonnes of unexploded ordnance are still being dug up 80-odd years after the cessation of those hostilities. When you think that, 80 years later, potentially lethal ordnance is still being found and dug up, you wonder how long it is going to take countries and the world at large to clear so many of the mined areas of Cambodia, Angola and parts of Latin America. The monumental size of that task really impacted upon me when I saw those battlefields of France. While they did not use landmines in those days that are as sophisticated as the ones that are used now, we certainly saw the impact and the devastation. We saw unexploded ordnance that had been dug up from the site of the memorial at Le Hamel. So it is a very important issue. The use these days of smaller and lighter weight components in the mines has made them even harder to detect and has made them more able, of course, to be moved around by floods.

I have a friend who is working in Cambodia for an offshoot of the World Council of Churches on community development work related to landmine victims. She has told me stories about travelling in the Cambodian countryside on roads and paths that have been cleared of mines. As Senator Hogg said, people do not read the signs, cannot read the signs or use the material on which the signs are displayed for other purposes. My friend said that she had seen families out ploughing fields that are marked with the signs that warn of landmines. She told me a story about one gentleman who had been partly maimed by a mine being helped by his child to plough a field. The dangers for that family were very great but, obviously, the dangers of starvation, hunger or no income were also very great. So it very much affects those countries that are less fortunate than us.

I think it is appropriate that we pass this piece of legislation today, which is the day we celebrate the 50th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Human Rights. This legislation will help people who have been fighting to maintain their access to human rights. It is important that we pass this legislation so that we do not contribute to the proliferation or the continued use of landmines. This is one of the most important pieces of legislation to come before us. It deserves to be classed as non-contentious legislation and it deserves to get the support it is getting from everybody within the government and this parliament.

It is legislation that puts to rest the lie that all we ever do in this place is argue, fight and disagree. This is a classic example of a good piece of bipartisan legislation being passed, one which will benefit many people, I hope. It certainly signifies Australia's commitment to the rights of those people and to not having landmines in a position where they can callously maim, injure and wound people in the future.

talk.start.para: —Earlier this year I was in Africa. I met some people of outstanding ability and fame, Mr Acting Deputy President—in fact, I met you there amongst those people. You were not on this part of the journey, Mr Acting Deputy President, but we went to two places: Angola and Mozambique. I must confess that I felt very proud in both places because of the work being done at Australia's instigation. It made me feel very proud to be part of the Australian community. In Angola, Australia was responsible for the making of artificial limbs and feet for people who had been injured by mines. It was tragic to see the people who needed these feet but very `proud making', if I can use that expression, to see Australia trying to remedy a dreadful situation.

speech.para: In Mozambique, the Australian Army had been central in educating local people in how to dispose of landmines. The Australian military force had started disposing of landmines themselves and then had taught others how to get rid of them. At the time, Major McIntosh was there; I single him out because of that. I would like, through him, to pay tribute to all the Australian Army personnel who have gone over there to help de-mine Mozambique. I should also pay tribute to our Kiwi colleagues who were there at the time.

talk.start.para: —Don't forget the AFP guys who were risking their lives in those areas, too.

—I accept that statement and endorse it, Minister; it is now on the record. Australia does great things around the world and the Australian Army does great things around the world. Mines, as everybody has said—the speakers before me, in particular—are the most cruel of weapons and are devastating to many people. It is good that we are known around the world not for laying mines but for trying to help those who are injured by them.

—I would like to thank all honourable senators for their contributions to the debate on the Anti-Personnel Mines Convention Bill 1998 . This bill will put in place the necessary domestic legislation for Australia's ratification of the Convention on the Prohibition of the Use, Stockpiling, Production and Transfer of Anti-Personnel Land Mines and on their Destruction, known as the Ottawa Convention.

speech.para: The Foreign Minister, Mr Downer, took particular pride in signing the Ottawa Convention on 3 December 1997, the day it was open for signature. I know that for a fact because I saw him very soon after he signed it when he visited Ottawa and then came on to New York to meet with Penny Wensley, the Australian Ambassador to the UN in New York.

I was equally pleased to deliver a statement on the floor of the General Assembly of the United Nations shortly thereafter. Just after Minister Downer signed the convention I was able to give a statement in which I outlined Australia's commitment to a lasting, effective and comprehensive solution to the global landmines problem, including through enhanced international efforts in the fields of de-mining and victim assistance. I was able to highlight some of the things that have been said around the chamber here today about Australia's role in that, about some of the technology that has been developed in Australia for de-mining, about the role the armed forces and the Federal Police have played and also about the pride we have in what Australia has been able to achieve in de-mining. I also mentioned around the traps some of the partnerships that were going on between community organisations in supporting people adopting fields and de-mining them.

So we have a good record. We have a commitment. I also take great pride in having taught some students in prosthetics and orthotics who have contributed to some of the developments in the technology, simplifying the development of prostheses for people who have been affected by landmines. So across the board we have set an example in signing the convention. With this bill we are ahead of the pack compared with some countries. We have a record in contributing to de-mining through technology, through personnel and through assisting people who have been injured. We all have the right to be proud of that but we should never sit back and rest on our laurels. It ought to be noted that this bill has been passed with very strong support on all sides of the chamber. That is not always the case with bills. I have much pleasure in acknowledging that. The passage of today's bill helps bring closer the goal of a solution to the global landmine problem.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 30 November, on motion by Senator Minchin:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports the Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill 1998 , though we do indicate that we will be moving an amendment during the committee stage of the legislation. The bill seeks to overcome the problems created for the government by the decision of Justice Spender in the Federal Court in Foster v. Attorney-General on 12 October this year. In that decision, His Honour held that the process adopted by the government in purporting to allow portfolio ministers to authorise junior ministers and parliamentary secretaries to act on their behalf was unlawful. In essence, the Federal Court found that there were flaws in the delegation process. A further flaw in the process was that the authorisation was made directly by the portfolio minister and not through the Administrative Arrangements Order or by the cabinet or the Prime Minister.

speech.para: Justice Spender's decision has a potentially wide impact. It affects the validity of all government decisions made pursuant to authorisations which were made in accordance with the Prime Minister's code of conduct since April 1996 and it affects delegations and decisions made by either junior ministers or parliamentary secretaries on behalf of a portfolio minister by or under, for instance, the following areas: the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 pertaining to foreign investments; some 21 acts pertaining to the Department of Health and Aged Care, including the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989; the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 and 17 matters taken by Australia on behalf of foreign countries; and the Crimes Act 1914 and a whole range of matters pertaining to parole, early release and revocation of parole.

It is important to note that Justice Spender's decision affects only those decisions made under a provision that vests statutory responsibility in a specifically named minister. In other words, if a minister, the Treasurer or the A-G is mentioned specifically in legislation, then under the Prime Minister's code of ministerial conduct and delegations of April 1996, quite a range of decisions taken over the last 2½ years under the four acts that I mentioned, in particular, are probably now unsustainable at law.

The problem identified in the Foster decision would have been avoided if the government had acted pursuant to section 19BA(1) of the act and sought to regularise the arrangements reached between the relevant portfolio ministers and their junior ministers and parliamentary secretaries through the issuing of amended admin arrangements. Basically, what we have here is the Prime Minister going outside the law and endorsing somewhat sloppy administrative arrangements for his government. As a consequence, in a critical case just a few weeks ago in the Federal Court of Australia, Justice Spender found that such delegations were ultra vires.

Since that date, the Attorney-General has had the job of cleaning up the Prime Minister's mess. He has acted, I must say, with appropriate alacrity. This legislation is a sign of that. It must be put on the record as well that the Commonwealth is appealing the decision, and I gather the appeal was heard last Thursday. This legislation is necessary and it is urgent. It is for that reason that the opposition is assisting in the passage of it.

The bill, however, does go further than is required. What we have here is a bill which is retrospective in nature. Retrospectivity is always a concern but more so in respect of oral delegations. This government allowed, under the Prime Minister's arrangements, for oral referral of responsibility from a minister to a parliamentary secretary or a junior minister. Oral delegations have a number of problems in terms of ministerial responsibility and in terms of people being able to access their rights against government. Oral delegations are enormously difficult to ensure auditing of and administrative review thereof. The government has removed the ability to make an oral authorisation in future, but this legislation seeks to authorise past oral authorisations. We have some concerns about that, and they were expressed in the House of Representatives by the shadow Attorney-General, Rob McClelland.

Our second concern is the ability of a minister to job share even where parliament has prescribed that a particular minister needs to act. The A-G, for instance, has special skills and experience. We would not want him delegating some of his responsibilities to the primary industries minister, for instance.

In terms of our second concern, this bill goes much further than the previous custom and practice. What we are seeking to do by way of our amendment is to allow authorisation by a minister to a junior minister or a parliamentary secretary within a particular portfolio, but not jump over the portfolio fences and delegate outside one's portfolio responsibility. That should not be a concept which would appeal to the Senate, though I anticipate that the Democrats are still thinking seriously about whether to support such an amendment.

This legislation seeks to redress the administrative problems arising from Justice Spender's decision, but we should also keep in mind that the process we are going through here may very well be a futile one, because Justice Spender in his judgment questioned whether anything short of a formal Administrative Arrangements Order signed by the Attorney-General in this case would be valid. His analysis was based on the concept of the separation of powers, and it is worth putting on the public record the comments he made on this point. In his judgment, Justice Spender said that the intention of the relevant section of the Acts Interpretation Act was to:

. . . provide a mechanism by which illness or absence from Australia or leave or other emergency could be met so as to permit the continued orderly administration of the enactments of the Parliament of the Commonwealth.
So we say that it is appropriate for delegation to occur in that situation. Justice Spender went on to say:

Consistent with the notion of responsible government is the requirement that Ministers of State, appointed by the Governor-General, administer Departments of State, and the cases reflect a "longstanding practice " that the Prime Minister might appoint a Minister to act, for the time being, for or on behalf of another Minister.

Again, we are content to support legislation which will confirm, entrench or specifically authorise that acknowledged practice. Justice Spender then proceeded with his analysis of the separation of powers under the Westminster system. He said:

There is much to be said . . . that it is for the Governor-General on advice to appoint officers to administer such departments of State as are established, and . . . it is not even for the Prime Minister to determine who should be appointed to administer such departments.

So he went specifically to a discussion on the separation of powers and the role of the Governor-General under our Westminster system. He indicated that, basically, the approach that we are taking here may ultimately be found to be ill founded. This bill may turn out to be futile because it may breach the separation of powers concept. In the meantime, it is appropriate that the government should proceed to try to clean up this particular problem, and this legislation does that to the extent that we, at this stage, are assured of the constitutional parameters within which we are working.

I indicate that the opposition have one amendment, and it is an amendment I flagged earlier. It basically will ensure that delegations would occur within a portfolio rather than stretching over portfolios, and we will move that at the appropriate time. I also repeat that this legislation is substantially supported by the opposition.

talk.start.para: —The Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill 1998 sets out amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act and deals with the implications, as Senator Bolkus has pointed out, of the recent Federal Court decision in Foster v. Attorney-General. The government says that this decision has serious consequences for government administration. The Australian Democrats agree with that and we are happy to discuss this important issue which we believe goes to the very heart of how government in Australia functions.

speech.para: The Foster case itself has been the vehicle for this change and, in particular, the decision of Justice Spender, as Senator Bolkus has pointed out, makes this debate now necessary. I would like to briefly discuss the details of the Foster case and then move to the contents of the bill. The United Kingdom have request ed that Peter Foster be extradited on a number of fraud related charges. He was arrested last year in Australia and granted bail. He challenged the Attorney-General's decision unsuccessfully and, after a number of appearances in court, failed to attend a listed hearing on 1 December 1997. He was subsequently captured in February 1998 and brought before a magistrate to determine his eligibility for extradition. He was found to be eligible to be extradited on 4 March this year.

Foster challenged this decision in the Supreme Court of Queensland, which dismissed his application on 7 April 1998. He then made a number of submissions to the Minister for Justice and Customs seeking to avoid extradition. The minister for justice, Senator Amanda Vanstone, decided on 24 July 1998 that Foster should be extradited. Foster sought review of that decision in the Federal Court. On 12 October 1998, the Federal Court granted Foster's application on the basis that the minister for justice did not have the authority to make the decision on behalf of the Attorney-General. The Commonwealth appealed this decision to the full Federal Court on 15 October 1998, which was heard on 26 November, and the decision was reversed.

I received submissions from both Foster and his mother setting out a number of grounds addressing the merits of the case. There is no doubt that Foster is a colourful character and has undertaken activities which have attracted considerable media attention and other attention. I have accepted those submissions from the Fosters in good faith, and I have put their allegations to the Attorney-General.
This is an issue that goes to the merits of the case which has been the subject of comment by Justice Spender. The submission to the minister was described by Justice Spender as:

. . . a careful and fair summary of the submissions advanced on Mr Foster's behalf in relation to the nature of the offences, the likely penalty that might be imposed, submissions concerning the bona fides of the United Kingdom charge, delay in the prosecution of the United Kingdom charges, and the safety considerations advanced by Mr Foster.
Justice Spender found that:

. . . it was open to the decision maker to reach a different conclusion than that urged by Mr Foster as to the existence or extent of any threat to his safety on extradition. . . the claims and assertions by Mr Foster were investigated and, in the end, the Minister was not persuaded that any mandatory ground for denying surrender was made out, nor did any other discretionary factor so indicate.

This is a merits matter, and I am in no position in this instance to adjudicate the decision of the court, which is still the subject of an appeal. I have been assured of the bona fides of both the Commonwealth and the United Kingdom governments, and I accept that—although I would seek an assurance from the government that they do not have an agenda here, and suggest clear cases of procedural unfairness can have a political component which might in some circumstances warrant the scrutiny of the parliament.

Turning to the substance of this amending bill, the bill proposes amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act by inserting a new section 18C. This will provide for a portfolio minister to authorise a non-portfolio minister or a member of the Executive Council who is not a minister to act in the performance of statutory functions or the exercise of statutory powers. This bill makes amendments to section 19A so that all ministers within a portfolio can exercise the statutory powers of the portfolio minister. Amendments to section 19BA ensure the Governor-General may make orders under the section to meet the changes of an administration.

These amendments will also validate past authorisations to the extent that they may be invalid. The government, of course, has argued these amendments are urgently needed to overcome the implications of the Foster case. They say this decision would mean authorisations to another minister, to the so-called junior ministers and to parliamentary secretaries are invalid when that person was exercising statutory powers based on that authorisation. We believe that this is a serious matter, as the functioning of government depends on the designated decision maker having the power to exercise the functions available through statute, subordinate regulation rules and cabinet decisions.

From the Democrat perspective, the way the executive implements its own structures in order to exercise these powers is often shrouded in mystery. These are complex rules and practices about the appointment, powers and responsibilities of ministers and other members of the federal executive and the other office bearers. The Democrats are keen to see some formalisation of these processes under our general policy of accountability and transparency in appointment and decision making by governments. This is particularly important because the institutions in Australia, such as the cabinet, do not have any legal foundation.

However, there are some formalities. Central to this process are the administrative arrangement orders, the AAOs, made out by the Governor-General acting on advice. The AAOs set out the details of the department's and the minister's responsibility. It is under this scheme the Acts Interpretation Act enables the AAOs to take effect in conjunction with the existing statutory and other relevant rules assigned to particular ministers and departments, and the terminology in this debate is important.

Delegations are a complete transfer of the decision making power, whereas an authorisation is the decision making taking place on behalf of the decision maker. This debate is about authorisations—the exercise of a decision making power for, and on behalf of, the holder of the statutory power. We are concerned whether these amendments are necessary, and I am assured by the Attorney-General's office a resolution of this issue is essential for administrative certainty. However, I would note that this bill fixes up an erroneous interpretation of the Acts Interpretation Act and that the continued use of section 19 is possible because the Prime Minister might rely on the existing powers to deal with indisposed or unavailable colleagues and the re-making of AAOs.

We are also concerned that this bill goes beyond the issue in the Foster case. We are concerned that this bill sets out to retrospectively validate past decisions, which may effectively deny certain rights. I have raised this matter with the Attorney-General's office, and I have been assured that civil liberties and other rights will not be denied by this particular amendment. The government says this amendment puts into effect existing practice. This matter was identified by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. In response to these concerns, the Attorney-General has said that these amendments would in no way prejudice practice that has in the past ensured due process. We are happy to accept this assurance from the Attorney-General, although we would seek a further assurance that where this retrospective amendment does affect due process the government will use their discretionary powers to remedy that or any injustice.

I am also aware that the debate in the House of Representatives focused on the place of oral authorisations—again, Senator Bolkus has referred to this. The government now has introduced its own amendment to make all these authorisations in writing. The Democrats support that amendment, recognising the difficulty and often the considerable expense faced by anyone challenging a decision to determine the decision maker and the decision making power. We are of the view that every authorisation and delegation should be in writing and easily identifiable to ensure open and accountable decision making in government.

The Acts Interpretation Act has been subject to review by the department and a discussion paper has been prepared. We welcome that review. The issue identified by the discussion paper for section 19 of the act is that what is printed in an act may not have the meaning that the text indicates. The problem then arises in identifying the decision maker and tracing the thread of power through the various orders. This is clearly not satisfactory.

The Democrats are also conscious of the changed administration under the previous government that created the mega departments and the new range of junior ministers and parliamentary secretaries. These structures have been inherited; they have been maintained. However, the Acts Interpretation Act was never designed to deal with this structure, and we are effectively imposing a new struc ture on an old framework. The solution is to review the Acts Interpretation Act comprehensively to reflect these new structures. This is under way in part, and we would like to see this involve the parliament to make sure the important issues of transparency, accountability and responsibility are maintained. I am happy to discuss that further in a committee stage whenever that may be.

Basically the Democrats are very keen to see reform of the Acts Interpretation Act. We see an act that was made out in 1901, which has been amended to try to reflect modern times but still in many ways is holding onto the past. Government is very different now from what it was back in 1901. We have had a huge increase in the amount of legislation administrated by the executive, and we have had a huge increase in the size of the executive and we have a society that is no doubt becoming more and more complex.

The Democrats believe that the Acts Interpretation Act is essential as an interpretative document and a pivotal act in the devolution of powers. It is for this reason alone we need to make sure that the act reflects our needs now as well as into the future. We will be supporting this bill with an understanding that the Acts Interpretation Act is under review. We would expect to see the outcome of this review in legislation before the parliament and, in particular, the entire issue of the distributions of powers between the Executive Council and others. The Labor Party has flagged its support for this proposition, and I look forward to the government making the same commitment.

I want to make very clear why the Democrats will support the government's amendments and this bill. We accept the need to remedy the presently invalid authorisations from ministers to junior ministers, parliamentary secretaries and others. But we also see the need to make the Acts Interpretation Act reflect modern times. We are very pleased to see that this process of review is under way in the Commonwealth's review of the act. We support this review and the proposed rewrite.

I will say clearly that the need for change to include institutions such as the cabinet in the formal legislative structures is something else that motivates our support for these changes. Another important reason for the rewrite of this legislation is to recognise the evolution of administrative law.
