The legislation of administrative law has been a great move forward in government accountability, transparency and efficiency. This has required decision makers to be accountable for their decisions and, in opening up the review of these decisions, the powers of decision makers are under scrutiny. From the Democrats' perspective, the powers to make decisions should be easily identified and their scope strictly within the powers that are given according to our laws. Further, for anyone challenging a decision, the scope of power should be an easily resolved issue and should not be a major legal challenge in itself.
Finally, we look forward to the review and the rewrite of the Acts Interpretation Act, and we expect to see that legislation before the parliament—hopefully soon.

talk.start.para: —People looking at this situation might well say, `Of course, this act should be passed. Isn't it nitpicking to say that the proper process wasn't gone through? The Attorney-General didn't have power to delegate to another minister. So what? Everybody knows what was intended, and everybody knows that the proper result has been obtained.'

speech.para: The judge in this matter, Mr Justice Spender of the Federal Court, saw that argument and answered it—and, I thought, answered it very effectively—when he said:

It might be thought nit-picking and offensive to the efficient and orderly arrangement of the business of the Attorney-General's Department that I have concluded that the Minister for Justice is not a person who satisfies the description in s 19 of the Acts Interpretation Act. However, the liberty of an Australian citizen and our international obligations in respect of extradition highlight the need for a punctilious compliance with the law in this area. Deane J noted in Re Bolton; Ex parte Beane . . .

"Any officer of the Commonwealth Executive who, without judicial warrant, purports to authorise or enforce the detention in custody of another person is acting lawfully only to the extent that his conduct is justified by clear statutory mandate. That being so, it is the plain duty of any such officer to satisfy himself that he is acting with the authority of the law in any case where, in the name of the Commonwealth, he directs that a person be taken and held in custody."

It would be a terrible thing if we as legislators and the government of the Commonwealth became desensitised, that is, we thought that locking people up was not a terribly big issue. To take somebody from the community and to lock them up in a cell—which, judging from my visits there and from illustrations that are made of it, is certainly not comfortable or big—is a dreadful and fearful thing. We must never forget it is a dreadful thing to arrest somebody and to lock them up in gaol. It is easier to do that to someone who we think is guilty. If you look at the history of what is alleged against Peter Clarence Foster, you can see that people might well say that this person has been in gaol and, on the surface, has been associated with fraud and what-have-you and so it is really not as bad to lock him up as it would be to lock up someone who was innocent.

The law in this area and the whole concept of civil rights are tested by our ability to apply them to the unattractive people in the community—the people who have a criminal record; the people who are twisted in mind and body. It is very easy at times to provide civil rights and the rule of law to the attractive, but it is often times less so where the ugly of the community are concerned. I think it would be a bad mistake on our part to say, `Foster'—that is what we would call him; we would not give him his full title—`is guilty anyhow. Therefore, we won't give him the rule of law.' The judge was a bit overenthusiastic in nitpicking about whether the law should apply or not.

It would be a bad thing to do that, especially on the day when we are celebrating the 50th anniversary of the signing of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The issues of 50 years ago are still the same as the issues of today. Taking away a person's liberty or going into a person's house without a warrant is a fearful thing. It is a fearful thing, even with a warrant. It is a fearful thing to be put in gaol, if you are put in gaol according to process.

It is for that very reason that we need the process. If we are going to do these sorts of things as a community—that is, to take away a person's liberty or to invade his or her house—we should do it only within the strict conformity of the law. It would be wrong of us to think—not that we do think it, but if we were inclined to think it—that Mr Justice Spender was somehow being pernickety, that he was somehow being precious in these circumstances. He was doing what he should have done as a judge, that is, to protect the liberty of the individual.

It is proper for us as legislators to think of these things. Indeed, as legislators, we do things about civil liberties and what-have-you. Mr Acting Deputy President McKiernan, I think the committee you are chair of—the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee—has done great work in this area. It has given parliament a real part in the protection of liberties. It has had many a fine secretary. I see Mr Paul Griffiths here in this chamber, and it is very true that having him in the system will ensure that the sorts of things I am talking about are properly listened to. Senator Coonan, an eminent barrister from the Sydney bar, is here too. It is good to have her in the loop.

talk.start.para: —Will a common senator do, too?
—An eminent minister has gone beyond the legal toing and froing. But may I say the minister went to a great law school and was there with many other eminent people.

speech.para: Returning to the issue, there is some very good thought going on about how we as a parliament can protect liberties. I refer to two people who have done a lot of work in respect of committees in this parliament. The first is Professor Janet Hiebert, who is a professor at the Queen's University in Canada. She has written several articles, but the one I particularly address my attention to is entitled `A hybrid approach to protect rights? An argument in favour of supplementing Canadian judicial review with Australia's model of parliamentary scrutiny'. This article shows that proper parliamentary scrutiny can overcome problems that might arise in legislation.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, which I am honoured to be the chair of, has played its part in that scrutiny. Over the numerous parliaments since I have been here, ministers have cooperated very effectively with that committee in trying to get legislation free of any infringements on human rights. The legislation that does infringe human rights usually does so by accident. When you draft legislation, these things can creep in. I must confess that over the years the executive has usually been keen to see that the legislation does not breach human rights.

The other person I want to refer to is Frank Brennan, who is probably known to everyone listening to me speak now. He has written a book called Legislating Liberty: a Bill of Rights for Australia? that has recently been published by the University of Queensland Press. Again, he goes into this issue of how parliament can have its input into seeing that civil liberties are properly attended to through the legislature. He argues that the Bill of Rights is certainly not to be put aside, because it can be a very effective means of looking after the liberties of the citizen, but that parliament itself can and should do more. I think we as a parliament should take up the words of Janet Hiebert and Frank Brennan and take their issues forward.

I make the point that the judge on this occasion was fulfilling the grand traditions of the judiciary, that is, he was ensuring that a person—no matter what his background, no matter whether he was good, bad or ugly—was nevertheless given the full protection of the law and that, if his liberty was going to be taken away, then it had to be taken away according to due process and that due process is a very high test—and so it should be.

The next point is that the courts over the years have been protective of the freedom of Australians, as has parliament. We should not overlook that. But this is the occasion and the time for the parliament to look more and more at its part—it would have to be a bipartisan approach—in establishing that legislation in any event does not contain problems in so far as human rights go. This is a good occa sion to raise these issues, today being the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

The work of both Janet Hiebert and Frank Brennan provides us as a parliament with a way of going forward to ensure that we do walk proud as citizens and that nobody is going to be able to interfere with us, as we do walk proud as citizens, unless the full operation of the law has been called into play. It does mean the full operation. We cannot cut the corners. Once we start cutting corners, then we get instances of injustice, which we want to avoid. I do not want to go through the number of people who have been wrongly convicted and wrongly treated over the years—that will keep going because to err is human. But I think we as an institution can do a lot to ensure that that does not happen as much as it otherwise would.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Margetts, I seek leave to incorporate her speech on the second reading of the Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill 1998 .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

para.inline: 1. General Themes

speech.para: The broad issues in this bill relate to achieving a balance between administrative ease or speed and proper oversight of executive decision making. Administrative law in general, is concerned to ensure that the existence of values of fairness, openness, honesty and efficiency in Commonwealth executive dealings with the general public.

Now—I would like to make clear that the Greens (WA) are supportive of the concept of administrative efficiency. Administrative efficiency is beneficial for members of the executive so that they can deal with their business in an optimal fashion without unwieldy red tape. Administrative efficiency is also beneficial for members of the public dealing with the executive. It is not in anyone's interests that government decision-making process should falter on what are no more than mere technicalities. Third parties dealing in good faith with the Commonwealth have a legitimate expectation that arrangements will not be frustrated by administrative oversights beyond their control. In addition, otherwise reasonable and lawful action taken against wrongdoers should not be defeated by technical objections.

However, administrative efficiency should in no way be confused with administrative ease and speed. The speediest methods of administration are not always the ones that produce the most desirable outcomes. The Greens are concerned that best practice administrative procedures and protocols are in place in our executive arm of government—so that the executive can do their job with certainty, transparency and effectiveness and that the public can go about their business with certainty without having their rights unnecessarily or harshly or unjustly impinged upon.

The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 is one of the central pieces of legislation in this kind of framework. In some instances the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 will operate to confer legal responsibility for particular statutory provisions on persons other than those specifically named in the legislation. Consequently the Acts Interpretation Act in prescribed circumstances works to bring the legal position into line with changes agreed at the administrative and political level. As such, the Greens take very seriously the potentially immense implications of even small changes to this Act.

In effect, the Bill asks the Parliament whether (and to what degree) it is prepared to permit the Executive to exercise a wider discretion than is currently available when altering lines of administrative authority and responsibility delineated by legislation.

para.inline: Verbal Authorisations

speech.para: One provision in this amending Bill, which would have had immense implications, is the ability to verbally authorise another Minister. We are pleased to see that the Government has taken on board concerns raised regarding their proposal that a grant of authority may be oral in cases where authority is conferred on a Minister. Oral authorisations are obviously problematic for a number of reasons.

The ability to authorise without a written instrument decreases the transparency in administrative decision making—it makes it hard to engage in proper auditing of these decisions; it creates problems in the enforcement of individual rights—as anyone who is aggrieved by administrative actions would run into evidentiary difficulties, and this would make it more difficult to gain redress through administrative appeal. Oral authorisations could also increase the incidence of court and tribunal proceedings being commenced with the wrong respondent/decision-maker being nominated by the complainant.

The lack of publicity and the lack of a clear paper trail could result in not only in severe injustices for anyone seeking to review or challenge an administrative decision, but in bad practice in Government decision making. Best practice most consistent with the principles of administrative law would be written authorisations for reasons of transparency and accountability. If oral authorisations are legitimate, there would a temptation to pursue this easier and less specific path—which would undercut best practice.

Not only that, but oral authorisations would potentially undermine parliamentary intention in specific pieces of legislation. But I will come back to this point later. For all these reasons—oral authorisations are a good example of where administrative ease or speed would not produce administrative efficiency—and may have produced very poor outcomes all round.
For all these reasons, I am glad that the Government has been persuaded by these arguments and has removed the ability to orally authorise.

para.inline: 2. What the Bill Does

speech.para: This bill is ostensibly a clarification of when it is allowable for a Minister to authorise another Minister or a Parliamentary Secretary to exercise statutory powers on their behalf.

The Bill amends the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 in direct response to the decision of Justice Spender in Foster v Attorney-General (1998) that has put a question mark over the breadth of s19 in the Acts Interpretation Act.

Justice Spender's decision in the Foster case means that s19 is not sufficient legislative authority for a portfolio Minister to authorise a junior portfolio Minister to exercise statutory powers vested in the holder of a specific ministerial office (ie vested in the "Attorney General"). So in the Foster case, the Attorney General's authorisation of the Minister of Justice was held to be invalid. Consequently, a decision to issue a warrant purportedly made by the Minister for Justice, Senator Vanstone, under section 23 of the Extradition Act 1988 was held to be invalid.
This decision, by implication, also means that a portfolio Minister cannot authorise non-portfolio Ministers or Parliamentary Secretaries when powers are vested in a specific Minister.
Essentially this Bill will do a number of things.
(a) It will retrospectively validate past authorisations that may have been made in reliance on section 19 to the extent that they may be invalid.
(b) It will provide for a Minister to authorise a non-portfolio Minister or Parliamentary Secretary to act on his or her behalf.

(c) And it will ensure that an order can be made by the Governor General under section 19 whenever there is any change to the administration of government business and validates past orders under s19BA to the extent that they may be invalid.

para.inline: 3. Concerns

speech.para: The Greens appreciate the concerns expressed by the Attorney General in relation to Foster . The decision does have potentially serious ramifications for the administrative process of the executive and the Greens will not be preventing this Bill from attempting to address these concerns. The Greens see the merits in remedying the defects of the past. However, we do have concerns that a whole raft delegations or authorisations were done in an informal or non-recorded manner. And we would not like to see our acceptance of past validations as condoning informal delegations/ authorisations in the future.

Of course the issue of retrospectivity is ever present when we are dealing with past delegations. The issue is of injustices in the past that may no longer afford a remedy to an individual. This is always a difficult issue to weigh up. But on balance, as I mentioned previously, I do appreciate the concerns of the Attorney General and the potential for immense difficulties if these past authorisations are not validated.

para.inline: Parliamentary Oversight

speech.para: Another concern the Greens have is with the removal of the variance between specific and non-specific references to Ministers. This Bill essentially operates to remove the distinction between more general terms like "the Minister" and highly specific terms like "the Attorney General".
The situation as it currently stands is that when a piece of legislation uses the term "the Minister" this refers to any Minister with responsibility for that portfolio.

However, when a piece of legislation uses the term "the Attorney General" or "the Minister for Finance" or "the Treasurer", this refers specifically to the person currently occupying that position. By naming a particular Minister, there is an assumption that it was Parliament's view that that Minister should be accountable for things done under the Act and should be required to personally perform the statutory functions that the law assigns to her or him.

The amendments in this Bill, by homogenising the distinction between these terms, threaten to usurp parliamentary intention when the legislation was written and agreed to. Although the Prime Minister's ministerial code of conduct prefers the generic term to avoid potential complications, the legislation handbook recognises that there are appropriate circumstances where parliament should legislate to name a specific minister because of the special skills needed in undertaking a particular duty or function.

Of course, the entire basis of administrative law is that everything requires a specific statutory mandate. Ministers (or anyone else in the executive arm of Government) cannot go off on "a frolic of their own" without reference to a specific statutory authority. So when a piece of legislation says "Attorney General"—it is indicating that there are special skills needed in this area. This should not be overlooked too easily.

The Greens (WA) note that the Attorney General's department is currently undertaking a review of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 . We shall be watching these developments carefully to ensure a good balance is struck. We shall be watching that changes do not ask the Parliament too go too far in permitting the Executive to exercise a wider discretion than is currently available and when altering lines of administrative authority and responsibility delineated by legislation.
While supporting this Bill at Second Reading, the Greens (WA) will carefully consider the amendments in the Committee Stage of this Bill.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank senators for their contributions to this debate. The bill provides that all ministerial authorisations that may have been affected by the decision of the Federal Court in the Foster case are validated. Because of the implications of the decision, it is appropriate that urgent legislative action be taken to clarify the position of ministerial authorisations.

speech.para: The amendments in the bill will ensure that there is no uncertainty about the legal status of decisions made under such authorisations. The bill also clarifies the legal basis for senior portfolio ministers to authorise junior ministers and parliamentary secretaries to exercise statutory powers on their behalf. As senators are aware, the speedy passage of this bill will restore certainty to government administration and facilitate the continued orderly and efficient conduct of government business.

In relation to two matters raised by Senator Stott Despoja, I would say as follows. The government can give the assurance sought by Senator Stott Despoja that there is no political agenda involved with these amendments. Extradition matters or other matters which are sensitive and require review will be capable of review—judicial, administrative and political—in the same manner as occurs at present.

In addition, Senator Stott Despoja wanted an undertaking in the same vein as this sentence: `The amendments will in no way prejudice practice that in the past has ensured due process.' On the contrary, the amendments validate past practice. It will not retrospectively disadvantage anyone.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.39 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison. Is the minister aware of a letter dispatched by the former Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin, to coalition senators and MPs in relation to the new workplace agreement for MOPS staff? In particular, is the minister aware that Senator Minchin urged coalition MPs and senators to `support this offer and impress upon their staff the importance of accepting the agreement in their own interests as well as that of the government'? Why was this final paragraph deleted from the letter sent to non-coalition MPs and senators? Does the minister endorse the view that de facto employers should be encouraged to place pressure on their staff to accept for political reasons an offer which the majority agreed by vote was not in their interests?

—I thank Senator George Campbell for that question. I am not aware of the difference that he points to. The question of a certified agreement was taken to the staff, and it is well known that that was rejected. We are continuing consultation with both opposition and government staff in relation to this. In fact, today I will be talking to representatives from the Democrats. We are very keen to get this right. We are endeavouring to sort the matter out.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, what are the government's proposals in relation to further negotiation of a workplace agreement for MOPS staff after the government's own staff overwhelmingly rejected the dud deal?

—I thought I had already answered that, but what we are doing is talking to staff and finding out what their concerns are. This is very important. It is a fair enough process, one which the opposition always advocates in relation to industrial relations—consultation. That is what we are embarking upon.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. The coalition government since its election has concentrated on the key areas of health, housing, education, employment and economic empowerment in addressing disadvantage within indigenous communities. What is then the minister's response to the sweepingly inaccurate claims made on the international stage regarding Australia's policies on indigenous affairs?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Payne for her question and for her interest in this matter. I find some of the criticism directed at Australia very difficult to accept, particularly when it comes from Australians attending overseas events often at public expense. Australia has an outstanding record on and commitment to human rights. As a nation, we take a very strong bipartisan approach to this important issue. Australia strives to be a decent and harmonious nation, with a society fundamentally based on fairness, on appreciation of racial and cultural diversity, on tolerance and on mutual respect. The government is committed to upholding these values.

answer.para: I find it interesting to note that, since 1945, 5½ million people have come to Australia as new settlers and have made it their home. Last year 100,000 people from 150 different nations settled in Australia. I believe we all should be proud of the fact that Australian society is made up of many different races, religions and beliefs and that this society is balanced, harmonious, rich, varied and united. Indigenous Australians are a vitally important part of this society, and those of us whose origins lie elsewhere recognise that they are an important component and rightfully recognise them as the original inhabitants.

It also needs to be acknowledged that both this government and the previous Labor government have put enormous resources into addressing indigenous disadvantage. There is no question of that disadvantage. International critics and Australians who go overseas and criticise should consider these facts. There are 352,000 Australians who identify themselves as indigenous. Over the past 10 years, the Commonwealth government has provided $15.3 billion in indigenous specific funding. During the past decade about $3 billion has been provided for indigenous housing and infrastructure. Some $3½ billion has been spent on indigenous employment, education and training, a billion dollars has been spent on indigenous health, and $350 million has been provided for indigenous legal aid.

Over $210 million has been provided for native title and land claims. A $64 million package was provided to assist people removed from their families in response to the Bringing them home report. In addition, there has been state, territory and local government funding. There has been support and assistance from churches, religious orders, charitable institutions and foundations and individuals as well as indigenous organisations and individuals. The disadvantage that exists today is not through any lack of government and other resources. The disadvantage exists because of poor outcomes. I think the previous Labor government failed not because of any lack of funding but because it lacked the will to insist on reasonable outcomes from that expenditure.

The Howard government has fought hard for decent outcomes and, as a result, we have been criticised. The ill-informed and politically motivated critics of Australia might like to consider this. Neither this government nor the previous one has had direct control over most of the indigenous programs designed to address disadvantage. As part of the process of indigenous self-management and under legislative requirements, the Australian government is the funding body but not the program manager. The critics need to understand that the Australian government will not be held accountable for failures in program areas it has no control over. They should also be aware that the Howard government will not be deflected from aggressively pursuing improved outcomes for indigenous Australians. We will continue to pursue improved outcomes in health, housing, education and employment no matter what the ill-informed or politically motivated have to say.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is it true that Centrelink staff have been subject to surveillance of their phone calls and that anyone who has made a call to anyone or any organisation deemed to be out of the ordinary has been interrogated? If so, how does the minister defend such action, particularly when Centrelink staff are under such pressure as a result of the government's disdain for the public sector generally and its determination to contract out to the private sector the delivery of government services? How much is being spent on this surveillance operation?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Before I go to the specifics of the senator's question, can I just say that the constant criticism of Centrelink staff seems to be pretty rough, coming from the Labor Party, particularly those who are shop stewards. Only last night, here in the President's suite, I met a woman, a lone parent, who was sick from her job. Because of the sorts of things the opposition has been running about Centrelink and how dreadful it is to deal with, she went in fear and trepidation to the Woden branch of Centrelink to find that she was seen within 15 minutes, treated with compassion and care and given ongoing service, which is fantastic. That is the sort of response I hear from people all the time, except from the opposition, who seem to find it life's mission to put down the Centrelink staff.

answer.para: As to the specifics of the question, a recent improper release of confidential information to the media resulted in the Chief Executive Officer of Centrelink requesting Centrelink's audit team to investigate whether there had been any misuse of Centrelink property. Standard investigation techniques were ap plied which included reviewing and analysing all outgoing PABX—
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Do you want the answer to your question?
—Order!
—Just keep reading.
—Madam President, I want the opposition to have the facts as they are advised to me from the minister for Centrelink.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Standard investigation techniques were applied which included reviewing and analysing all outgoing PABX—
—Order! Senators on my left, Senator Bishop is entitled to hear the answer to his question.
—Madam President, I presumed Senator Bishop did want an answer, but it does not seem as if any of his colleagues do.
—We don't want to hear from Truss's mouthpiece.
—Senator Ray is making an art form these days of being the noise from the back seat. I thought better of him when he was a minister.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order!
—Come on, Hyacinth.

—Madam President, this is really becoming quite impossible. I know that, with a bit of luck, it is the last day and everyone is a bit excited, but they only have to last another three-quarters of an hour. If they have asked the question, I would have thought that they would want the answer.
—We'd like an answer.
—Madam President, the interjections are unruly and I would ask that you rule accordingly.
—Senator Carr, stop shouting and you might hear something.
—As I was saying, standard investigation techniques were ap plied, which included reviewing and analysing all outgoing PABX phone and fax facilities.
—Yes—thumbscrews, garrotting, fingerprints—
—Senator Schacht, people are trying to hear the answer.

—Centrelink is completely within its legal rights to investigate any potential misuse of Commonwealth property. Interviews were conducted with a number of staff who were identified as having placed phone calls to a third party. Officers were asked a series of set questions to assist the investigation team to complete their inquiry. The inquiry is yet to be concluded. From time to time, staff's access to internal email services is revoked for misuse of these services. Surveillance of calls is not a standard practice and would only be used with proper authority in the course of formal investigations.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that a Centrelink employee had their email access cut for circulating bits of a Hansard transcript? Is it true that the offending transcript was one of her own inept answers to a question without notice?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I hope they send around a lot of my Hansard extracts, because they tell me as I go around regional offices that they are delighted about the fact that somebody is sticking up for them when they see the attacks that are coming from the other side of the chamber. So that is the answer you will get today.

—My question is to Senator Ellison, representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. The Howard government has committed to a three-pronged attack against drugs through law enforcement, health and education. A significant part of the $290 million Tough on Drugs initiative is to ensure that schoolchildren receive education about the damaging impact of drugs. Will the minister outline to the Senate the government's National School Drug Education Strategy and the benefit it will have for schoolchildren across Australia?
—I thank Senator Coonan for that very important question.
—Gallery! Gallery!

—I am sure the opposition would be interested in the answer to this question, which perhaps is one of the most serious issues facing young people in Australia today. The young people of Australia are, after all, our most precious resource. The coalition government has shown a real commitment to addressing the question of illicit drug usage in this country. In the recent election campaign, the coalition committed a further $10 million for the National School Drug Education Strategy over the next four years, bringing the total expenditure in this area to $17.5 million. This school drug education component is part of the Prime Minister's national illicit drug strategy entitled Tough on Drugs. The total expenditure involved is some $290 million and it covers areas such as law enforcement, health and, importantly, education.

answer.para: As the former minister for schools, I had the pleasure of being involved in setting up the National Advisory Committee on Drug Education chaired by Ms Karen Hart, President of the Australian Secondary Principals Association, and consisting of representatives appointed for their expertise from education authorities, health and law enforcement agencies, principals, teachers, parents and other community organisations. The committee provides expert advice and direction to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs on the development and implementation of this strategy.

This committee will also monitor, review and evaluate the progress of the strategy, particularly in light of emerging issues relating to drugs and associated drug education. That will be done both nationally and internationally. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the National Advisory Committee on Drug Education has completed a draft strategy and that has been released for comment by my colleague Trish Worth, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. It has been released for wide consultation, and submissions are invited. Those submissions will close on 12 February next year. I urge everyone here to participate in that process.

The goal of the draft strategy is to achieve no illicit drugs in schools. This goal has been endorsed by all states and territories. The strategy aims for world's best practice and reflects the best possible advice from health, education and law enforcement experts in the field. The National School Drug Education Strategy is about more than just teaching our young children to say no to drugs; it is about teaching young people to know and understand why saying no is much better and healthier for them than saying yes.

Key organisations and interested parties included in wide consultation have been the state and territory governments, the National Catholic Education Commission, the Australian Council of State School Organisations, the National Council of Independent Schools, the National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre, the Australian Parents Council and the Australian Federal Police. The government recognises that community support for schools is going to be vital to the success of this school drug strategy. The government is therefore inviting parents, teachers, key experts and community groups to submit suggestions and make contributions to the consultations on this draft strategy. As I say, submissions close on 12 February next year. The National School Drug Education Strategy and feedback sheet are available on the DETYA web site, and I invite everyone to participate in what is a most important process.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware that, notwithstanding the assurances she gave the Senate yesterday, Child Support Agency senior management personnel have only recently told staff not to be `paranoid' about their personal safety concerns about having to disclose their full names to disgruntled clients? Is the minister aware that Child Support Agency staff are still being told by senior management that they are in fact still obliged to provide their full name to clients and will be sacked if they do not? How does the minister explain this inconsistency between the supposed guidelines she referred to yesterday and what is actually going on in the agency?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I am not aware of the claims made by Senator Collins. The answer I gave to the Senate yesterday was taken on notice some days before and was the answer provided to me by the Child Support Agency. I will certainly refer Senator Collins's response to the Child Support Agency to see whether the information she has been given accords with current practice or whether she is out of date.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister share the view of some senior management in the agency that staff are being paranoid? Can the minister confirm that agency staff have been advised by former military personnel in staff protection security briefings that full disclosure of names could cause security problems? Perhaps also the minister could confirm precisely what Hansard was being circulated on the email that was cancelled.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I think the opposition is suffering from a bit of an ignorance deficit.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There is an awful lot of mirth here. I hope that the spirits were not engaged in too much over lunch. The situation is that the opposition knows full well that the service delivery responsibilities for Centrelink and the Child Support Agency are the responsibilities of the Minister for Community Services, Mr Warren Truss, who actually is accountable to the parliament in the House of Representatives. If the opposition were really interested in these issues, then they would be asking the minister directly.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Newman as the portfolio minister, the cabinet minister, now on a number of occasions, repeated today, has suggested the opposition ask questions of her junior minister in the House of Representatives. She is the portfolio minister. A similar situation would be for Mr Costello in answering a question to suggest we ask Senator Kemp in the Senate. That is the equivalent of what this minister, who is the portfolio minister, the responsible cabinet minister, is saying to the Senate. That is absolutely inappropriate. I believe that a demand should be made of this minister to answer questions directed to her in her capacity as the responsible portfolio minister. She cannot duckshove it to a junior minister.
—There is no point of order.
—If the opposition were not so hell-bent on showing their ignorance, they would have looked at the administrative arrangements laid down by the government.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. The minister is out of order. She is out of order because she is answering by saying `the opposition'. She was asked a question by a senator. A senator is elected to this chamber and is entitled to question in her own or his own right. This is a question to the executive. The minister is an executive member with the portfolio responsibility and is bound to answer to the senator.

answer.para: Senator Alston interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The conduct on my right is absolutely unacceptable.
—I am perfectly happy to seek an answer from the minister responsible, Mr Truss, who is responsible for the administration of services in the Child Support Agency and Centrelink. (Time expired)
—You are hopeless! Sit down!
—Madam President, it is one thing to take spurious points of order—
—Are you taking—
—This is a point of order—
—I will determine that, Senator.

—I am simply drawing your attention to what is nothing more or less than plain abuse. Saying, `You are hopeless! Sit down!' has got nothing at all to do with anything that is being said in this chamber by Senator Newman; it is simply a tactic on the part of someone who should be setting a good example but who seems to be determined to ensure that no answers can properly be heard. —Madam President, on the point of order: first of all, the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate stood up and again abused the chair by just beginning to speak without being called by you or taking a point of order. I believe that you should draw that to his attention and ask him to stop behaving in that fashion. The other thing I mention in relation to the substance—if there was any—of Senator Alston's point of order is the clock. The one-minute time limit for Senator Newman's non-answer had run down—no time left—and it was time she sat down. After all, she is not willing to provide any information to the Senate, because she does not take her portfolio responsibilities seriously.
—Madam President—

—Order! Just a moment, Senator. I think it is time we got on with question time. There has been shouting on both sides of the chamber, making it extremely difficult to hear. The behaviour is completely disorderly, and disruptive of question time. I now call Senator Bourne.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Hill. I refer to the announcement yesterday of the minister's plan to revise Australia's action plan on human rights, creating Australia's second such action plan, and I ask: will community groups be consulted in the redrafting? Will the minister be seeking the views of all non-government agencies involved in the promotion and protection of human rights, including aca demics, commentators, lawyers, church organisations and other advocates of human rights? Will the action plan cover the range of rights enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, as well as the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights? What is the timetable for completion of the new plan?

—I am pleased that Senator Bourne read the speech that Mr Downer gave last night on the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, in which he outlined our position in relation to the international environment and also what we are seeking to do domestically. One of the announcements he made was that he was committed to revising Australia's national action plan on human rights. He said:

answer.para: We will commence work on this, including the processes of consultations, shortly.

I remind the honourable senator that the recommendation from the 1993 Vienna World Conference on Human Rights that all states consider drawing up national action plans on human rights led to Australia's development of the first plan in 1994.

I understand that there will be extensive consultations. There are two existing forums through which such consultations can be undertaken: one coordinated by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, primarily focused on the international human rights issues; and the other coordinated by the Attorney-General's Department, primarily dealing with the domestic human rights issues. A wide range of community opinion is expressed and input conveyed through those forums. A thoroughgoing process of additional consultations specifically in relation to the national action plan is currently under consideration, involving not only NGOs but also Commonwealth ministers and their departments and the state and territory governments.

A working group comprising officers of Commonwealth departments will be established to develop the best possible format for the new national action plan. This will be submitted for approval to the Attorney-General and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Therefore, whilst the precise coverage of the new national action plan is still to be determined, the government would emphasise that it is committed to the universality of human rights and would expect that this commitment would be fully reflected in the plan.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has not mentioned the last part of my question, and that is: what would the timetable be for completion of the new plan? I understand I am not actually talking to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, so the minister may not have that on the tip of his tongue. But if the minister could get back to us with a timetable, if it is available, that would be appreciated.

—I will seek advice on that. I suspect that the timetable has not been settled. It was not referred to in the speech last night nor is it in the briefing notes, but I will see if Mr Downer can give an indication of how long he expects this process to take.

—My question is addressed to Senator Newman as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer to a recent article under the minister's name that appeared in the Melbourne Age . I ask whether the minister recalls stating in the article her view that:

question.para: Leadership calls for courage, risk taking, vision and a sense of community. Australian women are prepared for this, and it is time we used them in the service of our country.

In light of her robust views on the qualities of leadership, will Senator Newman now finally commit herself to appear before the Senate estimates committee and answer questions relating to the status of women portfolio instead of abdicating her responsibilities to Senator Hill, whose ignorance on these matters is legendary?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Madam President, they must have been at a Christmas party for lunch. To describe Senator Hill in that form is just amazing—the kindest and most gentle of men, a real sensitive new age guy who has always been totally interested in the rights of all people, particularly the rights of women. I think that was a very unkind cut from Senator Crowley, who should have known better. Senator Crowley, you also know full well—
—Her insensitivity is legendary.

Senator Hill appears very properly before your committee representing the Prime Minister. answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senators on my left.
—Did you ask for double the money?
—Senator Schacht, cease shouting.
—I think they have had tipple. There is no other explanation. I wish them well for their Christmas, but not here, not now.
—Senator, remarks like that do not add to the decorum of the chamber.
