—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. If Senator Newman does place such store, as she says in this article or seems to suggest, on the questions of concern about women, I am sure we could release her from her obligations in the estimates to address her own portfolio, perhaps during the time when she fails to answer questions on Centrelink. Perhaps the minister would like to comment on whether or not she would make an arrangement to support the questions about women during the hearings of PM&C and find a replacement who will answer questions on Centrelink?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I can only assume that Senator Crowley is asking me to absent myself from my own portfolio's estimates on child care, child support, family and children's services, youth homelessness, disability services and so on. I assume she thinks that these are not matters of importance to women.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. On the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, I want to ask about West Papua, Irian Jaya, again. What further information does the government have on the massacre of an estimated 150 West Papuans on 6 July this year after they raised the Morning Star, the freedom flag, on the wharf in Biak? In particular, is there any follow-up information about the plight of Dr Philip Karma, who has been reportedly shot in the elbows and legs and carted off to gaol to face a life sentence? Is the minister aware that today the traditional council of the Amungme people, meeting near the Freeport mine, have called for the United Nations to reopen the case of the plight of West Papua? Can the minister say whether Australia would be amenable to a new discussion of West Papua in the United Nations and, indeed, to reviewing its own policy? (Time expired)

—I have just checked the briefing notes that I have been provided with and there does not seem to be anything further than that which I had previously advised Senator Brown of. I have read some material to suggest that the earlier estimates of violence were overstated, but nevertheless any level of violence, particularly if there are deaths concerned, is totally unsatisfactory.

answer.para: The approach of the Australian government has been to support in whatever practical ways it can the process of change that is occurring in Indonesia at the moment. There are a number of ways in which we can be supportive in such a practical way. Basically, we can encourage the forces—particularly the military forces, but other security forces as well—to respect the human rights of all individuals who are under their coverage. We can also provide aid and assistance to try to help them through the time of very severe economic stress, which is no doubt contributing to the difficulties as well. We think this is the best way in which we can be of assistance. I know of no suggestion of any change to the foreign policy of Australia in relation to Irian Jaya.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, but I draw his attention to the fact there are many political prisoners in West Papuan gaols for supporting the call for independence of West Papua. What further investigations will the Australian government be taking into the plight of those prisoners and their civil rights, and indeed the need for them to be brought to a speedy, open and fair trial? Secondly, again, will the minister put to the foreign minister that Australia should be reopening the question of a debate in the United Nations about the rights and the aspirations for freedom of the West Papuan people?

—I do not think the latter will occur, because it is inconsistent with longstanding Australian government policy. In relation to the former, we are obviously concerned about continued imprisonment of political prisoners. There were some releases after the new presidency in Indonesia, but there are still many political prisoners. We are working, both bilaterally and multilaterally, to see their early release and, in accordance with the international declaration, to see that those who are being held be brought to speedy and fair trial. That has also been a longstanding position of the Australian government, and we will continue to press the issue.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Self-funded Retirees

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. In the light of the minister's complete inability to answer my question yesterday regarding whether superannuants will be worse off under the proposed tax arrangements, I ask: can the minister now confirm that a self-funded retiree who receives between $30,000 and $40,000 per annum will not be eligible for either the aged persons savings bonus or the self-funded retiree supplementary bonus, worth $3,000? I also refer the minister to fact sheet A337 of the tax package. Can the minister explain how the government's proposed new 15 per cent tax on the underlying income of allocated pensions and annuities will actually operate, and what effect it will have on the long-term retirement incomes of those self-funded retirees with these private pensions?

—Senator Faulkner, your question on self-funded retirees was answered yesterday. I suggest you go back to the Hansard , and you will find that that question was very clearly answered. We pointed out the income tests which are available for the aged person savings bonus and we pointed out the possible effects of other elements of the tax package on self-funded retirees.
—You haven't got a clue, have you?

—Well let me make it very clear—I am delighted the question was asked, again, by Senator Faulkner—that in the Labor Party tax package there was nothing for self-funded retirees. No tax cuts available for self-funded retirees; tax cuts available for those in the work force.
—That is not true.
—Senator Cook, if you do not agree with that, you get up after question time and attempt to correct me.
—I'll tell the truth, you can tell the lies.
—We'll see about that. But there was one major effect on self-funded retirees.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. However interesting this may be, I asked Senator Kemp a question about the government's approach in relation to self-funded retirees earning between $30,000 and $40,000 per annum. I also asked him to explain the government's proposed 15 per cent tax on underlying income of allocated pensions and annuities. It is a very clear question and I ask you, Madam President, if you would direct him to answer the question asked.

—I cannot direct him to answer it in a way that you might want, Senator. I can only see that his answer is relevant to the matter that you have raised. But I am certainly mindful of the question, and Senator Kemp should be also.

—Madam President, the question in relation to self-funded retirees and the benefits that they get out of the tax package was explained very carefully yesterday. The income test in relation to the aged persons supplementary benefit was also carefully explained yesterday. What is the point of answering questions, Senator Faulkner, when you absolutely refuse to read them? I am pointing out that self-funded retirees will note that they got nothing out of the Labor Party tax package except the capital gains tax. They de-grandfathered the pre-1985 assets. That is what the Labor Party attempted to give to self-funded retirees. Labor's real concern for self-funded retirees will come in a vote later today. One of the groups in the community pushing as hard as they could for the health rebate were the self-funded retirees. They are the people that are waiting for the Labor Party to recognise that an election commitment was made, which this government is attempting to deliver. One of the non-government parties which is going to attempt to block this particular item—well, we shall see—is the Labor Party if they stick with their stated position. So don't you get up here and attempt to lecture us-
—Don't you lecture us.
—Don't you attempt to lecture us with your polices on self-funded retirees.
—Senator Kemp, you should direct your remarks to the chair.
—Don't you lecture us, you little upstart!
—Senator Cook, stop shouting.

—They are an absolute disgrace. The other issue was the impact on the recipients of allocated pensions and annuities. Let me make it absolutely clear that, during the election campaign, there was an attempt by the Labor Party to run a scare campaign on that. A variety of changes were made in this area, and no-one accepted the Labor Party's scare campaign on this particular matter.

answer.para: Under the reforms outlined in our new tax system, from the 2000-01 income year the income of the underlying annuity and pension business of life insurance and superannuation funds would be assessable, and deductions would be allowed for the interest component of the pension payments and associated expenses. The effect of this is that any net profit derived by the life insurance or superannuation fund on an annuity or pension business would now be taxed. The proposal in the new tax system that we are bringing in will not change the tax treatment of allocated pensions or annuity recipients. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Yesterday and today I have asked the minister about private pensioners receiving between $30,000 and $40,000 per annum. I ask the minister whether his dismissive answers both yesterday and today to this question actually change if he knows that his own ministerial colleague, Mr Ruddock, wrote to a constituent of both his and mine saying:

question.para: Please understand that I truly appreciate your financial position in that you fall between categories.

My supplementary question is: do these privately funded retirees fall between categories, and isn't the result of them doing so that they will be fully liable for the GST on all their expenditure and they will have little or no compensatory measures applying to them? Was that deliberate on the part of the government or was it a design fault?

talk.start.para: —This is a leader of a party that attempted to penalise, above all, self-funded retirees in its tax package in the last election. One reason you lost that election was the punitive tax that you attempted to impose on self-funded retirees.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. My question related to private pensioners earning between $30,000 and $40,000 per year. I asked Senator Kemp whether this is a deliberate policy on behalf of the government or whether it was a design fault. The question is about, quite clearly, a certain category of private pensioners and superannuants. I ask you to direct him to answer it. Admit what is going on, Senator Kemp. Own up!

—Madam President, on the point of order: that was clearly no point of order. Senator Faulkner asked me about the impact of the tax package on self-funded retirees. I have outlined that yesterday in some detail and the benefits that people who are receiving over $30,000 a year could receive. What Senator Faulkner is sensitive about is that I am talking about the Labor Party policy on self-funded retirees.
—Order! I draw your attention to the specific question that was asked by Senator Faulkner. Address yourself to that, Senator Kemp.

—I have outlined in detail that self-funded retirees will receive a large number of benefits under the tax package. Many will receive the benefits of the income tax cuts that we have proposed. Many will benefit from the refundable franking credits that we have proposed. Many will presumably benefit from the health insurance rebate, which we are trying to get through this Senate over the opposition of the Labor Party. The point I am making is that this was the group that tried to impose a penalty tax on self-funded retirees. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the former shadow minister for the status of women and now Minister for the Environment and Heritage. In May this year, you announced your intention to assess the possibility of a new marine protected area of Tasmanian sea mounts. Could the minister advise the Senate of progress on this matter?
—If Senator Hill heard the question, I invite him to answer it.

—I have a fair idea of the question. I commend Senator Gibson for his interest in conservation, which is more than you get from the Labor Party. This is in fact further good news from a government committed to good conservation practice. The Howard government is committed to the development of a nationally representative system of marine protected areas.

answer.para: Earlier this year, I was pleased to declare the world's second largest marine park in the Great Australian Bite. I also announced in May our intention to assess five additional marine park proposals, including the area known as the Tasmanian sea mounts. I am delighted to indicate to the Senate today that the assessment is now complete and that we will be issuing a notice of intent to establish the Tasmanian Sea Mounts Marine Reserve. The notice of intent will be followed by a three-month public consultation period before the reserve is formally declared in accordance with the requirements of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act.

The Tasmanian Sea Mounts Marine Reserve will cover an area of some 370 square kilometres 170 kilometres south of Tasmania. This marine reserve is the first exclusively deep water marine reserve in Australian waters and will protect an outstanding aspect of our ocean environment. The Tasmanian sea mounts are a collection of 70 submerged mountains that rise from water in depths of between 1,000 and 2,000 metres from the sea floor to heights of between 200 and 500 metres. This field of sea mounts, which are remnants of extinct volcanos, is a distinctive geological feature not known anywhere else on the continental margin of Australia. Equally, the flora and fauna of the sea mounts contain many animals that are not found anywhere else on earth. Recent research by the CSIRO found a high proportion of species, including eight genera, that are new to science.

The Tasmanian Sea Mounts Marine Reserve will protect a representative sample of the sea mounts. While final management arrangements will be determined following the declaration of the reserve, we have indicated that our preference is to establish a unique vertical zoning system for the reserve. Areas under 500 metres will be managed as a highly protected zone while areas shallower than 500 metres will be referred to as a managed resource zone. These arrangements reflect advice from the CSIRO that the sea mounts ecosystem is not closely interrelated or dependent on shallower waters.

In conclusion, the development of this reserve proposal has followed extensive consultations with both conservation and industry organisations. I am particularly appreciative of the constructive approach that these organisations have been playing. I would particularly also like to thank my departmental officers and the CSIRO who have helped bring this proposal to fruition.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister confirm that the effect of the proposed health insurance rebate, which is not means tested and which will operate alongside the existing Medicare levy surcharge, will provide a double incentive for high income earners to take out insurance? They will gain a 30 per cent rebate and avoid the one per cent surcharge. Does this mean that a person on a high salary, such as a Prime Minister, of $205,000 per annum who is currently paying the one per cent surcharge would receive an effective subsidy of $2,950 per year for a $3,000 policy? Is it true that a family on $35,000 per year, which already receives $450 under the existing incentive scheme, would gain only an additional $90 per year on a policy worth $1,800? Do you support fully subsidising the health insurance of high income families?
—That is getting very close to debating matters within a bill that is before the chamber. If the minister has anything to say that does not intrude on the debate, he may answer.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Though I recognise that it is close to what is on the Notice Paper , I want to seize the opportunity to answer this question because it really clarifies something that seems to confuse the Labor Party and has confused the Labor Party ever since it introduced Medicare.
—That is not answering the question.
—I have been on my feet for about 30 seconds. The reality is that Medicare is for all Australians, be they wealthy, indigent, aged or young. It is a system that the government fully supports.

answer.para: The tax comes in at a higher level than it does in the normal taxation system. Senator Evans is probably unaware of that. Many people are confused about this, and the Labor Party is obviously confused about it as well. Something that has never been acknowledged but that I think Senator Lees mentioned at one stage is that many people self-insure. If you go into the statistics on people admitted to private hospitals you will find that in many private hospitals, particularly maternity hospitals, people are uninsured but pay the Medicare levy and then pay out of their pocket on top of that.

The class struggle and class warfare have always been a chip on the shoulder of the Labor Party. It has always been there. All on the other side feel that they have been badly done by, somewhere or other, and that anybody who earns a few more bob than somebody else does should be cut down. They do not believe in creating wealth; they believe in cutting people down to the mean common denominator. Somehow or other they cannot get over this nonsense that you should not encourage people to earn a few bob, get off the taxpayer's back and take out private health insurance.

I am proud to say that nearly all my colleagues have private health insurance. They recognise that they are going to take the burden off the public hospitals, and so they either pay their own way, if they can afford to, or are insured so that they take the burden off the public system. That does not seem to get through. The Labor Party believes in a completely public system and that we should all be lowered to the lowest common denominator.

Another point that I would like to make to Senator Evans is that I heard Senator West this morning crying about the cost of the gap. Across the patients admitted to private hospitals, the average number of bills is 6.4 and the average gap is $106. Across all medical services in Australia, the gap is $14 for all Medicare services. In the private hospitals, the gap is $106. Obviously there are outlays. I know of a patient who had a $40,000 heart operation. The gap was $346. There will be outlays. There will always be people complaining about the gap. Everybody wants something for nothing; it is human nature to do so.

It is important that the legislation be passed, because it is equitable for every person in this country—for both the wealthy and the poor. It is equitable for the 700,000 people who are below an income of $20,000 who care to take out private health insurance. Of course there may be people on a higher income who will benefit in one way or another, but it is their right.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Just a moment, Senator Herron. There are far too many people on my left who are shouting, and it is totally disorderly. It makes it impossible for people to hear, either in the chamber or through radio or television.

—I want to clarify another fact. The private hospital system subsidises the public hospital system in relation to the medical officers there. I am proud to say that for over 30 years I worked on a sessional basis in the public hospital system. I earned about five times as much in the private system as I did there, but I en joyed lecturing to students, nurses and medical graduates. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Minister, this is not about class warfare; but I note that you represent vested union interests in this debate—those of your own union. Isn't it true that the Prime Minister and you will be among the high income earners who will benefit from over $900 million of the $1.4 billion subsidy? Isn't it true that the vast bulk of the subsidy goes to you, the Prime Minister and your fellow high income earners and does not go to the battlers at all?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The simple answer is no. The longer answer is that I got off my backside, studied and entered a noble profession. Not one of them over there has done that. They are the old trade unionists who bludged off the system and are still bludging off the system. They come in here and attack people who have made a few bob and who go out and work in honourable professions.
—Senator Herron, I ask you to withdraw those remarks.
—I withdraw them. In a spirit of goodwill, may I wish everybody here a happy Christmas and hope they have a happy holiday.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. Minister, were the environmental consequences of the tax package considered at any stage of the package's formulation? In particular were you, as environment minister, consulted on the environmental implications of cuts to the diesel fuel excise?

—Of course I was. We on this side of the chamber are interested in win-win outcomes. We want good environmental outcomes but we also want to provide people with jobs and economic opportunity. That balanced approach is clear within the tax package. We recognise that Australian industry suffers a disadvantage in excess of industry in other countries, because of the long distances that have to be travelled. The cost of transport in Australia is high in comparison with transport costs for our competitors. We have sought to reduce those costs to help, in particular, the bush and regional areas of Australia but also basically to help all of the economy to grow and to give the benefits that can flow from that to all Australians.

answer.para: We are very pleased that, so far, we have been very successful in that. The rate of growth and the falls in unemployment are something that we want to see, but they have to continue—and that requires further reform and further economic change. One of the areas of reform is taxation. As I said, by reducing the cost of transport we can continue to grow the Australian economy and to provide the advantages that we wish for.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Minister, is it true that Australian Greenhouse Office attempts to have input into the tax reform process were knocked back by Treasury? Is that rebuff one of the reasons that the tax package gives great incentives for using diesel fuel but no incentives—in fact, disincentives—for using renewable fuels? Given that diesel has just been listed by the Californian EPA as one of the top ranking causes of cancer, isn't this part of the tax package a big threat to the health of Australians and to the quality of the air that we breathe?

—There are no disincentives built into the policy for alternative fuels. We have reduced the price of diesel for the economic reasons that I have just stated—to help grow the economy and provide jobs. That might not be of interest to the Australian Democrats, but jobs are of interest to most Australians.

answer.para: The Australian Greenhouse Office reports through a ministerial council that I chair. Therefore, the views of the Australian Greenhouse Office were properly inputted to the deliberation of the cabinet on this matter. So, yes, we want to encourage and support renewable energies. We have a number of programs which do that. If the honourable senator would like to come around to my office, I will arrange a briefing for her.

I would like to join with Senator Herron in wishing all senators a happy Christmas. We look forward to their return next year and to a more cooperative mood from the other side, we hope, to ensure the continuation of good government. I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talk.start.para: —Senator Ray asked me questions yesterday relating to the superannuation surcharge. I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard additional responses to those questions.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
RESPONSE TO QUESTIONS FROM SENATOR RAY ON THE SUPERANNUATION SURCHARGE

para.inline: Can the Minister confirm that the Australian Taxation Office is imposing the 15 per cent super tax on deceased Australians?

speech.para: No.

Assessments are issued to the holders of for member's contributions, generally superannuation providers. They are based on information given to the Commissioner about members' contributions. Basically, if an assessment is raised in relation to a member's, contributions and that member died before the assessment is received by the provider, then the assessment is taken not to have been made in relation to that member's contributions.

para.inline: How many assessment notices have been sent to deceased taxpayers for the 15 per cent super tax?

speech.para: The Commissioner of Taxation would not send out a surcharge assessment if he is aware the member has died.

In most cases, assessments are sent to superannuation providers as the holders of members' contributions. However, if a provider ceases to be the holder of a member's contribution (for example, when a member is in receipt of a pension or annuity), any assessment will be issued to the member. If a member dies before an assessment is received, the assessment is taken not to have been made, that is, there is no requirement to pay any assessed surcharge liability in these cases.

para.inline: Why does the Government believe that it is appropriate to levy the surcharge or super tax on Australians who have not and cannot receive their superannuation because they have died?

speech.para: Surcharge is calculated on the surchargeable contributions of high income earners and is assessed to the holder of the contributions. As I indicated earlier, if a member dies before the surcharge assessment is received by the holder of the contributions, then the assessment is taken not to have been made and there is no requirement to pay the amount assessed.

para.inline: How much does the Government anticipate collecting in this matter?

speech.para: The Government does not anticipate collecting any amount in relation of the surchargeable contributions of high income earners who die before an assessment is received by the holder of the contributions. The law does not allow it.

para.inline: Would the Minister like to comment on the principle of sending out notices of assessment, which are quite appropriate with income tax and other matters, to people who have died and are not able to access their benefit to superannuation but who still have to pay the tax on it? Can you see that that is quite a different principle to any other tax imposition for a deceased person? Can you imagine the distress it causes to those managers and beneficiaries of the estate? Can you tell us what the situation is, how many people are affected, what the value of it is and how you rationalise the principle of the matter?

speech.para: The Commissioner of Taxation would not send out a surcharge assessment if he is aware the member has died. If the Commissioner is not aware of the death and an assessment subsequently issues, there is no requirement to pay the assessed surcharge liability.

talk.start.para: —Senator Murray asked a question without notice to the minister representing me, Senator Ellison, on 2 December on whether the government would consider legislation allowing the Australian Taxation Office to deem contractors as employees. I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard the additional response to the question.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
RESPONSE TO QUESTION FROM SENATOR MURRAY ON DEEMING CONTRACTORS AS EMPLOYEES
The response read as follows:
The Government has proposed legislation as part of its tax reform package that will address the concerns of Senator Murray.

Specifically, the introduction of the Australian Business Number (ABN) will provide an opportunity to improve compliance. Businesses will generally be required to issue an invoice quoting their ABN. In most cases this will happen as part of the normal GST arrangements for tax invoices.

These quotation arrangements will be complemented by the new pay as you go (PAYG) system. The withholding arrangements under PAYG will apply to payments to employees and other office holders covered by the existing pay as you earn (PAYE) system.
In addition payers will withhold:
. from specified payments, such as labour hire arrangements;
. from a payment for work if the payee agrees to instalment deductions being made; and
. from a payment on an invoice that does not include quotation of an ABN.
This approach will do away with the need for difficult judgments by the businesses about whether the service providers they engage are employees or contractors.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Family and Community Services: Answers to Questions

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Newman) to questions without notice asked today.
What an utterly unbelievable performance we had here today. Basically, it is: don't ask me, I'm just the senior minister.

talk.start.para: —You lot are so unoriginal.

—It was actually a worse performance than Senator Kemp normally gives. She says, `Don't ask me. I'm just the portfolio minister.' Senator Newman makes Senator Kemp look good. That is how bad Senator Newman is, and that is a very big call indeed.

speech.para: In relation to questions, she does not answer any of them. It is always the big flick to Mr Truss, the Public Service, the secretary to a department or whatever. This minister is utterly hopeless. She is utterly hopeless in terms of her portfolio. She is utterly hopeless in relation to representing her home state. On the one hand she says she does not handle Centrelink anymore—that is Mr Truss's responsibility—but on the other hand she says her workload has doubled, so therefore she cannot come along to Senate estimates. You cannot have it both ways. This is her excuse for not turning up to the status of women committee estimates. The bottom line is that Senator Newman does not have the intestinal fortitude to front status of women committee estimates.

talk.start.para: —Oh, Senator Mackay! How could she be in two places at once?
—It is true, and you know it, Senator Coonan. This is the gossip around the bureaucracy.

speech.para: Senator Coonan interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Coonan! You will get your go shortly.
—Senator Newman has often not been available and deliberately not turned up to Senate estimates, to status of women estimates. She does not have the intestinal fortitude to turn up.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. We have just heard what really must be one of the most absurd comments ever heard in this parliament: Senator Newman is somehow afraid to face you, Senator. I can't believe it.
—Senator Kemp, what is your point of order?
—That is the point of order, Madam Deputy President.
—There is no point of order. You have been here long enough to know that that was a spurious point of order.
—I just wanted to record that that was the most absurd comment ever heard in parliament.
—I thought he may have been more charitable having been now named as only the second most incompetent minister on the other side.

speech.para: Since the coalition came to government in 1996, we have witnessed a deliberate rapid decline in positive policies for women and a deliberate rapid increase in policies which have a negative impact on women, thanks to the government and Senator Newman. The coalition has consistently sought to wind back the clock to the bad old days when women were denied access to child care, when women did not have choices because they alone carried the burden of providing care for the children, the sick and the aged and when women struggled for equal pay and equal access to the work force.

Well, the coalition should be very proud of what it has done, very proud of its measure of success. The employment figures today paint a very grim picture for women. I repeat: the employment figures today paint a very grim picture for women. Let me just explain to you what they are—and I am sure that at least Senator Coonan and Senator Payne will be interested in what I have to say. Today we saw that the participation rate of women in the work force has declined to 53.8 per cent—twice the fall, as reported today, as having occurred in the male participation rate, thanks to the government and Senator Newman. Women are giving up in the work force, thanks to the government and Senator Newman. Women are also being hardest hit by the squeeze on jobs. Today's unemployment statistics have shown a rise in the unemployment rate for women that is more than double the increase in the unemployment rate for men—I repeat: more than double the increase in the unemployment rate for men. And that is on the back of pretty bad employment figures, anyway.

The bottom line is—and I think it was Senator Coonan who warned the coalition, and I agree with her—that there appears to be mounting evidence that the coalition government is losing ground with women voters. I think that is a statement of the absolute obvious, but she was absolutely correct. Make no mistake: this is quite a deliberate strategy. Make no mistake: John Howard's 1950s white picket fence agenda, supported by Senator Newman, is behind all this. And make no mistake: this is why in the last election far more women voted Labor than the coalition—four per cent, in fact. This government, with Senator Newman, has utterly betrayed the women of Australia.

talk.start.para: —What an extraordinary performance from Senator Mackay this afternoon. This is, under the standing orders, as I understand it, a period to take note of answers given by ministers during question time. I think a close examination of the Hansard of Senator Newman's responses given in question time certainly will not provide any support for anything Senator Mackay has said this afternoon.

speech.para: But, in relation to Senator Mackay's last few points, I would just note briefly that in my own state of New South Wales—where we were told time and time again that the women representing my party in that state would not be returned to the parliament—the member for Gilmore, the member for Hughes and the member for Lindsay have all come back into the parliament as proud and strong members of this government. That is a very important aspect that the opposition continues to ignore.

However, Madam Deputy President, in relation to the things that Senator Newman did refer to in her responses in question time today, I would like to address some of the issues in relation to Centrelink and the minister's portfolio. Do you know, since its establishment in just September of last year, Centrelink has made some extraordinary advances in service delivery to Australian consumers. It has improved access to government services by having brought together a huge range of service delivery functions from what were previously the departments of Social Security and Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.

But those opposite do not want to know about any of those efficiencies, any of those more effective service delivery options. They do not want to know about the new approach to the delivery of government services—an approach that works from the customer's perspective. Centrelink has extended its previous roles beyond just the assessment of entitlements and distribution of payments to providing solutions for customers. It does this by providing a range of services, products, advice and payments on behalf of government departments.

What Centrelink currently does is bring together and deliver services on behalf of seven client departments, their services being delivered to customers in a manner targeted to simplify their interactions with government organisations. But the opposition does not want to know anything about that. It does not want to see anything positive in those changes, and it does not want to see anything positive in improving services for the customers who access Centrelink.

Centrelink has, in the last 12 months, achieved an enormous success in becoming customer driven—and it has done it in practical ways. It has held value creation workshops where the staff listen to customers providing on the spot feedback. It has set up a popular 1800 customer feedback line. It has drawn up a customer charter and provided customer comment cards for customers to complete. It has been trialling what are referred to as `personalised service initiatives', which take the form of a `one main contact model' where the customers are able to deal with the same Centrelink customer service officer for all their business. That is what being customer driven is all about. It is a model that has been very favourably received by both customers and staff.

And Centrelink will build on the achievements of the past year to further improve its delivery of services. A new service delivery model has been developed that Centrelink describes as being based on `a life events approach'. When you talk about life events, what do you mean? They include things like looking for a job, needing help after someone in your family has died, and planning retirement. Under that new model, customers are not expected to walk in off the street and know the wide range of payments that are available; they are not expected to know what each single payment is called or how you specifically access it or fill in the appropriate form; whether you might be eligible or what queue you are supposed to be in. All of those things can be quite confronting, quite difficult for people who are accessing services for the first time.

All that those persons need to bring to the office is a knowledge of their own circumstances and a preparedness to tell the truth and give the details of those circumstances. What they receive then is a package of products and services that are tailored in response to that life event, whatever it may be, that take into account their individual situation, their needs and their expectations. That is what responsive customer service delivery is all about.

In the new service delivery model, Centrelink will retain the `one main contact approach' so that the customer can represent themselves to Centrelink with whatever life event they are experiencing and have their own situation assessed. They can then continue to do business, if they choose to do so, with that same customer service officer over a period of time. What knowing a customer clearly does is cut out a lot of red tape. It cuts out, for example, the current proof of identity processes where, if you are not dealing with the same person, you do have to prove who you are on each occasion that you present to a different customer service officer in your Centrelink office. They do not have to repeat their story time and time again. That is a flexible customer-sensitive approach to service delivery. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —One could say that the speech that Senator Payne has just given is the answer we should have heard from the minister before, and it certainly does go some way in defence of Centrelink. Centrelink's ambitions have just been very well described; Centrelink's performance is something else again.

speech.para: Some of us have had the opportunity, as part of a regional employment inquiry which I chaired, to visit and cover many, many places around Australia this year. Again and again, the complaint from the Job Network providers and from the people who were looking for jobs and assistance through the Job Network was that Centrelink was one of the major breakdowns and failings in that process. Centrelink, for something like eight weeks, failed to provide referrals to Job Network agencies. That is why so many unemployed people were disadvantaged, and why so many Job Network providers went to the wall.

So you might have listened to Senator Payne's excellent description of what Centrelink might be or might even strive to be, but it is not a description of what it is. Certainly it is not. As for the suggestion that it has a new service delivery model that makes everything wonderful for the community out there, anyone who has ever rung a 1300 number trying to get information from the department will know that the time delays are very extensive.

talk.start.para: —Not all the time.
—No, not all the time, but one of the most recent calls I made involved a 20-minute wait. That is no service assistance to the community.

speech.para: One of the things that really troubled me when listening to Senator Payne's answer on behalf of the minister was the use of the word `customer'. Most of us do not think of people as `customers' of government services. People who go to Centrelink or the department of social security or Medibank offices are not customers. They are citizens—they are people of this country. They are not there to buy a service; they are there to access what the public sector in this country provides for its citizens, for its people. I think the use of the word `customer' conveys a whole mentality that is characteristic of this government, and one of the reasons why so many women—another responsibility of Minister Newman—in the last election voted overwhelmingly to support Labor.

I find the mean spiritedness of Minister Newman interesting. On occasions she has told us of the pride that Mr Howard and the coalition government took in their success in 1996 to have so many women come into office. She has certainly not offered the same congratulations to the Labor Party, with so many women who have been successful in coming into the parliament this time around. I have actually congratulated Liberal women in the past on their successes. I would have thought it was befitting of the Minister for the Status of Women to also acknowledge the success of the Labor Party in getting so many excellent women, along with their male colleagues, into parliament this time around. Many of them, of course, are in safe Labor seats and they are here for the long haul—excellent.

Much of what Centrelink is proposing to do with the amalgamation of the service delivery so as to make it customer friendly—building on what the Labor government had instituted and was in the process of implementing—had already started. It is not the policy or the intention that the opposition and I stand here to criticise today; it is about exactly what is happening. This process is fraught with difficulties and, like the Job Network, the minister fails to acknowledge that.

Senator Newman is saying, `If you want to know about Centrelink, I am the minister with portfolio responsibilities in the book, but don't ask me any questions. Centrelink stands by itself; you'll have to ask them direct.' Where does ministerial responsibility for the insufficiencies of this organisation stop? They stop with Minister Newman, who is actually stopping thousands of citizens getting easy and proper access. It stops with the 5,000 people who are going to lose their jobs from Centrelink over the next fews years, as people are going to be encouraged—the `customers'—to find out what their services are from a touch screen. I hope they have had lessons in how to use it. Thousands of people who would rather talk to somebody in the department or in Centrelink to assist will, I think, be disadvantaged.

Minister Newman, who has responsibility for Centrelink, is failing in her service to the citizens. She has failed to come before the parliament to answer questions that relate to the status of women. There are many things that the Howard government has sneered at that Labor introduced. They have decided to cut the funding, and lots of services for women are no longer in existence. The minister does not support the services to assist women that have continued. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I too rise to take part in the debate on the motion that the Senate take note of answers that were given with respect to Centrelink. Just a few moments ago, Senator Crowley disparagingly referred to the use of the word `customers'. I might just mention that, when we came into government, the people who attend these government offices were also referred to as customers.

speech.para: When we came into government, the Howard government was committed to bringing under one roof all those areas that acted independently and were disparate of each other. They were the social security areas—pensions, unemployment, veterans and jobs. And, like everything where there is a radical change, there have been some teething problems. Those teething problems have largely been overcome.

The comprehensive area encompassed by Centrelink includes major regional centres in Western Australia—centres like Kalgoorlie, Geraldton, Carnarvon, Albany, Bunbury and Busselton. It was not practicable for the government to fund offices in separate parts of those particular towns. What the government did, I think, was commendable. This was an integral part of the plan, the mosaic, that the government put together shortly after it came into office. It must have been. It lowered the unemployment rate that had peaked during the horrid 13 years of Labor government from 11.2 per cent to the latest figures that I have seen of just over seven per cent. It lowered interest rates in the same areas with respect to that mosaic that I spoke about from over 20 per cent to ones that are now under six per cent. The ANZ survey of job vacancies—a respected survey; one used by most major and small businesses throughout Australia—indicates that expectations have risen, exports have increased and our system has survived the Asian devastation. Centrelink is an integral and important part of that system.

The Labor Party seems to have a bent that it cannot get away from. It wants to have Australians dependent on them. Centrelink takes away that dependency. This arrangement has increased the possibility and the practicability of assistance by providing a hub that encompasses a whole lot of offices. Centrelink has survived in most, if not all, of the major centres that I mentioned. With the retreat from the rural and coastal areas of Western Australia, all of those offices could not have survived. Some of those offices would have had to close if they had remained in the form they were in prior to the Howard government coming into office. They have been saved from closure.

There seems to be a growing thrust by the Labor Party to ensure that people of Australia remain dependent on government largesse—the government handout; the government trough. Centrelink does not do that. Centrelink takes away that dependency and makes people more independent. It gives them more hope. It is highly successful. The 1800 number does work. The fact that you cannot get through at times is a manifestation of its success. It is so good, it is so busy, that that is a clear manifestation of its success.

It is about time the opposition gave some praise where it is due to this government. The success that it has had in weathering the Asian downturn is something that it deserves credit for. Centrelink is part of the mosaic, part of the major plan that has driven Australia forward, that has improved the areas which needed to be improved and that has taken people away from the dependency that the Labor Party desperately needs to maintain its support. Australia is far better off for it.

talk.start.para: —In taking note of Senator Newman's responses to several questions today I would like to go back to the question that I raised in relation to the Child Support Agency. Senator Newman should not be held trussed by Mr Truss as her junior minister and should deal with this issue. She did provide an answer yesterday but, as we have pointed out in question time today, the official answer coming through her junior minister, or through the senior levels of management in the department, are obviously out of kilter with the reality on the shop floor.

speech.para: Given all of the comments that government members are making about Centrelink, perhaps I should suggest also that the minister spend some time in a Centrelink office and actually experience how it is on the shop floor in those offices where, for instance, agencies have to close down for the day simply to catch up with business. I am somewhat amused by Senator Lightfoot's comment that the 1800 number is working because you cannot get through. That is absolutely astounding as a test of the success of service delivery. I wonder what the bases were of his development of logical reasoning.

But let me go back to the issue of the Child Support Agency. I would like to refer, so that the minister is fully briefed on this matter, to a letter sent to the national program manager of the Child Support Agency from the CPSU in relation to the issue. The union still has had no response to a letter sent on 3 December on this very important issue. In trying to follow through for a response, they have been told that they will eventually get a response on Monday. That is simply not good enough, particularly given the fact that the minister through her junior minister is meant to be inquiring into the matter. The letter says:

The issue of CSA staff identification has been an ongoing one for the union and for the agency management. Concerns have repeatedly been expressed about the potential danger to staff if they are forced to reveal their full names and therefore in most cases give access to their residential address to clients. It is of great concern that with the introduction of the new CSA computer system staff's full names will be automatically printed on letters being sent out.

It is one thing for Senator Payne to be talking about wonderful efficiencies and performances and new models and theories, but again we have to get to the issue of how they are delivered in practice. If the minister spent a bit more time in Centrelink agencies she would see that it is pretty obvious that the differential between models and practice is vast. This is a case of another issue raised. The move to the computer system and automatic correspondence is obviously creating very severe security concerns for staff within the agency and they are not being addressed by senior management. The letter goes further:

I am aware of a staff petition from Box Hill staff signed by 61 staff imploring you to change your approach on this matter and of your response. Given recent events in the ATO, the union again requests that you urgently review your position on this matter. I will be contacting officers and indicating that we wish to discuss this vital issue and that we meet next week. The union will be examining issues such as employers' possible legal liability if changes are not made to the system, including duty of care issues as well as possible breaches of the Occupational Health and Safety Act.
Again, I highlight that this letter has not been responded to. The portfolio minister should now be paying some attention to this matter, rather than referring it back to her junior minister.

Let me deal with some of the other comments made about Centrelink today. Senator Lightfoot's contribution I would characterise as denial and optimism. Denial of any of the problems in Centrelink is a bit like the government's denial of any of the problems in relation to CASA and the civil aviation tests, which have been overturned. It is a bit like the government's denial of any problems with the Job Network, which they should at least be aware by now is publicly seen as laughable. The same denial applies to the problems in Centrelink.

But then, the optimism was fairly extreme as well: `We have survived the Asian devastation.' Has Senator Lightfoot not seen today's unemployment figures? Does he not realise that the bump that we had last month is not characteristic of a trend but that we are back to eight per cent, that there has been a severe decline in full-time and part-time employment? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The performance we have seen today of taking note of answers is nothing more than a renewed attack on one of our ministers. Each day they seem to focus on one. The game is up. The tactics are obvious. I think you need a few fresh minds in your tactics committee. Yesterday we had Senator Kemp. That well and truly flopped over. The one that really flopped over, Senator Carr, was the attack you launched on Senator Macdonald. Today it is Senator Newman, so much so that Senator Mackay came in with a set piece. It wouldn't have mattered how Senator Newman answered the question or what the question was; Senator Mackay came in with a set piece talking about the performance of Senator Newman in relation to the status of women. I don't think Senator Newman even mentioned the status of women issue. She mentioned Centrelink. She mentioned child care. She did not even mention the extra arm of her portfolio in relation to women. Such was the set piece put down by Senator Mackay. It was a blind and unresearched attack.

speech.para: I would like to detail some of that research in regard to Senator Newman. She is the Liberal Party's woman in cabinet. She is the most senior woman we have in government. It is not a token position. I remember only too well when we were in opposition, Senator Carr. How could we forget? We had 13 years in opposition. So there is not much you can tell us about opposition that we do not know. When we were in opposition, there was a certain female politician that was promoted by the Labor Party into cabinet. It was well recognised that that was a token promotion. In fact, a very disgruntled junior minister who thought they should get the position was reportedly going around saying that this promotion was made only because she had the right genes in the right state. Now work that one out!

Few on the frontbench have had to make tougher reforms than Senator Newman when she first took over her portfolio. We are now in our second term of government, and she has held that position in cabinet. Anyone—even you, Senator Carr—who knows politics knows that it is pretty hard to hold a position for two terms in cabinet. To her credit, this is her second term in cabinet. Few on the frontbench have had to make tougher decisions in their portfolios than Senator Newman has in hers. When we came into government, we had a deficit of $10 billion. We had to tackle that. Every portfolio had to deliver savings and cuts. One of the portfolios left with the legacy of disaster was the social welfare portfolio.

Senator Newman tackled her portfolio with sensitivity. She changed the whole philosophy of social welfare in regard to mutual obligation. That is something that Mr Latham would like you to look at: the question of mutual obligation. That is the great philosophy change in social welfare. There is no longer this handout mentality. Senator Newman's greatest achievement has been a saving of $1.4 billion a year in her portfolio—simply by bringing to hand the unchecked fraud that was going on by the previous government and the errors. An auditing process that went right through that portfolio at the time came up with a remarkable saving of $1.4 billion. That is the record of Senator Newman. That has sent a message right throughout society that the days of rorts and the handout mentality of social welfare are gone.

Senator Crowley made some pretty glib remarks about the women supporting the Labor Party in the last election. That is the first time I have seen that statistic put on the table. I do not accept it at all. How could I when your primary vote was as low as it has ever been? You did not advance your vote at all. I am not going to accept that very glib remark by Senator Crowley. The great disappointment that Senator Crowley should have spoken about was the Labor Party's approach towards women in politics. They with great jubilation set down a quota system for I think 30 per cent of women to be in parliament by the year 2000. They are way behind in meeting that quota. In fact, they are not going to, particularly in New South Wales. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —The President has received letters from party leaders nominating senators to be members of committees.

speech.para: Motion (by Senator Heffernan)—by leave—agreed to:
That senators be discharged from and appointed to committees as follows:
Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee
Participating member: Senator Murphy.
Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit
Discharged: Senator Crowley
Appointed: Senator Faulkner.
Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters
Appointed: Senator Murray.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Reported on ABC radio today were comments from Mr Paul Kemp, the Chief Executive Officer of the Trust Bank in Tasmania, saying that statements I had made about him were incorrect and had no basis, and inferring that I may have been drinking when I made them. The facts of the matter are as follows: on 1 October 1991 the Trust Bank, of which Mr Kemp is the chief executive officer, bought a car from Mr Kemp—a Rover Stirling 827 sedan—for the price of $44,000. That car was subsequently sold on 8 October 1993 for $16,000, but at the time the bank purchased the car it had a red book value if in mint condition of some $28,000.

speech.para: As part of my explanation, I seek leave to table some documents. I have shown them to the Chief Government Whip. The document I seek leave to table is a copy of the Trust Bank's asset register, which displays the purchase and the sale of the said car.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —The remarks that I have made about Mr Kemp are not remarks that I have not previously made. Mr Kemp has never denied the fact that a car that belonged to him was purchased by the bank. People in banking have a fiduciary responsibility, and I have questioned the integrity of Mr Kemp. I continue to question the integrity of Mr Kemp because of a number of matters, not the least of which being the selling of a private car he owned into the bank's car pool—something that would not be afforded, and as far as I know has never been afforded, to any other employee of the bank, particularly when the car was purchased by the bank for at least $16,000 more than its market value worth at the time. That raises a serious question of propriety. Moreover, banks have responsibilities in terms of their customers.
—Senator Murphy, I would appreciate it if you could show me where you have been misrepresented and seek to correct that please.
—Mr Kemp has made public statements that what I have said has no basis or foundation. What I am doing here is providing evidence with regard to the basis of the comments I made.
—Keep it tight.

—I have to be able to do that to give basis to the comments attributed to me in the Senate chamber during the adjournment speech when I said that he was a crook and that he sold the car into the bank pool. I am now in the process of giving this explanation and providing evidence as to why I questioned Mr Kemp's integrity and propriety. That is what I seek to do. I have to do it by way of giving explanations of the circumstances in which I made those comments.
—Keep it to the point.

—Yes, I will, Madam Deputy President. I do understand. I do not want to take up the time of the Senate. Bankers are required, in the case of the bank's customers, to conduct themselves in a particular way to ensure that the customers' interests are held uppermost. Mr Kemp's bank repossessed a number of cars. The particular cars in this case were Porsches. There were four of them. The cars in relation to which people defaulted on their loans and which the bank repossessed were supposed to be sold by the bank and, indeed, ultimately were.

speech.para: But one in particular—again, this is part of my explanation in terms of questioning Mr Kemp's integrity—was a 1990 Porsche 944 S2 Cabriolet with which Mr Kemp was photographed in the Examiner in April 1992. Mr Kemp said that the bank entered the car in Targa, a race which is quite well known in Tasmania. He is attributed as saying:
"We are trying to sell this one. It's been on the books for eight months," Mr Kemp said, patting the V8 vehicle's brown bonnet affectionately.
"Meanwhile, I may as well be driving it," said Mr Kemp, admitting that the bank also owns four other Porsches, "all of them for sale if you are interested."

That is right, but the other three had been sold. Indeed, it is my information that this one had been sold, but the person who was selling the cars for the bank had been asked to keep the sale back. That is not the part I wish to come to. What happened was that Mr Kemp smashed this car up, doing $40,000 worth of damage, thus devaluing the car in terms of the resale value it would have in terms of recovering debt for both the bank and in the interests of the customer. That is a clear breach of the banking laws of this country.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think we have been rather tolerant on this side of the house. Senator Murphy asked to make a personal explanation, but we seem to be getting into an adjournment speech now. I am not saying that he should not be able to say what he wants to say, but I think that this is not the right place and time for it. I think an adjournment speech would be much better. Normally personal explanations are usually kept very short and to the point.

—They normally are kept very short and to the point. Senator Murphy, you sought to make a personal explanation because you had been misrepresented. You have given evidence that you have been misrepresented.

—Madam Deputy President, I do respect the time of the Senate, but some of these things are not easy to address. I would have endeavoured to put this on the public record by way of an adjournment speech but, because we are at the end of a sitting period, it is likely that there will be no time for adjournment speeches before we rise at the end of this sitting period. So I have to take the opportunity to rectify this as quickly as I can. Primarily, those are the two issues I wanted to raise.

speech.para: I will not continue further. There are a number of other issues which I think should be put on the public record, and I will put them on the public record in due course. I thank the government for giving me leave to make a brief personal explanation. I have put on the public record one of the most important aspects, but certainly not the least important. I thank the Senate for its time.

interjection.para: PRESIDENT'S REPORT TO THE SENATE ON GOVERNMENT RESPONSES OUTSTANDING TO PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE REPORTS AS AT 10 DECEMBER 1998

para.inline: PREFACE

interjection.para: This document continues the practice of presenting to the Senate twice each year a list of Government responses to Senate and joint committee reports as well as responses which remain outstanding.

The practice of presenting this list to the Senate follows the resolution of the Senate of 14 March 1973 and the undertaking by successive governments to respond to parliamentary committee reports in timely fashion. On 26 May 1978 the then Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Withers) informed the Senate that within six months of the tabling of a committee report, the responsible Minister would make a statement in the Parliament outlining the action the Government proposed to take in relation to the report. The period for responses was reduced from six months to three months in 1983 by the then incoming government. The then Leader of the Government in the Senate announced this change on 24 August 1983. The method of response continued to be by way of statement. Subsequently, on 16 October 1991 the former Government advised that responses to committee reports would be made by letter to a committee chairman, with the letter being tabled in the Senate at the earliest opportunity. The current Government in June 1996 affirmed its commitment to respond to relevant parliamentary committee reports within three months of their presentation.

The list does not usually include reports of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works or the following Senate Standing Committees: Appropriations and Staffing, Selection of Bills, Privileges, Procedure, Publications, Regulations and Ordinances and Scrutiny of Bills. However, such reports will be included if they require a response. Government responses to reports of the Public Works Committee are normally reflected in motions for the approval of works after the relevant report has been presented and considered. Responses to reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts are usually made in the form of Finance Minutes which are tabled by the committee. Where a response has been made by way of Finance Minute, the date of presentation has been appropriately annotated.

Legislation committees report on bills and on the provisions of bills. Only those reports in this category that make recommendations which cannot readily be implemented through the bill, and therefore require a response, are listed. The list also does not include reports by legislation committees on estimates.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment No. 1:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, items 1 and 2, page 3 (line 5) to page 4 (line 23), omit the items, substitute:

para.inline: 1 After section 18B

speech.para: Insert:

para.inline: 18C The Prime Minister or Cabinet may authorise a non-portfolio Minister or a member of the Executive Council who is not a Minister to act on his or her behalf in the performance of statutory functions or the exercise of statutory powers

speech.para: (1) The Prime Minister or Cabinet may during the temporary absence or incapacity of a Minister (the portfolio Minister ) who administers (whether alone or jointly with one or more other Ministers) an Act or a provision of an Act authorise:
(a) a Minister who does not administer the Act or provision; or
(b) a member of the Executive Council who is not a Minister;
to act on behalf of the portfolio Minister in the performance of functions, or the exercise of powers, that the portfolio Minister may perform or exercise under the Act or provision.
(2) A portfolio Minister with overall responsibility for the portfolio (the senior portfolio Minister ) may authorise:
(a) a Minister who is responsible for certain matters within that portfolio (the junior portfolio Minister ); or
(b) a member of the Executive Council who is not a Minister and who is responsible for certain matters within that portfolio;

to act on behalf of the senior portfolio Minister in the performance of functions, or the exercise of powers, that the senior portfolio Minister may perform or exercise under an Act or a provision of an Act.

(3) An authorisation under subsection (1) or (2) in relation to an Act or a provision of an Act extends to the performance of functions, or the exercise of powers, that the portfolio Minister or senior portfolio Minister may perform or exercise under an instrument (including a regulation, rule or Proclamation) having effect under or for the purposes of the Act or provision.
(4) Subject to subsections (5) and (6), an authorisation under subsection (1) or (2) may be expressed:
(a) to have effect only during a period or periods, or during the existence of a circumstance or circumstances, referred to in the authorisation; or

(b) to take effect immediately, or at a time referred to in the authorisation, and afterwards to continue to have effect until another person is appointed to the office held by the authorising Minister.
(5) Despite subsection (4), an authorisation under subsection (1) may be revoked at any time by the Prime Minister or Cabinet.
(6) Despite subsection (4), an authorisation under subsection (2) may be revoked at any time by the senior portfolio Minister.
(7) An authorisation under subsection (1) or (2) given to a Minister or member of the Executive Council, and the revocation of such an authorisation, must be in writing.

(8) This section does not affect the giving, under a power existing apart from this section, of an authorisation to a Minister or other member of the Executive Council to act on behalf of another Minister.

(9) Either the portfolio Minister or the senior portfolio Minister, or the Minister or member of the Executive Council who acted on behalf of the portfolio Minister or the senior portfolio Minister, as the case may be, may be named as respondent in any proceeding to review the decision.
(10) In this section:
Cabinet refers to the group of Ministers who are designated as Cabinet Ministers in details of the Ministry issued by the Prime Minister.
function includes duty.

para.inline: Validation of past authorisations

speech.para: (1) Any authorisation that a Minister (the authorising Minister ) purported to give before the commencement of item 1 to another Minister or member of the Executive Council to act on behalf of the authorising Minister in the performance of functions, or the exercise of powers, that the authorising Minister was empowered to perform or exercise under an Act or a provision of an Act is taken to have been, at all times before that commencement when the authorisation purported to be in force, as valid as it would have been if that authorisation had been made by the Prime Minister or Cabinet in accordance with item 1 and the section inserted by that item had been in force when the purported authorisation was given.

(2) If an authorisation that a Minister (the authorising Minister ) purported to give before the commencement of item 1 to another Minister or member of the Executive Council to act on behalf of the authorising Minister in the performance of functions, or the exercise of powers, that the authorising Minister was empowered to perform or exercise under an Act or a provision of an Act purported to be in force immediately before that commencement, the purported authorisation has the effect after that commencement that it would have if that authorisation had been made by the Prime Minister or Cabinet in accordance with item 1 and the section inserted by that item had been in force when the purported authorisation was given.

As I indicated in the second reading debate, the opposition's concern is that the government goes too far in what it is attempting to do here. We understand that there is a problem. We understand that the government wants flexibility, but we think the government goes too far and, in doing so, in some ways may give authority for ministers to in fact override laws passed by this parliament.

Our concern is that ministers should not be able to delegate or authorise outside of their portfolio areas. That should be a responsibility of the Prime Minister or cabinet. We think that should be so for good policy and administrative reasons. There needs to be certainty. Individuals need to know who is taking decisions as to their existence, their businesses and so on. The current government proposal does not do that.

We are also concerned to keep in mind the words of His Honour when he tackled the case of Foster v. Attorney-General. In the judgment, as I cited earlier, Justice Spender made mention of the separation of powers under the Westminster system. Our amendment would offer protection against impingement on such separation of powers. I indicated before lunch that we would move this amendment. The Democrats indicated they would not support it. As a consequence, I will not be putting it to a vote.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the amendment moved by the opposition. As Senator Bolkus has indicated, the Democrats will not be supporting the amendment in its current form. Clause 18C makes provision for the Prime Minister or cabinet to authorise a non-portfolio minister or a member of the Executive Council who is not a minister to act for or on behalf of the portfolio holder. Although the Democrats have some reservations about the way this amendment operates in that it may not achieve its intended purpose, we are certainly quite glad that it is being proposed as a matter of discussion and debate.

speech.para: The Acts Interpretation Act was assented to on 12 July 1901 as the second act in the new Australian Federation. Since then, the sections covered by the government's bill have been amended a number of times to deal with changes in the way government operates. The idea supporting interpretation legislation has been a significant reduction in the amount of legislation because commonly used words and phrases can be relied upon. This was evident from a number of submissions to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report entitled Clearer Commonwealth law in September 1993. That report recommended the Attorney-General's Department and the Office of Parliamentary Counsel publicly review and rewrite the Acts Interpretation Act.

As I have set out before, the Democrats are keen to see this process advanced and encourage the government to rewrite this important act to reflect modern day times and needs and responsibilities. However, we also want to see that review and rewrite go further than just the interpretation measures. We want to see the Acts Interpretation Act deal with the institution of government and the way the executive organises itself and distributes the powers granted to government by our laws. We acknowledge the importance of the Acts Interpretation Act, and we want to ensure its continuing relevance and to promote legislative clarity so that those relying on legislation can know and understand what our parliament does and how laws are to take effect. More importantly, we want to make sure those challenging governments or who are subjected to the action of a government can ensure our laws are properly and appropriately administered.

The constitution makes provision for ministers and the federal Executive Council, but it does not distinguish between senior ministers, junior ministers and parliamentary secretaries. The Labor amendment, in many ways, is a welcome recognition of the central place of cabinet in the Australian government as well as these additional roles which reflect the changing way that government is administered. This recognition is now probably as important as ever before. This is because the changes to mega departments by the previous government, as I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate, have been carried on by this government. It is also important to realise the increasing scope of government in Australia.

The constitution makes provision for only seven ministers. At the time the Acts Interpretation Act was assented there were 10 ministers. In 1998 there are some 30 ministers. Perhaps more interesting is the rise of parliamentary secretaries. They first appeared in the Lyons ministry in 1938, with parliamentary secretaries for defence and Treasury. Since then, they have existed in a number of government departments. In 1980 they became statutory office holders, and from 1990 they have become members of the Executive Council.

The Democrats are keen to see a reflection of these changes in the Acts Interpretation Act. We welcome the Labor Party's recognition of these issues and their attempts to put them into effect. Unfortunately, we have some concerns about how these amendments have proposed to achieve their goal. We are of the view that they do not cover satisfactorily the complex issues. However, I understand we have a common interest in reviewing the Acts Interpretation Act to deal with this and related issues. I look forward to hearing the result of this reform process.

The Democrats will not be supporting the amendment in its present form with an understanding from the government that the Acts Interpretation Act is under review and that that review will be completed soon, we hope. We would expect to see the outcome of this review, as I stated in my speech in the second reading debate, in legislation before the parliament, addressing, in particular, the entire issue of the distribution of powers between the Executive Council and others. The Labor Party have flagged their support for this proposition, and I look forward to the government making the same commitment.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Stott Despoja for indicating the support of the Democrats for the Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill 1998 . I freely acknowledge that there are wider issues to be canvassed under the review, and I expect the Democrats and others will want to make submissions to that review of the Acts Interpretation Act, but their approach is a sensible approach to a potential problem we face. It has been well canvassed in the speeches in the second reading debate that a Federal Court judge has drawn an unexpected interpretation of the Acts Interpretation Act which has put a number of decisions at risk across a number of portfolios. That matter is under appeal, but the judgment has not yet been handed down. In the meantime, there is an absolute need to protect those decisions that have been made, obviously for the longer term, irrespective of the decision to deal with this matter.

speech.para: I thank the Democrats for their support and confirm our commitment to the proper review of the Acts Interpretation Act that is already under way. I thank the opposition for their interest, in the sense of coming up with alternative amendments, but simply indicate, for reasons I think that are obvious, that they are not satisfactory.
Amendment not agreed to.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
