cognateinfo.title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1998
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 8 December, on motion by Senator Minchin:
That the bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Lees had moved by way of an amendment:
Omit all words after "That", substitute:
"the Senate:

(a) notes the evidence provided to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee that the rebate scheme will not take the pressure off public hospitals and is an inefficient and inequitable use of public funds; and
(b) resolves that the bill not be read a second time; and
(c) calls on the Government to:
(i) introduce a means test to restrict eligibility for the rebate to hospital insurance for people on low incomes;
(ii) implement a review process to evaluate the rebate scheme against defined outcome measures;
(iii) require health insurance funds to achieve improved performance outcomes; and

(iv) address the key areas of need in the public health sector, including coordinated care for older Australians; waiting lists in public hospitals; public dental health services; rural health services; and the health care needs of indigenous Australians."

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1998 , the Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 1998 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Private Health Insurance) Bill 1998 . I indicate on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, the opposition in the Senate, that we support Senator Lees's second reading amendment to the private health insurance bills. That amendment provides:

speech.para: "the Senate:

(a) notes the evidence provided to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee that the rebate scheme will not take the pressure off public hospitals and is an inefficient and inequitable use of public funds; and
(b) resolves that the bill not be read a second time; and
(c) calls on the Government to:
(i) introduce a means test to restrict eligibility for the rebate to hospital insurance for people on low incomes;
(ii) implement a review process to evaluate the rebate scheme against defined outcome measures;
(iii) require health insurance funds to achieve improved performance outcomes; and

(iv) address the key areas of need in the public health sector, including coordinated care for older Australians; waiting lists in public hospitals; public dental health services; rural health services; and the health care needs of indigenous Australians."

These measures highlight the concerns that have been expressed about the inadequacies of this bill. We think the amendment ought to be supported by the Senate. The problems with the proposed bills have been widely canvassed in the second reading debate. It is clear that this is bad public policy. It will not relieve the pressure on the public hospital system. Most of the funds will be directed to those on high incomes who are already in private health insurance. A myth has been perpetrated by the government in this debate that somehow this measure is about assisting, via the rebate, low and middle income families who are battling to meet their insurance costs. The reality is that they will have a very small increase in the rebate that is available currently under the old scheme. Most of the money in this proposal goes to high income earners. Those earning over $70,000 a year are the ones that benefit most. The majority of the funds go to them.

We think that is inequitable. There are major problems in our public hospitals system and this sort of money would go a long way to addressing them. It would not only address those problems but mean that 100 per cent of the Australian population would have the benefit of those funds; that 100 per cent of the population could access good quality public hospital care, rather than just supporting the 30 per cent who are in private health insurance, as is proposed by the government.

It also does not solve the problems with the industry. The gap payments, the out-of-pocket expenses, are so high that a lot of people just cannot afford to use their insurance, even if they have it. That is a real problem in the industry. It is a problem that is not addressed in the bills. It means that this rebate will just get eaten up without solving the very real problems that exist in the health industry.

The other major problem it does not address is rising premiums. People in private health insurance know that their premiums have gone up 16 to 20 per cent in the last two years each year. That means that at this rate any benefit they get out of this measure proposed by the government would get eaten away in higher premiums within a couple of years. People will be no better off.

The measure is also highly inequitable, as I said. About $900 million of the additional $1.4 billion will go to families that already have insurance who are on high incomes. We are throwing money at the well-off in the community while denying funding for services, such as emergency dental care, for those who cannot afford to get treatment otherwise. It is just a wrong set of priorities by the government. They are throwing money at a scheme with no real idea what it will do to the industry and with no real idea whether it will halt the slide.

The government claimed the last scheme would halt the slide in private health insurance participation, and it did not. They have no statistical or economic modelling to suggest that this will be any more successful, but they will have wasted $1.7 billion of taxpayers' money by throwing it at the problem, not knowing whether it is going to work or not. They got it wrong last time and I suspect they will get it wrong this time.

The proposed amendment by the Democrats seeks to ensure that the pressure on the public hospital system is relieved, that the Dental Health Scheme is reintroduced and that the health needs of indigenous Australians and those in rural areas are addressed. It would ensure that the rebate would be means tested to ensure that it is targeted at middle and low income earners, at the people who need the help to pay the premium, not at John Howard, who does not need the help.

John Howard and people like him will benefit most from this measure. We will basically pay their private health insurance as a result of this measure. That is not what the health needs of this country are. That is not the priority. John Howard and other ministers in this government do not need help to pay their premiums, but people do need to get access to public hospitals and they do need to get off waiting lists to have operations performed when they are in pain. There is a whole range of health needs that are a far more urgent priority for this parliament than subsidising wealthy people to have health insurance.

We are not opposing support for those who need it, but we are opposing providing support for those who do not. As I say, there are some very good things in the Democrats' second reading amendment. It provides a much better direction for public policy in this area and the opposition will be supporting it.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Tambling) proposed:
That the resumption of the debate be an order of the day for a later hour.

talk.start.para: —As the government has been pressuring us to bring on this debate for weeks and has been saying how important it was we get on with it, I think it is only reasonable that this chamber have an explanation as to why the government is not ready to proceed. I hope that we would be able to resume the debate as soon as possible, but at this stage it is in order to accommodate Senator Harradine.

cognateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (LICENCE CHARGES) BILL 1998
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998
Consideration resumed.

talk.start.para: —The committee is considering the Australian Radiation Protec tion and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 as amended. The question is that clauses 7 and 8 stand as printed. (Quorum formed)

—I wanted to check with the minister—I did ask a question, but I did not get a response from him—whether ASIO officer operatives would potentially be exposed to almost unlimited levels of radiation in the course of their job as a result of this legislation. It seems to me that there is the ability for entire health and safety issues for particular categories of people, such as those people working for ASIO, to be isolated in this legislation.
—These issues had been addressed prior to lunch in the answers I gave at that point in regard to the role of the Director-General and the objectives of the act.

—I understand that the government argues that this amendment is impossible to support because defence and national security will in some way be prejudiced. The Democrats have always been fairly sceptical about the defence and national security requirements every time we happen to deal with something that involves radioactivity.

speech.para: I understand that the Minister for Foreign Affairs met yesterday with a group to discuss nuclear weaponry. By all reports, he was disappointed that they failed to appreciate how much good he is doing to prevent the defence uses of nuclear weapons. Recent surveys highlight the very clear difference between public sentiment about nuclear weapons and the activities of governments all around the world, but particularly the nuclear weapons nations. We believe the Australian government is out of step with the community here. Despite the good intentions of the foreign minister, we do not believe that he is doing enough or that he is necessarily going far enough.

It was significant that the group who met with the foreign minister pointed out last night on the radio the failings of the BJP government in India to focus on the nuclear detonations as a success of their office. This is significant, because we have been led to believe that there was great community support for those detonations and for the escalation of nuclear weaponry in India and in Pakistan. Clearly, the community does not necessarily share the same level of joy or have the same agenda as their government's. This was also obvious in the Rajasthan elections where the chief minister campaigned on the bomb, only to be ousted because the community was more interested in social problems such as whether or not there was enough food.

I suggest that the same thing is likely to happen in a nation like ours. It is probably time for our government to take a lead and do something to force the nuclear weapon states to get rid of their nuclear weapons.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!
—Thank you, Senator Margetts. It is good to see the Greens support this notion. We certainly support your amendment, Senator Margetts.

speech.para: This brings me back to the reliance on the defence and national security clauses in this bill. There is no place for these provisions in this bill, because the community does not want them there. Both subclauses 7(1) and 8 (1) are so broad that their application is uncertain. It is quite nebulous as a result. They effectively apply to anything that may affect Australia's defence or national security. What this means is pretty unclear.

Add to this the obvious public disenchantment with the use of nuclear material in defence and national security, and we cannot support these incredibly broad provisions. If the government want to do this, then they should at least define what they mean and set this out in other legislation. We believe everyone in Australia should comply with the same standards, and exceptions need to be clearly identified and defined.

talk.start.para: —The comments of both Senator Margetts and Senator Stott Despoja have been noted and will be passed to the relevant ministers. As I said earlier, the role of the Director-General is one that must take account of the objectives of the legislation.

—You will remember that before lunch I raised the matter, because it is pertinent here, of the Director of Safeguards report for this year through Foreign Affairs and Trade. The report points out that there is research and development being undertaken at Lucas Heights into the uranium enrichment process under the auspices of Silex Systems Pty Ltd, which has now combined with a United States company and a South African nuclear corporation. I asked the minister what he could tell the committee about this matter as I had raised it before in the chamber. I particularly drew his attention to the following comment on page 31 of the report to his government:

speech.para: If this technology—
which is being developed in Lucas Heights—
is classified as "associated technology", then any transfer to the US for further development will require an amendment to the existing Australia/US nuclear cooperation agreement, or a new agreement.

I asked whether that was so. I also asked whether, in order to accommodate this research into uranium enrichment, the government is moving to throw out, dismantle or change the nuclear cooperation agreement with the United States and, if so, why.

talk.start.para: —I will address the specific issue put by Senator Brown but, before doing so, can I have the indulgence of the committee for a moment to comment on some related matters that he raised in the debate yesterday about mining at both Kakadu and Pine Creek. I advise Senator Brown that his concerns on both these matters have been passed on to the relevant minister. With regard to Kakadu, oral advice has been received from the Office of the Supervising Scientist that the recent weather conditions in the Northern Territory have not caused any environmental problems at Ranger.

speech.para: The senator would, of course, be familiar with the very satisfactory record of the Rang er mine in that area over 18 years. I do not have particular information on the issue regarding Pine Creek. However, I assure the senator that it has been passed to a number of both Commonwealth and Northern Territory ministers for their early attention. As soon as I have any information on it, I will make it available to Senator Brown.

With regard to Silex and the laser issues, I am advised that the Silex project is a private sector project researching a possible method of enriching uranium for use in power reactors. This research is still at an early stage and it is not yet established that the Silex process will be effective in enriching uranium. The Silex company has a contract with the United States Enrichment Corporation for the commercial development of the process in the US if the research is successful.

It is too early to say whether the Silex process is of possible proliferation significance. However, security measures have been put in place to ensure that the technology is protected against unauthorised access. The Australian Safeguards and Non-proliferation Office is monitoring the process of the project to ensure that appropriate security is maintained.

Australian and US officials have been discussing a new agreement to ensure that if the technology is transferred to the US it will be used for exclusively peaceful purposes under international atomic energy safeguards. There is nothing inconsistent with Australia's non-proliferation commitments in undertaking this research. On the contrary, this enhances Australia's capacity to evaluate nuclear developments in other countries and to contribute to the development of effective non-proliferation controls. Examples are international safeguards and controls on the export of relevant technology. For these reasons, the research was authorised by the previous government.

The project does not represent any risk to the environment or public safety. It is extremely small scale. Silex is authorised to process no more than one kilogram of uranium. In practice, much less than this is being used in the process. Information on the project and safeguard arrangements applying to it is given in the annual report of the Director of Safeguards, the head of ANSO.

I trust that that provides Senator Brown with information. I ask him to address any other questions that he may have specifically to this legislation, which we are keen to process in a reasonably ordered timetable today.

talk.start.para: —I assure the parliamentary secretary that I will not take much longer. I recognise that he had a written response. I wonder whether I could have a copy of it.
—Yes.

—I thank the minister for agreeing to that. I recognise that the parliamentary secretary may not be able to answer these questions. If he cannot, I would again be happy to receive a later reply. Specifically, what in the Australia-US nuclear cooperation agreement would need to be changed to accommodate this research into uranium enrichment and, I am told, potential plutonium enrichment at Lucas Heights? Will there be a transfer to the US for the further use and development of this technology? Why is the research not being done in the US?

speech.para: When the minister says that special safeguards are being put in place to make this research safe, what exactly are those safeguards? In what way are they being implemented? Finally, is there any other known case of research of this variety which has the potential to enhance the production of nuclear weapons occurring at Lucas Heights or anywhere else in Australia? Can the government be more specific in saying what it means by it not being known whether this has the potential for nuclear weapons development when prima facie it does?

talk.start.para: —I will take those questions on notice and provide a detailed response to Senator Brown. I also take this opportunity to offer to him the availability of a comprehensive briefing on this by the safeguards office and other government officers, if necessary.
—I thank the parliamentary secretary for that. I accept the offer. I am very keen to follow up this matter.
—The question is that clauses 7 and 8 stand as printed.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—In the interests of progressing the debate, I ask that the opposition of the Greens (WA) and of Senator Brown to this motion be noted.
—by leave—I ask that the opposition of the Australian Democrats to this motion also be noted.
—by leave—I move Government amendments Nos 2 to 10:

speech.para: (2) Clause 14, page 10 (after line 21), after paragraph (e), insert:
(ea) to monitor the operations of ARPANSA, the Council, the Radiation Health Committee and the Nuclear Safety Committee;
(eb) to report on the operations of ARPANSA, the Council, the Radiation Health Committee and the Nuclear Safety Committee.

(7) Clause 32, page 19 (line 19), at the end of subclause (3), add ", and must also take into account international best practice in relation to radiation protection and nuclear safety".
(8) Clause 40, page 23 (after line 16), after subclause (3), insert:
(3A) As soon as possible after giving directions under subsection (2), the CEO must provide a copy of the directions to the Minister.
(3B) The Minister must cause a copy of the directions to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the directions have been given.
