hospital treatment has the meaning given by section 3 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 .
(4) Clause 20-5, page 45 (after line 25), after the definition of incentive payments scheme , insert:

known gap policy means a private health insurance policy that covers all but a specified amount or percentage of the full cost of hospital treatment and associated professional attention for the person or persons insured.
(5) Clause 20-5, page 45 (after line 28), after the definition of Managing Director , insert:
no gap policy means a private health insurance policy that covers the full cost of hospital treatment and associated professional attention for the person or persons insured.
(6) Clause 20-5, page 47 (after line 4), after the definition of private health insurance policy , insert:
professional attention has the meaning given by section 3 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 .

The legislation before the parliament provides for certain access options to the 30 per cent rebate from 1 January 1999. It provides for access reductions of private health insurance premiums—namely, 30 per cent received by either of three areas: a reduction of private health insurance premiums, a tax rebate or a cash rebate from a government office, presumably the Medicare office. That is precisely what it is in the legislation at the moment.

The rebate could be used to put pressure on funds in negotiation with the medical profession to offer no gap or known gap policies to health fund members. National Mutual already offers such policies to its members in South Australia and in Victoria, and some 30 to 40 per cent of insured South Australian residents have such policies. Under simplified billing arrangements, there are now over 25 simplified billing agents across the country, and many of these also offer known or no gap arrangements for privately insured patients using both public and private hospitals.

These policies require negotiation between funds, hospitals and procedural specialists. Now over 5.7 per cent of all claims are going through simplified billing agencies. National Mutual has processed over 200,000 claims on its own. This amendment attempts to build on this achievement, and that is exactly what this incentive scheme should be doing. I have argued all along that the 30 per cent rebate should deal with the gaps issue. This has been a critical question in my mind in coming to the conclusion that I have come to within the last few hours: that is, to support this measure.

There were other factors which influenced my considerations thereon, but the issue of the gap is one which we have to deal with sooner or later, and the sooner the better. What these amendments do is deal with funds that do not offer these options to their members. These funds would no longer be permitted to offer the 30 per cent rebate as a premium reduction. In other words, any fund that does not offer to its members a no gap or known gap policy would not be able to offer the 30 per cent rebate as a premium reduction.

Therefore, the members could only access the rebate as a tax or cash rebate. Many who would be aware of this would move to other funds that did meet the target and therefore could offer the 30 per cent premium reduction. The government cannot provide the committee with modelling to see how this would finally pan out, but anybody with any commonsense would realise that, in a competitive field such as private health insurance, the funds that could offer the no gap or known gap policies and therefore the 30 per cent rebate as a premium reduction would be at a considerable advantage in the marketplace as against those funds which would be unable to do that.

Those funds which would not offer that sort of policy would not be able to advertise or offer a cheaper premium based on the 30 per cent reduction in premium costs. Of course, the membership would be attracted to those that could. Clearly, it would provide an incentive to insurance companies to enter into agreements with private hospitals and with doctors, particularly specialists, so that they could offer the no gap or known gap policies. This is an advantage which should be considered by the committee as a step in the right direction to try to grapple with this vexed question of the gap.

I remind the committee that the thing that concerns members most is the cost of premiums, but this question of the gap is a matter that comes forward time and time again. People are complaining to us as members of parliament about it. You hear around the place in general conversation, `Yes, I had to go to the hospital. I was on top cover and thought I would be covered and now I'm receiving bill after bill after bill,' and those bills represent the amounts which were not picked up by Medicare or the fund and the person has to pay up out of their own pocket.

This is an attempt to overcome that situation. I appreciate that the funds would need a little time to ensure that this is worked out and to undertake the necessary negotiations with the private hospitals and with the medical profession. If the medical profession does not accept and cooperate and if they then do not themselves bring down their fees, then they are likely to face a real problem. If they do not do that, the whole private health system will be under so much pressure that it is likely to collapse. I therefore submit these amendments to the committee in the hope that, though they are not the optimum, they are at least achievable with goodwill on all sides.

talk.start.para: —That's what's needed.

—Yes, I agree, Senator Lees. I would like to take this opportunity to acknowledge the work you have done in the committee work and other areas. But at least these amendments are trying to address the problem. It might be argued that the doctors will just grasp this and say, `Oh, well, the funds will be responsible to pick up our tab, so we don't mind if we raise the fees. At least we won't have to send the bills to the patients. The health funds will have to pick up the tab.'

speech.para: Those that do that I think would be seen as traitors to the private health system by their colleagues. There will be, I believe, a considerable incentive on the part of funds to ensure that costs are kept down, because if they are not then the members have to pay increased premiums. If the members have to pay increased premiums, that is the primary concern of members. That will lead to the destruction of the private health insurance funds and, ultimately, to the private system itself. Those doctors surely would be regarded as traitors to that particular cause.

I submit this as workable and also constitutional. There are other ways to try to pull the doctors, the medical profession, into line. That has been tried in a number of fields. Much of the work therein was useless because it was considered to be unconstitutional. This is not an unconstitutional provision. I urge the Committee to at least accept this as a start.

talk.start.para: —Firstly, I say to Senator Harradine that I am pleased to see we have a step in the right direction. Just on that basis we would support it. However, unfortunately I see within this many problems—first of all, the way in which this amendment is worded. It says:

speech.para: . . . unless the health fund provides its members with the choice of one or more of the following types of policies:
I think virtually every health insurance company already fulfils this, and I would like to ask the parliamentary secretary if that is not indeed true.

My preferred option would have been that the 30 per cent rebate could only be available on policies where there was going to be no gap—in other words, if we could really have driven down the cost of those policies that really did offer everything. Looking at my home state, I congratulate the largest fund there. It has managed to do that, and a lot of people are now using that option. But my worry is that, given that in each state, except one state, there is a dominant insurer, the no-gap policy could indeed end up costing $6,000 and the premiums for ordinary existing policies for everyday hospital cover, which the minister has the final say in, would manage to stay down because the gaps will still be there. Those full hospital policies are the ones where you often get surgical and other gaps added on at the end, whereas with some policies there are absolutely no gaps.

I ask the parliamentary secretary: is it not the case already that most funds do provide the no-gap policy? In relation to the known gap, I ask the parliamentary secretary a second question: is it not the case already, and it is has been proven at law, that if a person wants to pursue a bill that they had no prior knowledge of they do not have to pay it anyway?

talk.start.para: —I would like to respond to the comments of both Senator Harradine and Senator Lees. The government supports Senator Harradine's important amendment, as it goes a long way to supporting initiatives the government is already pursuing to address the issues of the gap. In fact, the Howard government has done more to reduce the incidence of the medical gap fees than the previous government. In the last 18 months we have seen major successes which would have been unimaginable only three years ago. HIC statistics show that an increasing number of in-hospital medical claims are being processed through agreements with health funds and through simpli fied billing agents, many of which have eliminated gaps or shown known out-of-pockets.

speech.para: I draw attention to this whole issue of the success that we have had in Victoria and South Australia with a number of admissions to hospitals with a no-gaps basis rising exponentially. We have a real prospect of making major changes nationally within the next 18 months. Certainly, in the calendar year 1998, we have gone from no no-gaps product existing in the country to no-gaps products being common place in two states and in early stages of start-up in others.

I know that Dr Wooldridge has talked at length about how we can hasten this. He, of course, has referred to the areas where we will be providing money for computer software development, which is one of the limiting factors, to changing the reinsurance pool to provide greater incentives for funds to offer no-gap products. Within the last week, Dr Wooldridge has brought Medibank Private to his office and instructed work in this area as a matter of urgency.

You will recall that the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1998 has just passed through the House of Representatives, and it has a number of measures to help costs, such as attempting to create a wholesale market in private health insurance and removing incentives for in-hospital treatment when a procedure could be done in rooms or as day surgery. Certainly much more needs to be done. Senator Harradine's amendment will help immeasurably in this regard, and we acknowledge its important contribution to this part of the legislation.

Senator Lees asked about the issue of existing policies. I am informed that current covers are only in the area that relates to hospital costs and cover such issues as accommodation, whereas the extension of what is now envisaged in Senator Harradine's amendment picks up new and innovative products that will be available and will move into the wider areas of medical assessment and medical need. We are certainly pleased to support Senator Harradine's amendment.

talk.start.para: —I will start by congratulating Senator Harradine. I thought his second reading contribution was cogent, reasoned and convincing. I am sure anyone listening would have been convinced—if they had not been convinced when they heard the debate earlier—to vote down the bill. Unfortunately, he then reached a different conclusion to the one the whole logic and force of his argument had taken him to. I do not quite understand why, but I accept that he did.

speech.para: What we have here is, it seems, a result of some discussions between the government and Senator Harradine this afternoon. The parliamentary secretary has indicated that the government is responding to what I think he described as `Senator Harradine's initiatives'. I suppose that goes to confirm the letter that I was given recently which purports to be from the Prime Minister to Senator Harradine confirming arrangements that they have reached between them regarding health insurance. I want to ask a couple of questions about those matters shortly.

This amendment is a very meagre step in the right direction. And, given all the criticisms that Senator Harradine and others made which highlighted that the bill did not tackle the real issues of private health insurance, this amendment did not tackle the funding of health care in this country. This amendment is a very unsatisfactory sole sign of moving to deal with one of those problems. What we are doing here is providing a $1.7 billion blank cheque and saying, `In addition to that, we might have this small amendment moved, and carried by the government, that would provide some signal that there would be some serious attempt to deal with the problem of the gap.'

I agree with Senator Harradine that the gap is one of the major issues. I think all minor party and Labor senators have stressed that this does nothing for that major issue, that we are throwing good money after bad without any of the reciprocal obligation that the government demands of social security recipients or unemployed persons in this country. In return for $300 a week of pension, all sorts of reciprocal and mutual obligations are demanded. But in return for $1.7 billion we demand nothing. We say, `Take the money and we will have a look at some of the other problems down the track.'

Quite frankly, if Dr Wooldridge was in business, he would go broke very quickly. You never give them the money before you get the service. You certainly do not give them the money before you get some sort of sign of their commitment to provide some service in return. What we have done is provided an underwriting of 30 per cent of whatever the private health insurance funds choose to charge over the next however many years. They can increase premiums, knowing that we will always pay 30 per cent of the bill. I think that is an outrage in terms of public policy. While this amendment has some worthy objectives, it takes us no real way towards meeting our obligation to deal with the real problems or ensuring that we get a proper response from the health insurance industry.

Senator Harradine referred to the problem of modelling and costing that we found with the government's proposals, and I think he indicated that he had similar difficulties in costing this proposal. I think it is important that he or the parliamentary secretary provide some explanation, because the evidence given to the Senate committee of inquiry into this matter indicated that the cost of providing gap insurance would actually increase premiums by some 7½ per cent. I am not sure what the government and Senator Harradine are saying about this measure but, on the evidence of the private hospital industry, gap insurance would increase the total cost of premiums by 7½ per cent. Is that right? Is that the estimate of the cost of this measure—an increase in premiums of 7½ per cent? Is that the government's estimate as well?

And, will we be subsidising 30 per cent of that increase in cost? Is there any limit on the charges that can be applied to gap insurance? Surely it is going to be quite an expensive product, by anybody's reckoning. I would be interested to know what sort of restrictions or flexibility apply in that regard. Will any measures be taken to cap the cost of gap fees? I understood that Mr Chalmers of the private industry stated in his evidence at the committee hearing that there are no mechanisms by which gaps can be quantified or capped. It is unclear to me how this measure is to work, how it is to be funded, or what the government estimates the cost of the measure to be. Obviously, some answers to those questions would assist the committee greatly.

talk.start.para: —There are several issues that arise. I am surprised at Senator Evans's cynicism with regard to the bona fides of this particular amendment and the advantages that it certainly will bring. Whilst everyone has acknowledged the role that Senator Harradine has been able to play in brokering this important issue, I am sure there are many other parties whose willingness to reach real solutions should be acknowledged, such as the Australian Private Hospitals Association, the AMA and, in particular, the chairman, Dr Brand—I hope that he will not be undermined by people within his own area that have perhaps a different view to the executive of the AMA; we have certainly been cooperative and willing to pursue this matter very carefully and very properly—and, of course, the Private Health Insurance Association, which naturally has vested interests.

speech.para: I think the leadership and the cooperation of those people need to be particularly commended. I believe that the challenge of this particular amendment will impose disciplines and special requirements on each of those areas. The doctors themselves, we acknowledge, will have an important role to play in the partnership, as will the hospitals and the various insurance companies.

Senator Evans asked a question with regard to intended premium rises. I am informed that it has been generally indicated that increases in premiums would certainly be much lower than any figures you have used—the seven per cent or so.

talk.start.para: —No, as a result of this measure.

—I am sure as a result of this measure that increases would be lower—and also that they would not necessarily be implemented in the normal program of dates, which I think was intended to be about March. It will probably be later. Any deferment in that area will, of course, have advantages as well.

—I want to ask Senator Harradine about the modelling that no doubt understraps these amendments and the health minister's statement that the government's rebate proposal would increase participation in health funds by three per cent and also prevent a projected fall in participation from 30 to 20 per cent over the coming five to 10 years. How will this measure enhance those figures? If it does not, it will be a failed measure. In other words, is it going to increase the participation rate in the health funds by more than three per cent?

—If I could add to that question, I wonder if Senator Harradine might advise whether he believes a decline in private health insurance is per se a problem or the problem, and whether or not the survival of the private system depends on private health insurance. We have had issues about figures and the inability, as we have all seen, of the government to be able to justify the modelling. We have had dubious claims about the rebate taking pressure off the public health system for all the reasons given to us, including the fact that it is inevitable that money gets taken out of the bottom if there is money going out the top, equity measures, opportunity costs and so on. I wonder if that basic question might be addressed by Senator Harradine: is it his belief that the decline in health insurance is a problem or the problem?

—If I could respond to the matters that have been raised with me in the order in which they have been raised. Senator Chris Evans indicated that he has a letter to me from the Prime Minister. He has been pretty sharp. I received that letter at 8.10 p.m. on 10 December, which is today. I understand the Prime Minister's office has released that letter, and I gave the okay for that. I think it would be desirable, since the letter is now in the public domain, to have the letter incorporated into Hansard . I seek leave to incorporate it into Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—
Senator Brian Harradine
Senator for Tasmania
Suite S1.38
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Harradine
I refer to our recent discussions on the Government's private health insurance rebate legislation.

I consider that you have raised quite legitimate concerns about the `gaps' paid by people receiving treatment as privately insured patients. The Government believes that the amendment you have circulated would substantially address this problem and, accordingly, will support it. I note that the amendment would have the effect of setting a target of all private health insurance products having no gaps or known gaps by 1 July 2000. Funds that did not meet the target would not be permitted to offer the 30 per cent rebate as a premium reduction after that date. All fund contributors would, of course, retain access to a taxation or direct cash rebate.
I can also confirm that the Government will promote the facilitating measures concerning out of pocket costs and medical gaps previously discussed with Dr Wooldridge. These include:
. providing money for computer software development which is one of the limiting factors;
. changing the reinsurance pool to provide greater incentives for funds to offer no gap products; and
. asking Medibank Private to work on this area, as a matter of urgency.

We also discussed the provision of measures to alleviate the health problems of the aged and chronically ill. As you know, I made a major commitment at the recent ACOSS Congress to advance substantially the quality of health care delivered to older people, in the context of the International Year of Older Persons. Specifically, we will be:
. providing through Medicare for general practitioners to be involved in multi disciplinary care planning in case management for those with chronic and complex needs;
. giving incentives at the practice level for Gps to achieve multi disciplinary care plans for those over 65, or with chronic or complex need; and
. for those over 75, pay doctors to undertake an annual health assessment to focus on issues of prevention and better management of chronic illness.

Further, we talked of the provision of a coordinated care plan for disadvantaged elderly people. This would be a very substantial change in our health care system and the Government is prepared to trial it seriously. It is dependent on being able to cash-out hospital costs for a given group of people or a defined geographic area. The Government would also be willing to cash-out Medicare or pharmaceutical costs. I can confirm that in the next Budget, the Government will provide funds in the order of $25 million to run additional coordinated care trials in capital cities and selected regional centres to address the health care needs of older people who are chronically ill or disadvantaged.
The Government would, of course, appreciate your support in securing passage of the legislation in its amended form.
Yours sincerely
John Howard

talk.start.para: —Senator Evans raised questions about possible increases in premiums that the covering of the gap would entail. I suggest to Senator Evans that that has not been the experience of the National Mutual company in South Australia, as I understand the situation. These figures are available. I do not have them with me. As I understand it, you have got National Mutual already offering those policies to its members in South Australia.
—Why do we need these amendments then?

—To encourage that sort of activity elsewhere. Perhaps I can deal with Senator Margetts's question in regard to this matter at the same time. The whole point about it is that the medical profession does acknowledge the fact that, if there is a breakdown in the health insurance system, the public hospital system will also go down the drain. We do have to look at the effects not only on those hospitals and on the membership of the funds—and let us understand that 30 per cent of people are now in funds—but also on the public hospital system itself if the other system breaks down. That is something that has been concerning me for some considerable time.

speech.para: In response to Senator Margetts's question, the decline of the health insurance industry is not per se a problem, if you talk about per se, but the effects of that on both the members of the organisations and the public hospital system would, I believe, be quite disconcerting, if not devastating. Senator Brown, I am not sure I understood your question correctly. Maybe you could clarify it for me.

talk.start.para: —The question comes out of the figures that the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Dr Wooldridge, gave to me where he predicted that his measures in this legislation would increase the participation rate in insurance by three per cent. We would go from 30 per cent to 33 per cent. I know you were keen to have modelling on what the legislation was going to do. I wonder whether you have had modelling or whether you have had it from the government as to what improvement in that participation rate above 33 per cent your amendment will mean.
—No, I have not. Obviously the legislation does not consist of my measures. In fact, Senator Evans was correct when he referred to my speech. I indicate to the chamber that I prepared that speech—
—A couple of days ago.
—Well, I have been pretty flat out today. It has been a bit of a problem to change it.
—The last paragraph was different.
—Honourable senators might like to have a look in due course at the letter that I have incorporated in Hansard . It might indicate something as well.

speech.para: In answer to Senator Brown, no, I have not. Surely it stands to reason that, if funds can make arrangements with the private hospitals and with the medical specialists, particularly in certain areas, then clearly it is going to mean that the funds will be more and more attractive—those funds that at least have that no gap or known gap policy. They will be more attractive because they will be able to offer the cheaper premium rates—the rates which are discounted by 30 per cent—whereas those that do not have those policies will not be able to offer the rates. You might see some adjustment amongst those particular funds. There would then be even more incentive for them and others to undertake the necessary discussions and negotiations with the medical profession and with the private hospitals.

talk.start.para: —The difficulty with Senator Harradine's response is that it does come down to a supposition that there is going to be improved participation in health insurance because of the amendment he has made. The opposition has already made the point that one outcome is likely to be higher premiums, which has exactly the opposite effect because it would see more people shedding their private insurance. We are in the situation here of not knowing and that means, to some degree, flying by the seat of our pants.

speech.para: It is a very important matter, because the alternative that the opposition and the Greens have been putting quite strongly is that it would be better for the $1.7 billion to be going into the public health system. This would have a very clear impact for the good on the medical health services delivery to the Australian populace as a whole.

The problem with Senator Harradine's amendment is that while it appears on the face of it that there may be some beneficial effect in increasing the participation in health insurance, beyond that we have nothing to go by. We are being asked to give up the alternative of a much improved public health system—if the money went in that direction—in the hope that there will be some degree of improvement in participation rates in private health insurance.

We have already heard Senator Harradine say that it would be traitorous for doctors to increase fees on the back of this measure. But there is nothing in this amendment or in the legislation to stop that happening. Doctors—and I am one of them—are human beings and past practice has shown that some of them at least will move to take monetary advantage from a system that allows them to do so. The only way we can stop that is by regulating. I would be much happier as a member of the medical profession if that were an outcome that we were entertaining here tonight. But we are not. Therefore, what the argument for this measure comes down to is that it sounds like a good idea.

One thing I would like to know, which might help the committee in deciding whether this idea is going to be effectual, is what the participation rate in South Australia has been compared with other states. Has the participation rate in South Australia improved in recent times because of the availability of the no gap or known gap alternatives or hasn't it? If we could have those figures, it would give us some indication—even though it would be broad brush—as to whether in effect offering that policy option generally to the Australian populace is going to make a difference.

talk.start.para: —At the risk of being accused of cynicism, I share Senator Brown's doubts about some of the claims being made for the proposition. Not much can be expected of propositions drawn up in haste without public scrutiny. This suffers from some of those faults. Senator Harradine has already admitted that this can be done and is already occurring, so I am not quite sure what the great impact of this alleged legislative support will be. I will return to it in a minute. There is no implementation for 18 months, so this is not a measure that will have any immediate impact. It suffers from a lack of review and defined objectives. But, as I say, there are some worthy sentiments contained in it.

speech.para: I raised some concerns earlier. I think the parliamentary secretary may have misunderstood. I was not asking him what the costs of the measure are in terms of the package of the government's legislation; I was asking him what the costs will be of the amendment from Senator Harradine that has been agreed to by the government. Senator Lees asked the very question that Senator Harradine seeks to answer by this measure tonight. Mr Chalmers, from the Private Hospitals Association, provided the answer. This is not one of those witnesses who so upset Senator Knowles; this was Mr Chalmers from the Private Hospitals Association. When asked by Senator Lees about gap payments, he said at page 42 of the Hansard:

Senator, while my colleague is thinking about that, we have just done some quick `back of the notepad' calculations at the table. To answer the question of what would be the premium effect of covering existing medical gaps, that would require a premium increase in the order of 7.5 per cent. However, that would not necessarily ensure that the gap problem would be eliminated because there is no mechanism by which gaps can be quantified or capped.
So Mr Chalmers from the Private Hospitals Association seemed to be indicating that the idea was a nonsense and that it was not feasible.

The parliamentary secretary may or may not agree with that. Given that he is voting for the amendment and co-sponsoring it, I assume he does not accept that view. But does he accept, and has the government done the calculations on, the cost to premiums of the gap insurance? Do you agree with the private hospitals' estimate that it will cost a 7.5 per cent increase in premiums? Senator Harradine has now put this letter into the Hansard. I appreciate his doing that. I was not sure how I would come by it. I wanted to be a bit careful. I was not even sure that it was genuine, even though it was handed to me by Senator O'Brien, who is usually a most reliable source. It just got handed to me a few minutes ago. I am glad that Senator Harradine has corrected the public record.

In this letter from the Prime Minister to Senator Harradine, the government seems to have agreed to a whole range of measures in addition to the one provided for in the amendment. They go to a number of trials, incentives, a reinsurance pool and computer software development. They include $25 million to run additional coordinated care trials in capital cities and selected regional centres. In addition to the question I asked about the cost of the premium increase, I ask: what is the total cost of the contents of the letter to Senator Harradine? What is the financial impact of these commitments on the Commonwealth government?

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to note that Senator Evans once again notes how his introductory comments are often couched with cynicism. However, I do take seriously the questions that he has raised. One of the very important issues that must be addressed when we are dealing with private health insurance is the retention rate within the funds themselves. For many years now, the fall-off in membership has been one of the most serious factors influencing the continuation of premiums and, in fact, rising premiums for members who stay within the funds.

speech.para: Senator Brown referred to the South Australian experience. I know that National Mutual in South Australia has acknowledged that, in the changes to the system this year, the retention of membership has been one of the key goals. It is a very major economic factor in keeping the premiums either stable or as tightly measured as possible.

Senator Harradine's amendments now reinforce that opportunity for the funds to have innovative, new and special products that will not only appeal to retaining membership but also, hopefully, to expanding it and encouraging people in different areas. It will certainly be very focused in that area. The costs will have to be measured by the funds. Naturally, there will be normal economic adjustments based on their membership and participation, which are so vitally important. I believe that this amendment will go a long way to stabilising that area.

Senator Evans referred to the letter from the Prime Minister to Senator Harradine of today's date which acknowledges and puts on the record a number of the government's very important initiatives, not only those that Dr Wooldridge has been keenly pursuing now for some time in a number of particular areas and which I mentioned earlier in the debate this evening. The fact that Dr Wooldridge has been working for some time now in the area of gaps naturally meant that he, Senator Harradine and the Prime Minister were able to reach some very important agreements on this whole matter of the objectives that have surfaced in Senator Harradine's amendments.

Senator Evans refers to the other parts of the letter in which the Prime Minister acknowledges, very properly, to Senator Harradine that there are a number of other ongoing government programs to which he has alluded previously, particularly at the recent ACOSS Congress. Certainly, I am aware of the directives and the determination of both the Prime Minister and Dr Wooldridge in changing the areas of quality health care and how that is to be achieved, particularly measuring outcomes in a number of ways. The Prime Minister has quite rightly set out that there will be initiatives in the context of the International Year of Older Persons and has named a number of specific projects that the government was in the course of developing and has put on the record.

With regard to the area that Senator Evans mentioned, the coordinated care trials, I am pleased to note that the Prime Minister has confirmed a particular amount—and it may even be larger when the budget comes around—for these important projects. The coordinated care trials will have tremendous advantage not only for aged and elderly people but also for people in regional centres throughout Australia. I can speak from personal experience, as there are currently two such coordinated care trials operating in the Northern Territory, specifically in Aboriginal communities. They will have a major impact in delivering important health care outcomes.

I for one would certainly acknowledge that it is important that coordinated care trials should be expanded and built up to address the area of care for people in regional centres. If they are as successful as those that are operating in the Territory and elsewhere in Australia, I am sure that the advantage to people—particularly older people—who are chronically ill or disadvantaged will have a major impact.

I am sure that Senator Harradine welcomed the letter. I would say that most people in the community certainly would have. Many more of the items will be advanced in budget considerations and will certainly appear in full detail in the forward estimates in the budget.

talk.start.para: —I will ask the parliamentary secretary two questions but before I do that I will comment on something Senator Harradine said about his concerns at the way the level of private health insurance is dropping. Senator Harradine, even if we went down to only 20 per cent insured, that would cost us only $830 million to $900 million per year and not the $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion in this spending.

speech.para: Parliamentary Secretary, I asked you earlier if it was not the case already that if people wished to pursue unknown gaps—in other words, if they went in for an operation believing they were fully covered but then got a gap payment—they could take that through the process and find out that they did not have to pay. Hasn't that already been tried at law? Secondly, the minister has to approve increases in the cost of premiums set for the funds. Will the minister agree to an increase of what I suspect Mr Chalmers is right in saying is going to be about 7½ per cent on top of the increase that is already in the pipeline for next year—an increase that we understand is somewhere between five per cent and eight per cent?

talk.start.para: —Whilst the parliamentary secretary is seeking advice on that matter, perhaps I could add a further question. Part of the premise upon which the amendments are based is, I believe, that there will be a choice and an option, once there are further incentives, for health schemes to offer `no gap' or `no known gap' insurance. It sounds a bit like a product for sticking windows together, doesn't it? Once there is that extra incentive, what does it mean for states if they have very few choices already in health insurance packages or products? Does the parliamentary secretary have any specific figures on the coverage of health insurance and the numbers of health insurance products that are available in each state? I believe that in Western Australia we may have three. If that is not true, perhaps you can clarify that. What would happen? Is the government able to take any action if all three funds get together and decide not to offer this package?

—First I will address the two issues raised by Senator Lees. Her first question was in regard to unknown gaps. I am advised that that particular area would be treated as for any other debts. The second question posed was whether the government would agree to any increases on top of what may already be contemplated. Again, I am advised that we do not anticipate that any increases would be in the same proportion as those of previous years. In fact, Senator Harradine's amendment opens the area for negotiation to militate against this.

speech.para: Senator Margetts raised the question of how the impact would influence states and the agreements. Certainly, the recently negotiated arrangements with the states have been important. With regard to the public health systems area, I would remind Senator Margetts that the Howard government has provided the biggest ever increase in funding for public health systems: over $7.2 billion, an increase of 19 per cent. In forecasting that into the future, we have to be very mindful of the impact on national budgets. Any improvement in the area of private health insurance will militate against those future imposts on states.

talk.start.para: —I thank the parliamentary secretary for his answer, but that was not actually the question I asked. I may have said `packages' when I meant `funds'. Does the parliamentary secretary have some information he can provide to us about the number of funds that exist in states or territories? What would happen if, in a state or territory which had only a few funds, none of those funds offered a package for no gaps?

—We will certainly make that information available to Senator Margetts. With regard to the arrangements in states, I am firmly of the view that the innovation proposed in these amendments is going to create a special market pressure on funds, no matter where they are located—in any state or territory—and I am sure that it will be a very competitive market.

—I will just follow that up because Senator Margetts raised one of the scenarios. I want to take us back to one of the clauses in the amendments that Senator Harradine has moved. The proposed clause states:

speech.para: The Minister must not approve an application by a *health fund for the financial year beginning on 1 July 2000 or a later financial year unless the health fund provides its members with the choice of one or more of the following types of policies:
(a) a *no gap policy;
(b) a *known gap policy.

In effect, that looks like a sanction that is to be applied against the health funds—that is, unless they provided this choice, there would be some sanction. The letter that Senator Harradine received today from the Prime Minister, which has been incorporated, states:

I note that the amendment would have the effect of setting a target of all private health insurance products having no gaps or known gaps by 1 July 2000. Funds that did not meet the target would not be permitted to offer the 30 per cent rebate as a premium reduction after that date. All fund contributors would, of course, retain access to a taxation or direct cash rebate.

It seems to be a slightly different understanding of the sanction. So I would like some clarification as to whether the sanction is to be applied against the health funds if they do not provide this choice or, as it appears in the Prime Minister's letter, whether the only sanction is that they would not be able to offer that particular rebate as a premium reduction, that people would still be able to get the taxation or direct cash rebate.

Is the sanction on the fund really only restricting them in terms of one of the three options of paying the rebate to people but not restricting them from continuing not to offer the policies that you are suggesting are vital? I just want to get it clear what Senator Harradine thinks the amendment does.

talk.start.para: —That is precisely what the amendment does. That is a penalty. Is that not a sufficient penalty? You could then have a number of funds offering the no gap or known gap policies having their premiums presented to potential fund members at a particular rate; others would not. Those that did not so offer could not provide on any of their tables a cut rate from their premium.

speech.para: In the marketplace—if you are talking about the marketplace—it is an enormous advantage and an enormous incentive for funds to make sure that they offer this particular product, and it is what I propose in this amendment. To do otherwise would be to penalise the fund members for the failure of the fund to do what it ought to be doing. It would be unfair to penalise the fund members by taking away their 30 per cent reduction provided either by cash or through the taxation system. When advertising, the funds that were not participating and were not offering these particular policies would be at a great disadvantage because, in particular tables by comparison with the other funds, their premiums would have to be advertised 30 per cent above the others.

I come back to a point that you made. You are concerned about the failure of this to cap the fees that are charged by specialists. I think it will have the effect of capping them because there will be a lot of pressure on the funds to come to arrangements with public hospitals, particularly with medical specialists. But, let me make it clear to the committee, as most members of the committee must know, that it is, unfortunately, unconstitutional for the parliament to cap the fees of medical specialists. Senator Brown said we ought to be regulating them. Quite frankly, I tell you right here and now that I would be the first one doing that. But we cannot. I have been through it the last few weeks and you cannot do it. The states do have the powers to fix fees, but we do not. I know it is not perfect, but at least it is an advance. I am putting it to the committee and am hoping that it will be carried.

talk.start.para: —We ought to have the states come together with the Commonwealth for that purpose. We do it on so many other things, so I cannot see why we cannot do it when coming to an arrangement on capping medical fees. That seems to me to be an extremely good goal.

speech.para: I want to raise two things. What improvement has there been in the participation rate in South Australia, which has this system that is being advocated or promoted in this amendment, vis-a-vis the other states? Margaret in my office tells me that, in 1997, hospital cover in South Australia—this is an average sort of scheme—had gone to 267 per cent of 1989 levels compared with 220 per cent for the country as a whole. In other words, premiums have gone up faster in South Australia than they have in the rest of the country. Is this related to the fact that South Australia had this rapid change across to a known gap option? I do not know, but that is the sort of thing this committee should know.

It is a pity that we do not have time here to look at the ramifications of this amendment. I suggest, Senator Harradine, that it would have been a more assured outcome for you had the analysis and scrutiny that should have taken place on this amendment been made before we had the vote on it. As it is, nothing is going to change.

The other point evident here is: sure, as Senator Harradine says, some funds will be able to say, `Look, our premiums are 30 per cent lower.' But what is to stop the other funds from saying, `Look, our premiums are higher, but you're going to get a cheque in the mail or a tax deduction as a result of this new scheme coming in, and overall our premiums will be lower.' If the only thing to come out of this is to be an advertising advantage that will induce people into the funds, all of us in this committee know that a good advertising person will be able to put the argument in the other direction if fund participants themselves are to be able to get the benefit of the rebate—even if the fund cannot give it in reduction of cost of premiums.

I think we will not see much good result at all come out of this amendment. But we will see a heck of a lot of money go from the government coffers, into the rebate incentive, into the private system. As a committee, we are left with no figures, no modelling, no argument essentially, other than this being a good advertising way of increasing membership. I just do not think that is good enough, particularly considering the amount of money that is involved.

talk.start.para: —I agree with Senator Brown, but his arguments against Senator Harradine's amendment hold true of the whole bill. While I think it is a good argument, as I say, the government has not provided any modelling for any of this, so I do not think it takes us much further. Yes, we have another amendment that is uncosted, unmodelled, with no real idea of impact—but then the whole bill is like that. So I have given up on that argument. That has had no weight and no success in moving the Senate more generally.

speech.para: I do not want to spend too much time on this because, quite frankly, I think it is a very modest minor amendment that does not go to the heart of this bill nor to the heart of the problems of private health insurance. I think the sort of thing that Senator Harradine talked about in terms of sanction is more of a minor inconvenience to the funds. Nevertheless, that is not really essential debate on the bill. I do not think we ought to delay the committee stage too long on that issue. I think there are much bigger issues in terms of the bill.

I think it is unfortunate that we have not got any costings out of the parliamentary secretary in relation to this measure, nor in relation to the undertakings given to Senator Harradine. They obviously add to the total cost of this package; they add to the money that the government is throwing at getting this package through the parliament—and I think it is not unreasonable for us to expect to have that properly costed and be put before the parliament. But that is obviously not going to happen.

Again, I do not want to labour the point, but it is more money thrown at the problem in order to get the bill passed, because that is the political imperative. There is no health imperative, there is no economic imperative. It is just, `Throw money at the problem, get it fixed, get it passed; if we need to give $25 million for coordinated care, we'll throw that in as well; when you've got $1.5 billion, what's another $25 million? It's all big numbers and it's all got out of control, and there's no basis for any of it, there's no modelling for any of it—so, what the heck, what's a bit more? But the failure of the government to provide any costing on that I think is a sad reflection.

I just want to make this clear: the Labor Party is most concerned about gaps. They are a major issue. They need to be treated seriously. They need to be treated more seriously than was possible, it seems, in a couple of hours of discussions this afternoon in order to get a compromise to get the bill passed. What we proposed—and what the Democrats and the Greens proposed—was a proper look at these issues; that we would not pass this bill until we dealt with the gaps issue, until we dealt with the premium rises issue and had a coordinated thorough look at how to get good health policy. What we have instead is a slipshod bill that is throwing money at the problem, throwing money at people who do not need support, and denying that health support to people who do need it.

As I say, I do not want to labour this issue any longer. I do not disagree with the objectives; I think they are worthy. It is a major issue that needs to be tackled. I do not think this amendment goes anywhere near far enough in dealing with that. But that is not to say that it is not worth supporting, in the sense that it is at least giving some recognition to the problem and some recognition to the fact that we need to do much more about gaps and premiums. But, as I say, we will not solve those problems tonight because there is no serious attempt to deal with those problems in this bill.

talk.start.para: —Senator Brown raised the issue of the statistics based on South Australia. Obviously he has put them together based on anecdotal comment, whether in his office or elsewhere. But I appreciate his concern. I will seek that information for him. I was under the impression that what he was seeking was rather like comparing apples and pears, particularly with regard to the time scales covered. Looking at the prospective nature of what is intended in this legislation and the advantages of keeping people in a good and proper and balanced system, I thought they would be more the objectives and the purposes that we ought to be focusing on.

speech.para: Both Senator Evans and Senator Brown have raised a number of commercial and economic issues in that area, whether relating to the sanctions or other issues. All I can say is that, from my experience in business, obviously there is a big difference between us: with their appreciation of the factors of commerce and economic priorities and business operations, I would say that they are way off the track.

talk.start.para: —Just quickly, I would put one little perspective on this. If the competitive market is used as the model for the way this particular measure will work, you have to keep in mind that a competitive model works on full information. So I guess that people actually would have to go off and find out the information from the various health funds.

speech.para: But also with the ability to quickly transfer, I believe—and, okay, these are my personal feelings—that people generally stick with a fund, unless they make a major decision to change. If I am not mistaken, that usually happens because there are substantial penalties with what you can claim and what you cannot claim. I do not know that you can transfer those over from one fund to another, but for many kinds of health care you have to wait a certain number of years.

The private health insurance market operates in such a way that people will not transfer from one fund to the other, like in superannuation, because they are concerned about losing benefits they have to wait several years to obtain. The reality is that this market does not operate in the way a lot of other markets operate—not even in the way superannuation funds operate—and we have to keep those issues in mind when we think about incentives we are offering to create a market situation or to keep people in a market. It might have an impact on attracting new people to the market, but this has been unproven in all the statistics we have been asked to believe. In reality, it will not necessarily operate as a real market incentive for those existing clients of health insurance, because you are unable to easily move from one fund to the other without losing some of the benefits you have to wait for.

talk.start.para: —I am looking at the Prime Minister's letter and the third paragraph states:

speech.para: I can also confirm that the Government will promote the facilitating measures concerning out of pocket costs and medical gaps previously discussed with Dr Wooldridge. These include:
. providing money for computer software development which is one of the limiting factors;

What precisely is meant by `one of the limiting factors'? I do not understand what is meant by that. What are these limiting factors? Can somebody identify more clearly what is meant by that sentence?

talk.start.para: —I am advised that it is electronic transfer of information for billing purposes.

—I will pursue that one at estimates with a great deal of interest to look at the privacy aspects in a few of those. It is the third point that really interests me, which states that the government will be:

speech.para: . . . asking Medibank Private to work on this area, as a matter of urgency.
What compensation is going to be put in place for Medibank Private to undertake this work? What are the guidelines and the terms of reference for the work that Medibank Private will undertake?

talk.start.para: —Given that Senator West is quoting from a letter of today's date, I think it is quite appropriate to point out that these are matters that will be developed between the various parties.

—It is a bit like a pig in a poke. Medibank Private was separated from Medicare some time ago as far as its accommodation was concerned, because there was a need, we were told, for it to be able to compete and it had to be put on a level playing field. I want to ensure that Medibank Private remains on a level playing field. I would have thought this had already been considered and, according to this letter, this is not the first time this discussion has happened. What guarantees can the government give to ensure that Medibank Private remains on a level playing field?

—This is not a matter that really relates to this particular legislation. Whilst the Prime Minister's letter and my comments earlier this evening referred to the conversations between Dr Wooldridge and Medibank Private, they are matters that will be pursued and Medibank Private will be competing with other funds already offering no gaps. I am sure the matters of detail will be addressed between Dr Wooldridge and Medibank Private.

—I do not understand how the parliamentary secretary can make that point. We have in our possession a letter from the Prime Minister to Senator Harradine, which has kindly been provided, that commences:

speech.para: Dear Senator Harradine
I refer to our recent discussions on the Government's private health insurance rebate legislation.
And it concludes:
The Government would, of course, appreciate your support in securing passage of the legislation in its amended form.

The issues of substance that Senator West raised happen to be in the body of the letter. How can the parliamentary secretary seriously say to this committee that this matter is not relevant to the legislation that is being debated by the committee at this time? It is obviously an element of the deal that has been struck between Senator Harradine and the government. That must be obvious to everyone. I am sure even Senator Harradine would accept that is the case. I think it is quite disingenuous for the parliamentary secretary to come into this place and make that point in response to a serious question raised by Senator West.

talk.start.para: —It is a pity Senator Faulkner has not taken the time to read the letter very carefully. In the third paragraph of the letter, the Prime Minister says:

speech.para: I can also confirm that the Government will promote the facilitating measures concerning out of pocket costs and medical gaps previously discussed with Dr Wooldridge. These include:
And then three points:
. providing money for computer software development which is one of the limiting factors;
. changing the reinsurance pool to provide greater incentives for funds to offer no gap products; and
. asking Medibank Private to work on this area, as a matter of urgency.

I mentioned earlier in the debate this evening that the minister for health is pursuing those matters at length and has been for some time. The Prime Minister's letter confirms to Senator Harradine that those important objectives have a good standing. They are matters of government activity that very rightly were confirmed to Senator Harradine.

talk.start.para: —We know that the negotiations have not just been limited to one discussion between Senator Harradine and the Prime Minister and one letter from the Prime Minister to Senator Harradine. Surely the parliamentary secretary is not going to suggest that is the case. Really and truly, you cannot con all of us all of the time, Senator Tambling. It is quite clear what has occurred here.

speech.para: These things happen in politics. Deals are struck. Arrangements are come to. This is a done deal, Senator Tambling. Don't try to con me that this isn't an element—and it might even be quite an important element—of the deal that has been struck. Don't suggest for one minute, just because there were preliminary discussions and negotiations, that they don't form part of the deal. That is why I happen to believe that Senator West is entitled to a proper response to a serious question in relation to this matter when a letter like this is made public in the fashion it has.

We all know why it has been made public. We all know that, in order to get this piece of legislation through this committee, through the Senate, these arrangements have been come to between the government and Senator Harradine. A lot of people would say, `Well, that is the way the place works.' It is not that unusual in politics. It is part of the political process for a deal to be struck. But let's not have sanctimonious hypocrisy from the responsible parliamentary secretary handling the bill for the government suggesting that that is not an integral part of the arrangement that has been come to.

talk.start.para: —It is strange that Senator Faulkner would want to play theatre in an Alice in Wonderland type of environment. Surely he is aware from his experience, both as a minister and in this place, that governments do operate multifaceted and complementary policy initiatives. The Prime Minister's letter merely confirms that there are a number of complementary policy initiatives in this area. It is quite within very good grounds to establish that in any letter to Senator Harradine, as he would with many other constituents on health issues.

—We know that initially the government was saying that this 30 per cent tax rebate was going to cost $1.4 billion to $1.5 billion. We found out last Friday from the department that there was a mistake; it is now $1.7 billion. But on the Medibank Private work area alone, what is this going to blow the budget out to? Where is this going to take the additional costs out to?

—I think the Labor Party is engaging in catch the trick type questions. This is irrelevant to this legislation. The issues relating to Medibank Private are matters relating to other areas of government policy and will be appropriately funded in those areas of government.

—I say to the parliamentary secretary that this is not irrelevant to this legislation. We are talking about the gap part of the insurance. We are talking about private health insurance rebates. There are costs in this to the government. What we want to know is what are the costs to the government. Is there an estimate, a guesstimate? Or are we just buying, as I said earlier, a pig in a poke—you don't have any idea what it is going to do to the budget? We have the right, as a responsible opposition and as a responsible parliament, to ask what the ramifications are for these changes in terms of cost.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE AND HEALTH INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1998
The bill.

talk.start.para: —I had listed some amendments, but as these were contingent on the passage of earlier amendments I now withdraw them.

speech.para: Bill agreed to.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE) BILL 1998
The bill.

talk.start.para: —Again, the amendments that I was to move to this bill were contingent on earlier amendments passing. As they didn't pass, I withdraw these amendments.

speech.para: Bill agreed to.

Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1998 reported with amendments; Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 1998 reported without amendments; Taxation Laws Amendment (Private Health Insurance) Bill 1998 reported without amendments; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Tambling) proposed:
That the bills be now read a third time.

talk.start.para: —I don't want to delay the Senate long, but I do want to indicate formally on behalf of the opposition that we will be opposing the third reading of these bills. We have consistently opposed this initiative by the government because it does not solve any of the problems of private health insurance. It is a complete waste of public funds.

speech.para: We also put the government on notice that we will be closely monitoring the use of those public funds and drawing to the attention of the Australian public what a gigantic waste of money this proposal is. We will keep the government up to the mark, if this is carried, to ensure that it is widely understood that in order to pursue some political advantage the government has wasted $1.7 billion of public funds. If it does not meet the objectives the government sets for it, the government will have to explain why such money has been wasted in the pursuit of an objective they cannot define against performance criteria they cannot produce.

So we retain our opposition to this legislation. We will be voting against it on the third reading. I do not wish to re-cover all the ground as to why the opposition maintains its opposition to the bills. That has been covered adequately during the debate. We oppose the third reading of these bills.
Question put:
That these bills be now read a third time.

talk.start.para: —I think it is always good that, when a motion is sprung on, we know what we are adopting. A report being noted is one thing. In relation to a report being adopted, it is nice if we know what we are adopting.
—It is renewal of references from the last parliament.

—Senator Margetts, I was handed this particular matter on behalf of Senator McKiernan, who I see is in the chamber. My understanding is that the references committee met on 10 December 1998 and considered references not disposed of at the end of the 38th Parliament. The committee resolved to recommend to the Senate that, firstly, the following inquiry of the 38th Parliament—the rights and obligations of the media—not be re-adopted, the committee's first report on this matter in 1994, and its report of off-the-record shield laws for journalists' confidential sources. Although the committee believes the issue to be important, it does not consider it appropriate to continue with a matter that was first referred to it in May 1993. It would prefer to start with a new reference on the matter and will consider this at a later time.
—Thank you for that clarification. You can imagine why I, over the last couple of days, have been a bit careful about what I am adopting and voting on in relation to committee reports.
—I understand it was circulated before dinner, but it is better to clarify it. I put the question that the motion be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown moving a motion to provide that further consideration of the bills be postponed until the first day of sitting after 1 July 1999.

I do this because it is my belief that the Senate has got the process wrong on some of the most important legislation, in the Prime Minister's own words, that there will be in his period of government. This package is going to have enormous ramifications for the people of Australia and their environment.

There were two better options than the one of a committee system being set up to provide for a vote in this place before 1 July next year. The best option was that this whole matter should have been investigated before the election, and the results of those investi gations ought to have been before the Australian people when they voted at the election. After all, the Prime Minister did say that he got a mandate from the election. I know there are figures to show that that is wrong.

The second best option was for us to ensure that, seeing the vote of the people is so important to the Prime Minister, the Senate which was voted in at the election is in place when this matter is determined. That of course will happen on 1 July next year. That is why it is very important that we follow through the logic of the Prime Minister himself to make sure that the vote in the Senate reflects the vote of the people when they went to the election. That will not be possible until 1 July.

I would have thought that the Democrats, who are not here at the moment, would have welcomed this provision because they will clearly have the balance of power. If they wanted to really influence the impact this package will have on the people of Australia—and the Leader of the Democrats has said that she will not accept it if it is not fair—then they could assure that by supporting this motion. They could ensure that by making sure the Senate holds over the vote on this important package until 1 July next year. That is impeccable logic. That is the Prime Minister's own logic being followed through from the House of Representatives to the Senate.

I gave notice of this contingent motion to the Senate for consideration before the debate we had in the last few weeks, which came up with the committee system. But I want to finally say that it is my belief that after all the committees have sat, after all those community groups, interests and business houses have brought forward their evidence, it will come down to a numbers result in this place not too different from the one we saw a moment ago. That concerns me greatly. I think we should do better than that.

I ask honourable senators to look carefully at this motion and the good sense behind it. I ask honourable senators to consider that it should be supported. I cast my eyes around the Senate to see whether there is anyone who will second the motion so that it can be put to a vote.

talk.start.para: —We removed seconding 10 years ago.

—Yes, but you miss the point, Senator. I want somebody to say that they will second it, if they will, because I think it is an important motion. However, that said, I also want to take this opportunity to wish everybody a Merry Christmas.

—It will come as no surprise to honourable senators that the government will oppose the motion to suspend standing orders. The Senate has voted to create one of the most extensive and lengthy inquiries in Senate history. I am informed by the Clerk that it may not be the longest inquiry but certainly, with a number of committees looking into it, it will be an extensive inquiry which will allow virtually any Australian with any interest in the reform of the tax system the opportunity to communicate to their elected representatives on these matters.

speech.para: The final committee will report on about 19 April. To accept the logic of Senator Brown, firstly, that we need to suspend standing orders and, secondly, that we need to suspend the vote on this historic package of bills till 1 July would mean that you really could not seek to put anything through the parliament, except for old legislation, until 1 July after any election, which I think is a ludicrous proposition. If you apply the logic of Senator Brown, you would really have to wait for a further three years until the next set of senators came up for election. The Senate was designed by our founding fathers. They may have made some mistakes, but one of the reasons they designed it was not to reflect the same mandate that was given—

talk.start.para: —Because every Liberal elected in 1996 opposed the GST.

—Senator Ray says that every Liberal who was elected in 1996 said that they would not vote for a GST, just as those senators elected in 1993 on the Labor side stood on a platform that they would vote for a GST in the Senate. We can have this argument all night. The reality is that there is a different mandate in the Senate from that in the House of Representatives. It is quite ludicrous to say that you cannot pass any legislation through the Senate until the new senators come in. We have already shown here today and in this session—and I take this opportunity to thank honourable senators for their hard work during this short session—that a lot of constructive work can be done. A lot of constructive work has been done. The work of the committee system and the Senate as a whole, as we lead up to the debate of this historic package, is vital. I oppose this motion.

—The opposition will not support this motion to suspend standing orders that has been moved by Senator Brown. Let us be frank. As far as we are concerned, we have already agreed to a timetable for a Senate inquiry into the GST and related legislation. That timetable, if I recall correctly, will see the legislation available for debate in the Senate some time after 19 April 1999.

speech.para: The opposition is not about delaying debate on the government's GST proposals; we are and always have been about a very serious level of parliamentary and public scrutiny of these particular proposals. We have also been very serious about providing an appropriate forum to allow the public, particularly those who are going to be affected so adversely by the goods and services tax, to have their say before the committees of this Senate.

The other point that needs to be made in relation to the progress of the inquiry is that any Senate inquiry like this, in large measure, depends on some level of willingness on the part of the government to cooperate in providing the committee with adequate information. I think it is very disappointing to have seen this government's rejection of my proposed return to order for the modelling studies and the assumptions and other documentation on which the GST proposals are based. I think that was a very ominous signal to Senator Cook and his colleagues on the select com mittee and those who are serving on the references committees inquiring into these particular proposals.

As for the opposition's attitude, we remained, of course, resolutely opposed to a goods and services tax. It is, as we have said consistently, an extraordinarily unfair burden on those Australians who can least afford it. Let me turn to the other element of Senator Brown's motion, which goes to the composition of the Senate after July 1999. It does change. In one sense, it will be a very significant change because no longer will we have the government accepting the vote of Senator Colston, which they have consistently done since the last election.

talk.start.para: —A sleazy, corrupt deal!

—Of course it was, Senator Schacht. Mr Howard did not announce his approach in relation to Senator Colston at any stage either during or before the election campaign. No, he just snuck around and did a deal after the election in relation to accepting Senator Colston's vote. That really means that we are going to have six months more of timeserving from Senator Colston—that is what you can expect until July 1999—six months more of the venal bloodsucking approach that Senator Colston has to politics.
—Senator Faulkner, I ask you to withdraw those words.

—If I mentioned an unparliamentary word, I will withdraw it. There will be six months more embarrassment to this parliament and to the Australian Senate and, of course, six months more of ridicule and contempt, which is most deserved in the case of Senator Colston. The government stands condemned for accepting this tainted vote from this tainted individual.
—Senator Faulkner, you should not use that expression.

—What expression, Madam President? I will withdraw `tainted' from the front of `individual'. The government, in accepting this tainted vote, misled the Australian public before and during the election campaign and stands condemned for the approach it has taken in relation to this particular matter. So, of course, things will change in the Senate after July 1999, and in relation to Senator Colston they will certainly change for the better.

—Never in the history of the Senate has there been such a thing as a `pure Senate'. What Senator Brown is saying is that he prefers the numbers after July 1999. I do too; nevertheless, historically, this chamber has got on and done its business, because we have six-year terms. That does not recognise the parties and the change of power in this place. That is the way we do business.

speech.para: You cannot actually say that a government cannot try to bring in its program with a certain timing. That is up to the executive. It is one of the privileges of the executive to put matters that it considers important before this chamber. Our responsibility then as an opposition is to give it public scrutiny. The scrutiny process eventually achieved through a whole lot of argy-bargy and caving in by the government was a multifaceted committee system making inquiries and then agreeing to a timetable when this legislation can be put and considered over a reasonable time span—as I understand it, from 19 April—so that there will be a result one way or the other before 1 July.

Senator Brown is wrong to say that the Democrats will have the balance of power next year. On some occasions we will have the balance of power. On some occasions he will have the balance of power. On some occasions either Senator Harradine or—depending on other matters—Senator-elect Hill may have the balance of power. It is not just one party that will have the balance of power in this chamber.

But one thing this chamber will do is make sure that this legislation is given good and proper scrutiny. Compare that with the farce of the last three days in the House of Representatives; compare that to the guillotining through of 16 complex bills—the centrepiece of the government's strategy, they say, for the next three years—belted through with only the most cursory debate, consideration and scrutiny. I have never been a Senate chauvinist, but I think in any democracy we should have had a slightly longer consideration than that which occurred in that farce over in the House of Representatives.

But you will never get a pure Senate in terms of mandate or anything else. In 1993, we had senators elected—one lot supporting the GST, another lot opposing it—who said that they would not block an incoming government. That was the strategy that people went to the election with. In 1996, we had the Labor Party saying they would not introduce a GST; we had a Liberal Party saying they would not support a GST. Several people sitting opposite went out and campaigned on the `never, ever' pledge of their leader, Mr John Howard, saying they would never have a GST.

So there is no such thing as a pure Senate. You only have a mandate in this place if you have 39 votes. That is the only definition that you can have in the end. I do not think Senator Brown's motion would ever be acceptable to me, simply because of the history of this place. You deal with the numbers in existence.

Those opposite did not particularly like Senator Faulkner's comments, but the fact is that since August 1996, and especially in the last four weeks, this Senate voting process has been totally perverted, because one person elected as a Labor senator six years ago on the full resources, the platform and the pledge of loyalty to the Labor Party has left. Those on the other side say, `Do not criticise him. You are being a bit harsh before Christmas. You are just poor losers. You should just roll over and forget it.' But when the boot goes on other foot and someone from the Liberal Party deserts, see if they take that same avuncular attitude. See if they say, `That is all right. Senator Heffernan has decided to leave the Liberal Party. Good old Bill. See you later, Bill. We don't mind. You are still going to be invited to the Christmas party, even though you are a traitor. Don't worry about it.' That is the Liberal attitude.

The Liberal Party has always treated deserters kindly. Look at Francis and Jennings in Victoria who got expelled. Have a look at the current South Australian Liberal Party. Have a look at anyone who has deserted the conser vative cause. They get the same degree of contempt that we would offer to anyone who leaves the Labor Party.
Senator Ferris interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Ferris interjects, given the mess that she has got the South Australian branch of the Liberal Party in. You will never get a purist Senate. We deal with what we have got. Senator Brown, an executive has the right to put its program and it has the right to expect it to be considered in a reasonable time span. Our duty—your duty, my duty and everyone else's duty—is to make sure it is scrutinised to the maximum. Then we have to put it with whatever the numbers are. (Time expired)

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The only reason I rise is that it strikes me as extraordinary hypocrisy that we should be subjected to this sort of behaviour. I can well understand those who regret the fact that there have been defections from the ranks and I can well understand that you might complain about it from time to time. But that in no shape or form ought to excuse the vitriol and the constant vituperation that comes from Senator Faulkner in particular.
